0/post_text/0: Hi guys, some advice please.  Harrison has been on a slow wean off of Maxidex for the last 6 weeks (2 drops a day).  He has had a really bad virus which I thought would have affected his eyes but at the hospital on Friday they said that his eyes were quiet.  However, the pressure is now borderline and they can see the start of cateracts.  They took him off Maxidex immediately and he is on Vexol three times a day.  I knew this day may come as they couldnt keep him on Maxidex forever. Does Vexol have any side effects?  Is it just weaker that Maxidex.  I always come out of these appointments with questions I should have asked!! I am keeping positive but really scared what comes next as they said he may flare up.  I am hoping that he won't but not sure what happens next if he does.  His vision is fine at the moment.  Any advice on the next steps would really help as back to Moorfields next week.  Thanks.
1/post_text/1: Hope Harrison is over the virus now and good news that his eyes didn't flare.
1/post_text/2: Vexol is similar to Maxidex, but lower strength. It's much less likely to raise pressure. If Harrison flares on the three drops of Vexol, they may increase the number of drops a day, try a different steroid such as Predsol (medium strength) or Lotemax (not supposed to raise pressure). Alternatively, you may be told to revert back to Maxidex and use a pressure lowering drop to keep pressure down. What happens with the choice of drops largely depends on the severity of any flare.
1/post_text/3: The cataracts caused by steroid are often very slow growing and it may be years before they require removal, especially if steroid drops are used infrequently.
1/post_text/4: We are all often scared of what comes next and if you are worried that immunosuppressant treatment is the next step for Harrison, then it might be a good idea to discuss this at your appointment next week.
2/post_text/0: Hi Tanya,
2/post_text/1: I can't really add anything to Maxine's comments as she's covered it all!  All I would say is that again I would double check that when you're told his eyes are quiet they do mean zero cells and not that there are cells sitting at 1+ or under on the scale.
2/post_text/2: Remember also that the uveitis causes cataracts not just the steroid drops :/
3/post_text/0: Maxine/Nikki
0/post_text/1: Tanya
0/post_text/2: xxx
1/post_text/5: Immunosuppression is usually considered when both eyes are constantly flaring, when uveitis is intermediate or posterior, or when there is a systemic autoimmune condition which also requires treatment. While it may be difficult to accept such treatment, it often means that the steroid complications of cataract and high ocular pressure are avoided.
1/post_text/6: I hope Harrison's pressures are back within normal levels next week, there is no flare and you are able to continue the steroid taper.
2/post_text/3: Take care

3/post_text/2: Thank you

1/post_text/1: That's really worrying. I assume the conjunctivitis has been diagnosed and is being treated in the hope that it's controlled rapidly before wandering hands carry the infection to the uveitis eye. I would give the eye clinic a ring - should the uveitis eye become infected, you need to know what to do about the steroid drops. While I would like to think antibiotic drops and steroid drops combined would take care of things, I think this is a situation where only expert advice will do. I would hope that rapid treatment of conjunctivitis in the uveitis eye, should this happen, would prevent a uveitic flare, but can't be sure of this.

14/post_text/0: Hi Kaitlyn
14/post_text/1: I am so sorry and really feel for you having gone through all this with steroids.  I am hugely anti steroids other than an emergency measure but not for long term.  I truly think you should go back and make a fuss.  You are very young and as I understand you have had it for a while so really need a long term effective treatment plan to ensure you do not get any permanent eye damage.   I would look to see about going back on cyclosporin or one of the other similar immunosuppresants or talk to them about an anti-tnf drug like Humira or infliximab.  I fear the steroids at 40mg will kick the inflammation but as soon as you taper down it will come back especially as an orbital floor steroid injection did not work for you.  I know I could not tolerate steroids from a whole range of issues like sleeplesss nights to achy limbs although at 40 mg it would get rid of the fluid but you cannot stay on that amount long term.  No harm to also get a second opinion with a uveitis specialist, really would be worth it.    Keep us informed on how you get on and do not be embarrassed to make a fuss you have a right to, your eyes are so important.

7/post_text/2: It's not unusual for a single immunosuppressant not to work, so trying two in combination is one option. Another option is to go to the third line therapy of anti TNF drugs which Scotland will fund for severe uveitis. And it sounds like yours is severe.
7/post_text/3: I had constant cystoid macular oedema in both eyes like you've got and infliximab banished it from one eye. With the other eye, the oedema, which started three months after diagnosis, has remained. My specialist has discussed options about that which include injecting methotrexate into the eye. Possibly this might be risky for you unless it's something to do with steroid that causes the reaction you've had.
7/post_text/4: I hope you get answers about what's going on now when you go in and your specialist has a new plan for your care at the August appointment.
8/post_text/4: I asked him what my other option is to get rid of the fluid as we seem to have exhausted all options. He said that the ozurdex is the best and quickest option, however, if my specialist doesn't think it's safe to do it again then he isn't sure. He said there was one other injection I could get but he doesn't think its been approved in uveitis patients yet.
8/post_text/5: So as per usual it's anoyher waiting game until next Thursday when I get to see my specialist. However i am anxious to hear what he thinks.
9/post_text/1: So glad you did go in and discovered inflammation rather than some horrible complication of surgery is the problem.
9/post_text/2: Hopefully the steroid drops will have calmed things by the time your specialist gets back. One of the things Diamox does is get rid of unwanted fluid in the body, so it may help with the macular oedema, reducing the retinal build up of fluid.
9/post_text/3: There are anti vegf injections which work well at getting rid of retinal fluid, but the effect is temporary. For them to have better effect, the inflammation causing the build up of fluid has to be sorted out. I had those injections at one point, but as soon as they wore off, the macular oedema came straight back. Infliximab sorted out both problems for my eyes.
9/post_text/4: Please keep us updated on how you get on when your specialist returns.
11/post_text/1: Not sure when your appointment is this week but if you are able to let us know how your are getting on.
11/post_text/2: Becca x
12/post_text/1: I am wondering why ozurdex is not an option for you if it gets rid of the fluid for a while.  It only lasts a few months so hence keeps coming back so I would have thought that long term this is not a viable plan but as an emergency solution for now until your plan is changed.  I would certainly discuss taking another immunosuppressant which would at least control it if you find the right one.  They take about 3 months to fully kick in so maybe you could have another ozurdex in the interim.  Diamox is usually given to reduce the pressure so I am wondering if you had high pressure too from the steroid drops.  Perhaps another option would be an orbital floor injection (steroids injected to the side of the eye)  similar effect to ozurdex but does not last as long but it may stave things off while you take an immunosuppresant and it has  time to start working.  As Becca said I think it would be a good idea to really go through the options with your specialist so something can  be found to control this.  So many people keep the uveitis controlled with immunosuppressants.  Like you steroids did not agree with me and I feel they are unnecessary long-term but an immunosuppresant or even two maybe your answer.  There is also evidence to show in some people if you take these for a period of time and they work, you may come off them at a later stage and it  kicks your immune system to readjust and behave again.  Finally, as Maxine says  I would most definitely ask your specialist about Humira or infliximab which they will give in Scotland.  I am on Humira and it certainly saved me.  I hope you find a new successful plan which is what you need.  Let us all know how you get on as I know how miserable this can be until you find the right treatment programme.
13/post_text/1: So I was back in yesterday and he said my only options were prednisone or ozurdex. But he strongly advised me against the ozurdex due to my last reaction to it which I understood. So after years of saying I will not go back on prednisone, I am back on it 40mg a day.
13/post_text/2: Tania, the reason my dr advised me against the ozurdex was becuase during my last one I ended up with a lot of bleeding inside my eye, my retina was pulling and I had the biggest uveitis flate up I had ever had. I thought the implant had came to the front of my eye as sitting at the bottom of the colour of my eye was this cream coloured stuff. Which turned out to be puss from the uveitis flare up, I had to get a steroid injection, an antibiotic injection and sit with a steroid IV in my arm for a while. Was all a little too much for me.

0/post_text/0: I'm 13 and I was diagnosed with chronic intermediate uveitis on the 15.4.2014. when I first went to the Newcastle eye clinic I had to have cyclopentolate 1% eye drops in both eyes 3 times a day as well as predforte 1% 6 times in both eyes daily. Then there was no improvement I had pressure in both of my eyes off being on predforte for so long (as it is a steroid drop)so I had to start having cosop eye drops 2 a day to help with that. then there was a slight improvement in my eyes so I went onto cyclopentolate 1% once a day and predforte 0.5% 3 times a day. then I went back and the inflammation came back a bit worse so I had to go back on the cosop eye drops again, and they changed my eyes drops from predforte to lotemax 3 times a day and I stopped the cyclopentolate eye drops. they were working and then they stopped working as effectively so they were literally fighting to save my eye sight. they made the decision to go into hospital for 3 days to have a intravenous methylprednisolone (a steroid drip). I also got put under rheumatology as I have now been put on methotrexate 12.5mg once a week I also have to take folic acid and I started taking ondanstron for my sickness from the methotrexate. I have recently been for a check up and I'm changing to methotrexate injections instead of orally and my uveitis has improved significantly. my uveitis has no clear underlining systemic association

0/post_text/0: My 14 year old daughter Alice was diagnosed with Uveitis in March with 3+ cells in both eyes & synachie in her left eye. Steroid drops didn't work & she was referred to Bristol Eye Hospital & put onto 20mg Methotrexate weekly by injection early August. She takes it late Friday night but is nauseous (she takes an antisickness tablet) & wiped out all w/e unable to do anything, no quality of life at all. Also no appetite until maybe Tuesday so losing weight. Her consultant has suggested switching to Mycophenolate tablets daily but I've read this is not so effective as Methotrexate & wont help with her joints (she has suspected arthritis too although still waiting for clear diagnosis of this). We can't decide what to do. Please help. Thanks.
1/post_text/1: When methotrexate either doesn't work or isn't tolerated for uveitis, mycophenolate is one of the next options and for some patients, it will do the job when mtx failed.
1/post_text/2: If there were no cells found when you were in Bristol and mtx is now controlling inflammation, then it becomes a question of, 'At what cost to Alice?' At the moment, she's effectively losing half of her week to side effects, which cannot be easy. It's bad enough having uveitis without being poleaxed by treatment! And if there was still significant inflammation, it's even easier - no point suffering if there's no benefit for the eyes.
1/post_text/3: With the RA suspected, rather than diagnosed, I don't think you have much to lose trying the mycophenolate. If Alice's joints do become unbearable, you can ring the hospital for advice. Could you and Alice perhaps look on it as a break from mtx side effects initially? It takes some time for mtx to leave the body, so if Alice's joints are being helped by it, they shouldn't immediately flare once she stops taking it.
1/post_text/4: I think life will become much easier once they know exactly what is behind the joint problem. Not getting a clear diagnosis must be so frustrating.

Alice has been so unwell over the past 8 weeks on methotrexate that her mental health is suffering with anxiety prior to the injection & then being very tearful low & despairing after it. Alice doesn't feel she can continue to tolerate being so ill, literally wiped out in bed every w/e as her life has come to a standstill. Her inflammation has improved from 3+ cells to 1+ cells but her pressures have risen to over 30 from the maxidex steroid drops so she is on pressure drops too now. I think all in all you're right & it's going to be best to try mycophenolate & hope this does a better job & that Alice tolerates it significantly better. Having the w/e's back & being able to enjoy life again will make such a difference & help Alice to cope with all that's happening. When Alice was diagnosed we had no idea how complex long drawn out & demoralising treating uveitis could be. & because it's a relatively invisible condition, how isolating it is either. Bristol Eye Hospital are happy to arrange a new prescription today for Alice to start tonight. Thank you for your support which is very much appreciated.
3/post_text/0: Don't think you need worry over much about getting it wrong, Rachel - one of the docs involved in my care said they wouldn't let me get it wrong!
4/post_text/0: Thank you so much Maxine. That's so reassuring. I think I need to learn to trust the doctors a little more. Not my strong point. Alice does have a lovely Consultant & Specialist Nurse in Bristol I'm just not used to having to rely on or work so closely with others in the care of my children. As a single mum with no family (brought up in care) I've had to be fiercely independent & yet with all of this I feel lost. It's a very difficult condition to deal with, for Alice especially but also for my son Luke 11 (who has nystagmus & is visually impaired) & for myself. Also to explain & as you say, for friends to understand & know what to say to offer any comfort. I now have the mycophenolate for Alice to start tonight so here's hoping for a much better w/e. Thank you again so much for your support. I really appreciate it. Best Wishes Rachel

Obviously we need to wait a while to find out how well this drug will work on her eyes but for now we're just enjoying her feeling well & regaining her quality of life. Thank you SO much for your support in helping us to come to this decision. :-)

1/post_text/0: Hi, my heart goes out to you, I know how you feel. Loads of questions, concerns and no answers.
1/post_text/1: One thing I have learn't is that the consultants don't always have all the answers and yes, it is a roller coaster ride, so hang on. The best advice that was given to me ( and I think you confusion over your daughter diagnosis is best answered by her doctors) is write a list of questions the next time you see them, ask them. For example:
1/post_text/2: Ask why she has been given that diagnosis? Can they explain her blood test results to you? Did she have a false positive result the first time round?
1/post_text/3: Your consultant's comment... About the chances of JIA developing, unlikely but possibly sounds familiar. I would bet he / she doesn't know so is covering all bases. My son was given an antiviral medication and I asked what was the percentage success rate or was there a possibility of it not working. The registrar said "he had never known it not to work". You'll never get a straight yes or no. But that was the straightest answer I've had.
1/post_text/4: Children can get uveitis before JIA (it is quoted at about 10-15 percent) I think but blood test results tend to point in that direction (again I think) like being ANA positive. May very well be wrong. Often though no cause is found. My son's uveitis (we think) was caused by a virus.
2/post_text/0: I know exactly what you mean! You want to be told X, y and z and the solution is c. We had a horrible period over Christmas when we just didn't know what was wrong. My son had had every test under the son and nothing showed up, then overnight he lost sight in one eye. Urgent admission to hospital, he had vasculitis in one eye which caused a blood clot. We were told the vision lost was permenant but his sight is back to 20/40 in the affected eye. Not bad given he couldn't see anything at all.
2/post_text/1: He had a lumber puncture which showed chicken pox in his spinal fluid for which he was treated. He is now clear of the chicken pox and vasculitis but still has uveitis. We are in limbo, on eye drops still (nearly a year now) - bilateral uveitis was the first symptom. But methotrexate scares me too, particularly with the risk to immune systems and shingles in the optic nerve. But cater acts and glaucoma - with long term eye drops. 2/post_text/2: I would dearly love it all to stop now. Sorry if my response was patronising - just know how you feel. There are just no guaranteed answers. As you know, it's not easy!

1/post_text/1: Sorry to hear Humira hasn't brought remission. Taking that with mtx AND hourly drops when your son flares must be making life miserable.
1/post_text/2: Sometimes people may be changed to infliximab, a drug similar to Humira in its action, but a little different in its composition. With infliximab, dose is calculated according to weight and the interval between infusions can also be varied. With the dose and schedule not being fixed like Humira is, infliximab can be tailored to the individual's disease and so work better.
1/post_text/3: If your son is being treated in Bristol or another uveitis specialist centre, there are other iv drugs being used. For example, Tocilizumab. The use of these other drugs may depend upon an underlying cause for the uveitis, such as JIA. An adult patient recently in touch whose uveitis is part of rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with Rituxan.
1/post_text/4: I'm sure the consultant wouldn't mind you emailing to ask what this other drug is so you can prepare for the discussion.

3/post_text/2: I'm a bit puzzled about Elliott staying on the Maxidex if the drops haven't improved the situation over the past five months and now he has cells in the back of his eyes. When inflammation isn't controlled at the back of the eyes, vision can be permanently lost. Posterior uveitis is often treated with immunosuppressants to stop this happening. Eye drops tend not to reach the back of the eyes.
3/post_text/3: Where children are concerned, I'm not sure about steroid injections around or into the eye. These can help with posterior inflammation and can last for about three months in their effect. Has the consultant spoken about them with you?
3/post_text/4: As for length of treatment, it's hard to predict. Some people get better quickly just on drops, but for others who need immunosuppressants, it can take quite a few years before they're off the drugs.

1/post_text/1: Welcome to the OV forums.
1/post_text/2: Sorry to read that your iritis has been joined by intermediate uveitis. This 'spread' does happen at times and so does fluid on the retina. Fluid on the retina is often doctor speak for the cystoid macular oedema that occurs when inflamation hasn't been controlled. You're also right that this fluid can cause permanent damage, but only if it goes untreated. The steroid injection that you're going to receive has a very good track record of clearing the oedema.
1/post_text/3: The periocular injection is to the area around the eye, rather than into the eye itself. I've no idea what those feel like, but having had steroid injected elsewhere, I suspect you might feel a short lived stingy pressure as it goes in. The docs are very good at putting you at as much ease as possible before they inject and quite a lot of us who have had injections into the eye itself say the anxiety beforehand was worse than the event. If you're really anxious, the nurse, most likely, will hold your hand.
1/post_text/4: Usually you can leave the hospital not long after the injection. You might have to wait a while so they can check your ocular pressure before you go though. You might be given an eye dressing to wear and you will have a follow up appointment to check all is well and to measure eye pressure.

0/post_text/0: I want to know what type of drugs are out there that work for anterior uveitis sufferers.... apart from pred forte, viscotears, hylo tears and myralate. if i spelt it right. what treatments have others had. that s worked.
1/post_text/0: Maxidex is an alternative to Pred forte, but possibly won't do that much if the Pred isn't helping. There is also another steroid drop which your hubby could ask about - Durezol.
1/post_text/1: When eyes drops are not doing the job and the uveitis is chronic, people are often put on oral steroid pills or receive injections of steroid around the eye. After that, it's either immunosuppressants or if you can get funding and it's appropriate for you, steroid can be implanted into the eye. The treatments section gives you information about the immunosuppressants. If you follow the links to the NHS information about these drugs, bear in mind that the side effects listed are more for the doses used for cancer and transplant patients. Uveitis patients do also experience some side effects but receive much lower doses of these meds.
1/post_text/2: Your hubby really needs to read about the other treatments and then discuss with his ophth whether they are appropriate for him. Generally if the uveitis clears up and flare ups don't occur that often, eye drops are the safest option. If the uveitis is active all of the time and your hubby is at the end of his tether with the pain etc, then moving on to immunosuppressants which stop the immune system attacking the eyes is an option.
1/post_text/3: A warm compress on the eye can relieve pain for a short time. Not exactly the answer when the pain is constant though.

0/post_text/0: Hi, I have been suffering from uveitis on and off for 6 years now. I know I am HLA B27 +ve so I suppose that's why I get it. I just feel that whenever i get a flare up (such as now) i go to eye clinic and just get a prescription for Predforte and Cycopentolate thrust at me, and never get any information or advice. I had to insist on the blood test, I have never had any other investigations and I feel after 6 years still totally lost about the whole thing.I never get to see a Consultant, it's always junior doctors in clinic, and they don't give an opinion or answer questions, it's so frustrating!
1/post_text/1: HLA B27 positive people are more likely than the general population to develop an auto immune condition, but not all do. When the inflammation is confined to the eyes, treatment varies according to the part of the eye affected, the severity of inflammation, how often the attacks occur and whether one or both eyes are affected. When the inflammation is present elsewhere in the body as well as the eyes, it's sometimes necessary to treat the immune system as a whole.
1/post_text/2: The side effects of steroid drops affect the eyes - cataracts will form and some people find the steroid raises their eye pressure. When the immune system as a whole is treated with oral, injectible drugs or iv drugs, the potential side effects may cause damage to the rest of the body, as well as lowering the body's defences. Doctors balance potential benefit with risk before starting patients on immunosuppressant treatment.
1/post_text/3: If your attacks are becoming more frequent, you could initiate a discussion about whether immunosuppression treatment would be of more benefit than risk for you. You'll find details about the commonly used treatments in the treatments section.
1/post_text/4: You can always ask to see the consultant in the clinic. It helps to say you're  prepared to wait!
2/post_text/0: Thanks Maxine, Just feeling a bit fed up this time that's all. I usually just get on with it and remind myself I could have something far worse! I'm going back to clinic in 6 weeks and will phone ahead today to request that appointment is with a Consultant.

1/post_text/1: Don't know much about the various antibiotic eye drops, but perhaps they're the same as oral antibiotics in that some are better for particular infections?
1/post_text/2: With the infection returning, it's probably best to find out why this is happening. There have been instances of preservative free steroid drops being contaminated although I'm not aware of a problem with these at the moment. Sometimes eye make up, like mascara and liner, pose a risk of infection and eye lids doused in steroid several times a day don't help with that. With you being on oral steroid as well, it's probably much safer to endure the eye clinic or at least give them a ring, rather than self treat.

0/post_text/0: Hi
1/post_text/1: You and that poor eye have taken quite a battering.
1/post_text/2: In your position, I'd ask what is causing the CME. It can be caused by things other than uveitis so once you know, you'll know where you stand about treating it.
1/post_text/3: Ozurdex is used for uveitis and also for other retinal conditions. In some cases one injection might be enough but repeated injections are not uncommon. I don't know how many it's safe to have.
1/post_text/4: When people with uveitis have cataract surgery, they may receive either a short course of high dose oral steroid or a pulse of iv steroid just before the op. This is done to give the best chance of eliminating the possibility of post op flare. Since you already have the steroid in your eye from the Ozdurex implant, it will be protecting your eye from inflammation and hopefully CME caused by inflammation. Whether it is preventative for other types of CME is something to ask your surgeon.

To cut a long story short the upshot of the diagnosis to date has been: Oral steroids, Fluorescein Angiogram, Kenalog injections x 2, Laser, Vitrectomy and ERM peel, numerous eye drops and Ozurdex implants x 2 (which I can't have without a GA after a bad experience with the Kenalog injection - maybe I'm just a wimp!) and I am now waiting for a cataract operation (Dec). 0/post_text/0: Hello, I am hoping you can please offer me some advice. My daughter who is 3 was diagnosed with JIA on 1st August and within minutes of the rheumatologist diagnosing her she saw the ophthalmologist who said she had active anterior uveitis in both eyes. My husband and I were shocked. She was immediately put onto Pred Forte 1% eye drops 3 times a day and preparations were made for her to begin methotrexate treatment. She had a check up yesterday and we were told her uvetitis is under control and she was to reduce her eye drops to twice a day and they would reassess in 4 weeks. Whilst I am delighted at the outcome of this appointment I still feel there is a cloud hanging over us and now don't understand some things. Is it possible the uveitis can go away completely or will it only go into remission for some time? We have been told the eye drops are only for short/mid term use due to the potential problems they can cause so if the inflammation increases then methotrexate will begin. Is it possible that because she has no active joint inflammation with her JIA that the uveitis has also gone? Does it ever disappear for good or will she have this so long as she has JIA? Thank you in advance for any help you can offer. I just feel like there is so much to take on board. The ophthalmologist said her Uveitis is only under control because of the eye drops which I thought was a great thing but he was still serious in his manner and I didn't get a chance to ask my questions. She also tested ANA positive which I know increases the risk of uveitis but does it affect the long term outcome? Thanks again.

1/post_text/1: Yes there is a growing recognition of the role of food allergies/ intolerance and autoimmune disease. I'd recommend you try the GAPS diet - it basically removes common trigger foods and gives your body a chance to recover. I've completely got my uveitis under control (symptom and medication free) by doing this.
1/post_text/2: https://draxe.com/gaps-diet-plan-protocol/
1/post_text/3: It might be worth getting a reputable IGg food intolerance test - Cambridge Nutritional Sciences do one of the better ones. I'm afraid I doubt it's only milk that will be a problem food. This will help identify problem foods for you. Be careful I'm afraid Doctors are pretty out of touch with the role of food Intolerance in autoimmune disease and insist on "true -IGe antibody test) . This would have missed the foods that were triggering uveitis in my case.

1/post_text/1: I'm so pleased you managed to get some answers today and you sound much calmer despite your long day!
1/post_text/2: The Humira should work wonderfully on any inflammation in Jack's joints as well as his eyes.  It is quite a painful shot - not the needle but the actual liquid itself stings.  Many people report that taking it out of the fridge for half an hour before injecting helps massively, as does applying an ice pack for a few minutes after the shot.
1/post_text/3: The good news is that it's only once every fortnight, although I'm assuming jack will stay on methotrexate as well for a while, and it's quite common to stay on a lowered dose of mtx throughout the period of time on Humira.

3/post_text/2: The TB test tends to be a skin test: an injection that goes just under the skin, it's not painless, and Olivia wasn't too happy but she said it was like being scratched and by that night she'd stopped mentioning it.  It takes 48-72 hours to see if there's been a positive reaction - the skin goes clearly very red all around the site of the injection.  If the test is negative, the result you want, then the skin stays as normal.

0/post_text/0: Unfortunately my original thread seems to have disappeared but I felt an update was due (there's some history here -
1/post_text/1: Regarding long term side effects of steroids. Riley's original consultant was very much of the opinion that long term side effects were unlikely and they could be managed. I have to say I find him equally frustrating and reassuring. I just 'love' his reassuring manner as an 'anxious' parent; - I love my worries being soothed.
1/post_text/2: We went back to his him recently and it was a good appointment. One cell in each eye, not quite zero but nearly. He  also said that Riley's cataract (was very minor) and might never cause a problem. All fantastic. We agreed to stay in the loop with him. I don't want to burn bridges completely but we formally moved Riley's care. I will always be eternally grateful for him for not messing around and getting Riley admitted ASAP to hospital. However, there is a BUT to this....
1/post_text/3: Given Riley's (fingers crossed) tolerance to MTX. Seemingly no / minor side effects and so far, blood test results holding steady. I wish we had started MTX last April. I really like the reassurance don't get me wrong but I now have a double knot at the bottom of my stomach. I know Riley's original Consultant is right and not right all at the same time. I had been lead to believe (rightly or wrongly) that we would have ages before we had to start playing the steroid vs cataract route and yes, his cataract might have been caused by uveitis but still......... Also, the cataract diagnosis was just one more hit I could have done with out. It is funny but it is the one thing that has caused me the most problems because I knew he could get cataracts from steroids. I had read the information and yet I didn't act fast enough to stop it from happening. At this moment in time, I would choose MTX over cataract or glaucoma surgery every time.
1/post_text/4: Pete your son's case is (I think on the face of it - if you don't mind me saying) less complicated; Riley's uveitis could have been caused by VZV - so I still find the compromised immune system thing a wee bit terrifying. But you take your chances and play the odds but so far (fingers crossed) - MTX has been fine.
2/post_text/0: Hi Becca, thankfully (at present) I think my sons case is less complex and milder (particularly as its only in one eye at present - touch wood). Also, being intermediate, he suffers none of the discomfort that anterior Uveitis sufferers experience. These factors do make the argument for MTX perhaps a little weaker.
2/post_text/1: Despite the above, instinctively, a life time of Ozurdex steroid implants feels rather hazardous (not to mention expensive!) to me. If the Uveitis does come back then I will definitely seek another consultation with Prof Ayliffe and / or Prof Dicks to get a more informed decision regarding Ozurdez or MTX.
2/post_text/2: Best wishes for Riley and yourself.

11/post_text/1: I can't believe its been 5 months since my last post. In the end we went with the second Ozurdex injection. This was partly due to my son having some emotional / anxiety issues and we didn't feel it was right to go down the immunosuppressant route at that time. I had a brief email exchange with Prof Ayliffe who thought this was a reasonable course of action and my sons' consultant ophthalmologist recommended this course of action bearing in mind the Uveitis had responded well to this treatment and was only in one eye.
11/post_text/2: My son's mental state further deteriorated further and soon after leaving college he developed very severe OCD. As a result he became virtually housebound and was spending hours checking doors and sterilizing everything he touched. Following some sessions with a psychiatrist and psychologist and lots of anti depressants he's overcome this and is pretty much back to normal now. Thankfully our health insurance met the bill otherwise I suspect he's still be suffering / waiting for the NHS.
12/post_text/1: Thanks for the update and congratulations to your son on doing so well at college despite uveitis.
12/post_text/2: It was distressing reading about his mental health and thank goodness you were able to access help rapidly and he's more or less back to his old self. Uveitis sufferers should be supported sufficiently that they don't get into this state, but it happens to far too many of us, especially those who suffer sight loss. A few NHS Centres do provide psychological support and we hope this will be extended to more. Can't happen soon enough.

12/post_text/3: OV attended a NICE scoping workshop in the summer which looked at the use of Ozurdex and sirolimus in the eye. Both are now being considered by NICE as additions to uveitis treatments and, if successfully approved, should remove funding issues. Sirolimus has been shown useful in mild intermediate uveitis and spares the patient the potential side effects of immune suppressants. However, have no idea whether your son's uveitis would be considered suitable for such a treatment if it becomes routinely available.

2/post_text/1: Yes I can completely relate to your experience as I went for a regular check up at the hospital a couple of days ago and was told I now have macular oedema in one eye which they said was perfectly treatable, but it's still scary isn't it ? I found there is very little in the way of 'Emotional support' services available especially during the early days of having uveitis (so just at the point where I feel folks need support the most so websites such as this are great ). I put pressure on myself by constantly putting on a brave face and saying I felt fine when I actually felt really scared and frightened. There came a point where I realised tat I needed to do something and I contacted the RNIB who have been absolutely fantastic and  although I felt I wasn't the sort of person who needed any 'counselling' , I have found it so helpful just talking to someone on the phone  for a short while every couple of weeks and they also helped me with finding out more about uveitis - as I felt that I hardly knew anything about the disease. I have been off work for quite a while - a good few months - but hope to make a gradual return to work in a month or twos time. I guess what I've learnt on this long road is that taking things a Day at a time is the key but it is so frustrating sometimes - but we will get there ! Good luck with your hospital treatment and I  hope it all goes really well, take care,Fiona

5/post_text/0: Thanks Fiona, didn't feel particularly brave yesterday - but today I can see that it was a starting point. Coming on here and finding people in similar situations who can relate to the issues we face is reassuring.
6/post_text/0: Thanks Maxine your post us really helpful; it's just great to know there are folks out there who understand the uveitis issues and the impact of the disease on day to day life,  especially when I guess many if us went from having normal vision to significant vision loss within a relatively short period of time. quite understandably other people do find it hard to understand what having uvetis means in terms if some days being harder than others such as when the cloudy vision gets really bad and it's like looking through a very heavily frosted window. It ranges from folks thinking I just have a bit of mild blurry vision (if only !) to close friends knowing that it is a really challenging condition.  Like Donna, my consultant is also fantastic so that helps a lot and he is very honest in terms of explaining which symptoms are more serious than others ( ie which symptoms we need to worry about and what We don't need to worry about). However saying that, I didn't even know what terms such as 'flare' meant until last week when I read the glossary on this website so that has also been really helpful. The one thing I have stopped doing is reading Up too much n the web about it as I've realised that's everyone's case is very different and you can be easily made to be down hearted by reading a web page about poor prognoses for final visual outcomes etc Take care and thanks again Fiona
7/post_text/0: Thank you Maxine, I completely agree with what Fiona has said, especially the relatively short time it takes to deterorate.
0/post_text/1: My name is Fiona and I happened to come across this brilliant site by chance last night. I have been being treated for uveitis with retinal detachments for the past eight months and after reading Anons story on your weboages my story has many similarities. After lots of surgery my sight is now returning after what has been a very scary period and there is still a long way to go but the immuno and steroid treatment is working well and I've now been on that for 5 months. It's great to find a forum like this just to read about other peoples experiences as the most difficult part of all if this has been the emotional roller ouster and not feeling like 'me' sometimes. Just wanted to say that I've been having some informal counselling from the RNIB which really helped as at one point I was in the legally blind category earlier in the year. The thing I have realised with uveitis is that the additional symptoms and complications such as cloudy /dim vision can cause as many problems as the pure loss of acuity but I've found this site invaluable around providing more info on this. I am making good progress and can start to do things like reading and venturing out and about on my own into town again which is great after nearly a whole year of significant sight loss . Anyway just saying hello and hope you are all well !
3/post_text/1: I totally agree with the emotional support thing, think it is especially frustrating when people haven't even heard of uveitis. I have been similar with the brave face - joking about the severity actually not appreciating or embracing the fact that I am frightened and I don't like the fact I have little control over what is going to happen and that despite lots of tests I have not presented with any other possible underlying causes.
3/post_text/2: Think my main problem of avoidance has been when I have flashes of panic, like when I couldn,t see my toenails to paint them, or when I can't tell the difference between navy and black - but then I develop a strategy of making it fit without allowing others to help.
3/post_text/3: I have made the first step today by going to the doctors and being honest, he has recommended some time off work - I work in mental health, so obvious I am not able to concentrate on others needs without addressing my own. I have also made a self referral to a councilling service through work and had a telephone session this morning.
5/post_text/1: I completly understand the feeling fit and well thing - that makes it slightly more frustrating sometimes, especially the look on the consultants face when he asks about various symptoms I may have and me replying no to everyone! To be fair I have a cracking consultant - have a wealth of faith in him, never hurries either.
7/post_text/1: This site has absolutly, without doubt, been a constant point of consistent and reasurring information from the people like yourselves and the fabulous people who set up OV.
3/post_text/4: And also reading your message on here - I do feel more positive now than I did this morning, but know that I still have a long way to go ... but like you say one day at a time.
5/post_text/2: Will keep popping back on here periodically and hope you continue to improve.
7/post_text/2: I have hit a low point but do, by no means feel helpless, I just need to recognise this is a complicated and longer process than I anticipated back in February when I presented at eye casualty and expected them to say 'take some paracetamol and you will be fine'!! Naive, perhaps, but with no knowledge of such conditions, how could I have known.
7/post_text/3: I have done the trawl - for hours - on the internet, trying to make sense of this, but always end up back here - with real peoples stories, and similar things to relate to.
7/post_text/4: Many thanks to both of you, take care and I feel very grateful that this site is available to all that need it. Donna

0/post_text/0: For the past two years, our specialists have been trying to get policies in place within the NHS which ensure that those of us with sight threatening disease which does not respond to steroid and conventional immunosuppressants receive a biologic therapy which is likely to preserve our sight.
0/topic_title: Last chance to help stop children and adults going blind when steroid and immunosuppressants don't work.
0/post_text/1: A year ago, draft policies for the commissioning of Adalimumab and infliximab were presented to NHS England. We hoped the policies would be approved and consultants would no longer need to put in Individual Funding Requests to Clinical Commissioning Groups for Adalimumab or infliximab to be funded for their patients who need these therapies. At present, Clinical Commissioning Groups are able to reject such requests because of the lack of clinical evidence and the lack of clear guidelines.
0/post_text/2: NHS England has now considered the draft policies and placed them into a thirty day public consultation period before making a final decision about whether to adopt them. WE HAVE TO TAKE PART IN THIS CONSULTATION BY APRIL 23RD. IF WE DON'T, NOT ALL OF US WILL GET THE DRUGS WE NEED TO SAVE OUR SIGHT.
0/post_text/3: HOW TO TAKE PART
0/post_text/4: Click here:
0/post_text/6: This will take you to a first page where all you need fill in is your name and email address.
0/post_text/7: On page 2, select the second option – Clinical Commissioning Policy
0/post_text/8: On page 3, tick both adult and paediatric uveitis
0/post_text/9: On page 4, tick support.
0/post_text/10: The final box on this page allows those of us who receive anti-TNF to describe the difference it has made to our sight and lives. Some of us may wish to comment that had we received it sooner in the course of our disease, we may have retained employment, our sight and eyes may not have been so damaged, we may have missed out on the side effects of steroid and immunosuppressants and so on. Others, who have had their IFR request rejected, should describe their ongoing struggle to stay sighted. A few who have successfully challenged an IFR rejection may wish to comment that doing so was unwelcomed additional stress when vision was impaired and levels of anxiety about sight and the future were already at an intolerable level.
0/post_text/11: Our families, friends and work colleagues can also support us by filling in this page and using the final box to say how uveitis has affected us or our children. Put the link on your social media page and get their support!
0/post_text/12: If you want to read the draft policies, this link takes you there. You find the policies in the trauma section.

0/post_text/0: I was diagnosed with Anterior Uveitis which I had never heard of till then on 2 May 2017 after 5 weeks of treatment with Pred Forte drops on a reducing basis, Maxitol ointment at night and Mydrilate drops 2 times per day I was told to stop medication when drops had been reduced to 2 times per day for 7 days which I did. My review appointment was not till the following week. 4 days later my eye had flared up again and I had to phone clinic for appointment. Unknown to myself my pupil had been stuck to the lens in 2 places at my original appointment. I was put back on hourly drops for 5 days reducing to 6 x per day and 4 x per day however my eye got worse and pupil stuck again. After various toibg and firing to eye clinic and various attempts to unstick the lens i was sent home with the pupil still 3/4 stuck and mydrilate and more Pred Forte drops. Needless to say at my next review a week later my eue had got worse and pupil almost fully stuck. I was then given an injection to release pupil which eorked and back on Pred Forte hourly with Atropine drops 2 x per day. At next review a week later Atropibe was stopped and Pred zforte reduced to 6x per day for 1 week and 4x per day for 1 week. Had to go back to casualty eye clinic a week later as eye getting redder and pupil not dilating. I have since attended eye clinic 2 more times with Pred Forte drops being reduced and have been on Atropine 2 x per day for 2 weeks with no sign of pupil dating any further. Doctor didn't seem to think there was anything stronger they could give me to help. I am getting really upset as don't seem to be getting any further forward although inflammation seems to have subsided a little. The doctor seems to think that this is linked to my Seronegative inflammatory arthritis which I have had for a number of years and have taken Sulphasalasine for the last 4 years. I haven't been tested for anything else. My main question is how long can my pupil remain stuck to lens without me suffering loss of my vision.
1/post_text/1: Reads like you are having a really frustrating time with this. The pupil getting stuck happens to quite a few people and the degree to which it affects vision, depends on the position it sticks in. With the pupil controlling the amount of light which enters the eye, your vision may be affected in different light conditions so, for example, people whose pupils stick fully in a dilated position may need sunglasses in very bright light. One of mine was partially stuck and it needed a dilating drop (a weaker one than yours) every day until it was unstuck as part of cataract surgery a couple of years later. It didn't significantly affect my sight, possibly because the pupil was never fully dilated nor fully constricted.
1/post_text/2: Have you had an appointment with your rheumatologist since uveitis started to discuss it? Don't know much about your type of arthritis, but your rheumatologist will have ideas to share with ophthalmology about treatment.
1/post_text/3: Maxine
2/post_text/0: Synechiae won't cause loss of vision. You
2/post_text/1: May need glasses though. Most people don't know they have synechiae. Bad synechiae can be fixed when cataracts are removed. Synechiae can cause eye pressure pro lemon if it envelopes eye. Doc is treating you so should be able to release synechiae when they form.
2/post_text/2: Atropine discourages synechiae formation.
3/post_text/0: Thank you both for your replies. Have felt very alone with this till now as nobody else I have spoken to have even heard of this. The eye clinic at the hospital I attend are not very forthcoming with information and details of my condition. I have had to find info from the internet and ask them what things mean. I think at last appointment my pupil is approximately 2/3 stuck to the lens but was told no point in continuing Atropine as didn't appear to be working and that is the strongest they can give me. Feel as though they have just given up and will only now do something if eye pressure rises too high and that will be a lasered  hole in the iris. As far as Rheumatologist is concerned I have actually asked my GP 3 weeks ago to contact him to ask if he can review my medication etc as 2 of my joints are still swollen since the onset of the recurrence of the Uveitis. As far as uveitis specialists are concerned I have tried to research if there are any in the area where I live - Ayrshire in SW Scotland but there doesn't seem to be any. Think the closest I can find is Aberdeen. I feel the more I learn the condition then I will be aware of what my eye should look and feel like to know when something isn't right as I don't seem to get much support at the eye clinic without knowing what questions to ask. I have mentioned to the doctor that i can see a fluid in my eye almost like looking through an oily liquid with a few little black strands in it but there was no comment on whether this is normal for my condition or not so none the wiser. Although there is info on the net sometimes it is hard to know what is relevant. There is no support groups locally to me as far as I can find so relieved when I found this site. I was feeling really alone with this till now. So thank you.
4/post_text/0: Black strands might be floaters.
4/post_text/1: Dr foster keeps a list of specialists.
4/post_text/2: A specialist will know if you should take drugs to put the iritis into remission.
4/post_text/3: If you don't require much steroid to control iritis you would stick with steroids. Most
5/post_text/0: Hi again, Heather,
2/post_text/3: You may have sticky or granulomatous cells.
2/post_text/4: Learn to catch Inflammation early by Monitoring your eye redness. You need to see uveitis specialist if this continues.
5/post_text/1: If you can get to Aberdeen, do ask for referral there. Others who attend that clinic say the consultant is really good and with your uveitis likely to be linked with your arthritis, a uveitis specialist working with your local rheumatologist will help ensure you get on the best treatment, at the right dose, to control both conditions.
5/post_text/2: It takes time to understand uveitis and I think most of us struggle with it to begin with but it does get easier when you're with a specialist.
4/post_text/4: People with synechiae didnt go to doc for long time. Once synechiae is attached, Atropine won't help. The iris sticking and releasing does leave scars and pigment. Normally, People learn to detect inflammation and have steroid in fridge.

0/post_text/0: While doing some research, I came across an article that states that pre-term infants often have life-long effects of their pre-term birth that includes dis-regulation of the body's immune response. I was curious if anyone on here was a pre-term infant? Braiden was born at 29 weeks.
1/post_text/1: O was late!  Ended up being induced, I think she would have happily stayed there forever!!
1/post_text/2: Nicki x
2/post_text/0: Be very cautious about the background of research articles, particularly those that have not been peer reviewed by experts in the field.
2/post_text/1: Many "scare articles" get published as part of small pieces of research without having proper grounding in statistical terms. Many researchers do this to gain attention or are sadly bribed (see MMR fiasco). Whilst a researcher may publish findings in isolated samples this does not necessarily reflect the situation in large population groups.
2/post_text/2: Rob
3/post_text/0: Oh, I see. Thanks Rob. It was only one article published by the Lahey Clinic. Every other article stated other findings and corroborated each other. The Lahey Clinic stood alone in the autoimmume connection. I am familiar with the MMR fiasco, and that it was! We also belong to the Autism community and I get grief from anti-vaccine activists all the time because I support getting kids vaccinated. It is very disheartening the long-lasting effect that piece of junk research still has on parents.

0/post_text/0: Hi,
1/post_text/1: I had a condition where the vitreous pulled on the retina and there was an epi retinal membrane. My sight was affected.
1/post_text/2: Treatment was vitrectomy and the epiretinal membrane (scar tissue)was peeled during this surgery. A cataract was removed and an IOL put in at the same time. The eye needed a thing called a scleral buckle because in my case, the traction had affected the retina. From what I understand, in some cases, the traction can resolve by itself.
1/post_text/3: The surgery itself was done under general anaesthetic and post op, one dose of painkillers was enough for discomfort. The next morning, there was no discomfort.
1/post_text/4: When the patch came off, the eye had sight again after about 18 months of seeing precious little.
2/post_text/0: Maxine,
2/post_text/1: Thank you for the reply.  I do have an OCT scan most times I visit the consultant which has been around every 4-6 weeks for the last 2 1/2 years as the inflammation is refusing to lie down and play dead.  It was my last visit when she pointed out the VMT to me and showed me the last couple of scans so that I could see how it has changed.  She also said that she would keep a close check on the situation so I do have confidence that she is trying to do her best for me.
2/post_text/2: As you rightly say, it's hard not to worry about uveitis especially when it feels like you just get used to one bit of bad news and another one comes along and gets added to it.  I sometimes feel like the consultants don't tell you everything at once because they know it will be too overwhelming and maybe they're right.
0/post_text/1: Does anyone have experience of VMT resulting from uveitis?  My last couple of OCT scans have showed that MVT is starting to develop in my left eye. My consultant explained it to me in layman's terms and has told me to try not to worry about it because it may remain as it is for a long time and not give me any trouble for a while.  Of course it's hard not to worry about something which will affect your vision.
0/post_text/2: I understand there is an operation to help relieve the traction but I've no idea how successful the operations are or what complications there may be. All the information I could find on the web only talked about MVT in terms of degeneration in older people.  I'm presuming that as with my cataracts, the operation would be risky while I'm still suffering with inflamation?
1/post_text/5: It was necessary to have the eye inflammation free at the time of surgery and I did have a problem with post op inflammation which required a second change in immunosuppression.
1/post_text/6: You can read about vitrectomy in the treatments section.
1/post_text/7: I think if you are having regular OCTs, the consultant treating you is keeping a careful eye on the traction and however hard it is to deal with a new complication to the uveitis, you somehow have to trust his judgement on the need to treat the traction and if and when to do this. Not easy - everything about uveitis worries me.
1/post_text/8: Your reading on the web may have led you to discovery of a new method of treating the traction with an injected drug - microplasmin. I think the use of this is still under review in the UK.
2/post_text/3: Fingers crossed for my next visit that there's no more deterioration and an end to the inflammation would be a nice bonus.
0/post_text/3: Currently I'm on MMF and am reducing prednisolone minims.  My inflamation level is 1+.
0/post_text/4: Kind Regards,
1/post_text/9: I know it's difficult, but do try not to worry. I don't think your consultant would monitor rather than rush into treatment without very good reason.

0/post_text/2: Has anyone got this before and what type of support you requested? I was like an idiot in these conversations and didn't know what to say. Uveitis was a big problem for me when it flares up because I would have to run to hospital asap to reduce my IOP, but if things go well - often within 1 or 2 day - I can go back to work again.
0/post_text/3: Personally I'm feeling very disheartened by all of this. After years of struggling, I now came to accept that this disease would not go away, and every time my IOP reached 50 - which is quite often recently - I'm scared to death that it wouldn't go down. Admittedly my job is quite stressful and I sometimes considered quitting so that I could prevent my immune system from crashing as a result of stress. But on the other hand I need to support myself financially too. It also affected me professionally in the sense that I can't pursue job opportunities within the firm that I'm really interested in, because I know by nature those jobs will require lots of travelling and night hours. The only positive thing is that my eyes are still in perfect conditions despite all the flare-ups, though again I'm still very young and have many years ahead to live wigh this.

0/post_text/1: I have burned out intermediate uveitis. I've had an epiretinal membrane peel, and in the past macular oedema treated with oral steroids, sub-tenon injections and drops.  I now have very small cataracts. Recently, my option has found that I need reading glasses, ie have premature presbyopia - very early at age 33. Has anybody else had this happen?  Nobody seems to be able to tell me if it is caused by the tiny cataracts (which are right in the middle of my lenses) or by the uveitis, or if it is 'just one of those things'.  One thing is for sure, varifocal glasses for the rest of my life is going to be really expensive.

1/post_text/1: It reads like they are doing the best they can to get pressure under control. The reduction in drops should help a bit and adding a second pressure drop will also help.
1/post_text/2: Xalatan is very effective at lowering pressure. It does have side effects and it's important to place a finger over the tear duct to stop the drug entering the rest of his body.
1/post_text/3: When Jack's on the humira, they'll be able to reduce the steroid drops in both eyes even more and hopefully get him off them. Once he's off the drops, his eye pressure should go down and in time, he'll be off the pressure drops.
1/post_text/4: Do you know how much longer you are going to be waiting for that rheumatology appointment? Would it help to do a bit more chasing up? The sooner Jack is on humira, the quicker he's off the steroid and this pressure problem gets solved.

4/post_text/0: Hi Caron,
4/post_text/1: Methotrexate can cause mouth ulcers - Olivia suffered terribly the first 6 months but then they seemed to stop forming.
4/post_text/2: Methotrexate can also cause behavioural problems - by that I mean it can cause them to be more angry or teary than usual and on the whole a bit more emotional than is usual.  However it's very difficult as a mother to know what's them being stroppy, and what's not, and in Olivia's case how much of it is hormonal!
4/post_text/3: Would it help Jack to speak to other children or do you think he might need help in the form of counselling?  Speaking to someone else about his feelings might really help him and you.  Uveitis doesn't just effect the eyes or just the sufferer.  It's emotionally tough on the patient who's personally going through it, particularly when they're so young and don't really understand what's happening, but it can be equally hard on the carer who'd give her arms and legs to take it away from her child.

7/post_text/0: Hi Caron,
8/post_text/0: Hi Caron,
9/post_text/0: Hi Caron,
1/post_text/5: This bit is one of the hardest - waiting for the wheels to turn and the promised change in treatment actually happen.
5/post_text/1: In some people, xalatan can cause problems with mood and various aches and pains. Used long term, it does alter the colour of the iris in those with light eyes, but has no effect on brown eyes. Also, long term, eyelashes increase in length. That bit of it, by the way, is now being used as a cosmetic for women.
7/post_text/1: See what you mean about Jack's questions. I'm at a bit of a loss here too. Perhaps some of the other mothers will have good ideas. All I can think of is telling Jack that you'll ask the questions at the next appointment. A doctor telling you both something carefully optimistic (agreed between you and the doc beforehand) means you can build on that optimism at home and Jack's trust in you is not threatened. Perhaps even just asking the doctors what they think you should say to Jack would be even better since they must have plenty of experience about what works best for children in Jack's position.
8/post_text/1: Olivia's asked these questions and I've always said what I believe which is:
8/post_text/2: I will not let you go blind.  I will do everything possible together with Prof A to ensure that doesn't happen.  We might have to go through many different treatments but we will beat this disease, and you will retain your sight.
8/post_text/3: I'm happy to tell Olivia this because I truly believe it to be so from the bottom of my heart.
5/post_text/2: It's sometimes difficult to tell what is depression from uveitis itself and the effect it has on sight and what is depression as a sde effect of the drugs. I can usually tell instantly if a new drug or eye drop is affecting my mood because I become extremely stroppy and tearful within a couple of days. I am, however, in that minority who react to anything with the potential to alter mood.
5/post_text/3: If it helps, post Jack's questions on here. There's enough of us now for our combined experience of uveitis to find answers and plenty of parents who have tips to pass on like Nicki has.
7/post_text/2: I think you have to discuss Jack's emotional state at your next appointment or go to the GP about it. I'm afraid I recognise those moods - I experienced them as side effects of treatment and they were very different to the unhappiness about losing sight. As an adult, I knew what was happening to me, but I doubt a child can know. If you can pin point exactly when Jack became this unhappy, it will help to work out the cause - unhappiness about being sick or side effects.
7/post_text/3: With OV growing and more patients and carers becoming aware of us, it's likely that local support groups will develop. If we all keep posting, others will join us. It's early days but I bet within a year or less, you'll have made contact with other local mothers through this forum and Jack will have another young boy to talk to.
9/post_text/1: Is Jack still on methotrexate? Mouth ulcers can be a side effect from this, I too struggled badly at one point. The folic acid is really important to combat mouth ulcers and other side effects so perhaps you could ask about taking more of that - not on the same day as methotrexate though.
9/post_text/2: I'm currently on a humira/mtx combo and for me it's been phenomenal - I noticed a clear improvement in vision within 24 hours of the first dose, a lot quicker than I'd expected! I hope Jack is able to start it soon and that he has similarly good results on it!
9/post_text/3: Take care,
4/post_text/4: From time to time (particularly following an appointment) I sit Olivia down and ask her if she wants to talk about what's going on, if she has any questions or worries.  I always say I'll answer her as honestly as I can and that if I don't know the answer I will try and find out.  By doing this I find it gives her the opportunity to have a bit of me time and tends to lead to a good cry after which she feels a lot better.  It also gives her a bit of control back as she gets to do the questioning.
4/post_text/5: I know Jack's a few years younger but a similar approach might help.  If you think it will help, you can be referred to a child psychologist through your GP, just make sure it's one who has experience dealing with children with illness.
5/post_text/4: I wish it were easier for Jack and I hope the appointment letter arrives tomorrow.
5/post_text/5: Maxine

Hi, we have just been offered to take part in the humira trial I'd like to know what experience people have had so far good or bad? Hard part is going to be trying to convince my daughter to have another injection. She hates having her methotrexate and when i mention the humira she just doesn't want to talk about it and gets upset.
1/post_text/1: As you know from our previous conversations, my daughter Freya is on the sycamore study. 3 months in and the results are brilliant. Eyes are quiet for the first time since she was four (now 6) and her joints are better than ever been since she was two and first diagnosed with JIA.
1/post_text/2: She clearly dislikes the injections, but has had support from the clinical psychologists at the hospital who have helped her with coping strategies and gives freya more choices about how we do the injections at home. She still gets upset at the point of doing it but helps me get stuff ready in advance and is co-operative and afterwards just gets on with it and is happy it's behind her for two weeks. Admittedly, we take Oral MTX here to she only has to cope with the one injection - it must be hard to convince your daughter to do another one so I can imagine and understand her reluctance.
1/post_text/3: Remind me, how old is your daughter? I think it's important that you try to get her to talk about how she feels about her treatment and if possible get some support from the team about this, as it really helped us.
1/post_text/4: Freya hasn't really had any side effects - one recent skin reaction but till then, no probs. I think also, the fact that she now knows it is working gives her the confidence to continue with it and put up with the injections. Of course, this only comes with having Humira and not placebo which you know isn't guaranteed. Even we don't know for sure at this stage, though given the improvements we are cautiously optomistic.

8/post_text/0: Humira nurse supervised me at home the first 2 times but I did the actual shot from the word go.  O has it in her stomach but I know other kids have it in their thighs. O had no choice as she has zero body fat.

2/post_text/3: If I can help in any way, leet me know.
3/post_text/1: As you know O has been on Humira for 5 months now.  It took 3 months for it to work (40mg by epi-pen) but after 3 years of failed treatment after failed treatment both eyes are now cell and flare free.
3/post_text/2: The shot itself is painful - about 5 seconds of screaming, but after that no side effects, no reaction nothing.
3/post_text/3: We take it out of the fridge an hour before, and she has an anti-histimine pill half hour before shot simply because I was told by the nurse that this lessens the chance of any allergic reaction and helps prevent a lump forming at injection site. O also puts an ice pack on the skin for a few minutes beforehand and sometimes straight after the shot as well depending on how she feels.
8/post_text/1: O will speak to T no problem, she's already spoken to several other kids who've gone on to have the Humira and she's in close contact with one of them ie they text each other permanently!
8/post_text/2: With the trial it's made very clear that if you are willing to travel to the hospital every 2 weeks for the shot that it's not a problem - entirely your and T's choice as to who does it. x
3/post_text/4: She still has mtx weekly but in all honesty she's never been very bothered about the actual injection, it was the sickness that affected her. As Sam said, it really helps knowing that the Humira is actually working!
3/post_text/5: Let me know if there's anything else you want to know and remember you can read more by clicking "Humira Trial" at the top of the page.

1/topic_title: On going intermediate uveitus - progress update
0/post_text/1: i thought I'd just post an update on how things are going.
0/post_text/2: I've been waiting to see a rheumatologist so that he can recommend a course of treatment. Well I've seen the rheumatologist and was told that my condition is not linked to rheumatology so they would write back to the opthamologist with recommended treatment. The letter that was sent only recommended what the opthamologist had suggested in the beginning i.e MTX or Ciclosporin first then the infliximab or another biological agent.  So I'm sitting here wondering why I had to wait 3 months to see the rheumatologist - don't these Dr's know that we live in the age of the email.
0/post_text/3: on returning to the opthamologist I was hoping he would now start some new treatment so that I can reduce the steroids - at the moment I'm down to 15mg but can't get any lower without a flare up. However my bloods are not normal I have a low white cell, bone marrow count which isn't recovering since I went on the Tac. Now I'm of tac since last Sept it should have recovered the opthamologist has now referred me to haematology.  He won't start MTX because the count is low but it hasn't improved in 3 months.  He has told me that it is 0.4 and the normal reading is 1.5 - 2.6.  I've tried to find out about this on internet but it seems there are several different counts for white blood cells and I'm not sure if the result he's give me is an overall count or relating to a specific area.
0/post_text/4: Does anyone know anything about the WBC that they can clarify for me? I feel more in control when I know what's happening.
0/post_text/5: At the mo I'm pressing on and trying to put up with all the usual steroid side effects.
0/post_text/6: Thanks

0/post_text/0: My nine year old son has had severe posterior uveitis for over three years he's still on high dose steroids on MTX, eye drops, had six operations and still is partially sighted. My seven year old daughter who already wears glasses for long sight has suddenly started writing big and scruffy and saying she cant see the lines on the paper. I am now petrified she has the same. Any body know the chances of having two children with uveitis? Does it run in families.
1/post_text/1: You're clearly very worried. If you haven't already done so, getting your daughter's eyes checked is going to be the only thing that will allay your worry. Sincerely hope a change in prescription is all that's needed.
1/post_text/2: Uveitis running in families is uncommon, but has been known. You will be very unlucky to have two children with uveitis. If you know of an underlying cause for your son's uveitis which is related to a genetic element, the chances of two children developing uveitis are possibly a little higher. Both would have to have the same genetic element and even here, things are not clear cut. Research is being done in rheumatology to find out why family members with a shared genetic predisposition to develop disease do not all develop disease.
1/post_text/3: Fingers crossed here for you and your daughter.
1/post_text/4: Maxine
2/post_text/0: Brenda,
2/post_text/1: Maxine is right the only way to quell the worry a little is to get your daughter's eyes checked. A good high street optician should be able to do that for you, if something is amiss they will be able to fast track you to your local Eye A and E. The other option is to speak to your son's consultant.
2/post_text/2: I have just had a similar worry with both my children, my elder son has ideopathic uveitis and has become partially sighted in one eye and then my other son has some rather worrying rheumatic episodes in his knees. Maxine is right the genetics is very complicated (and it is best to speak to your consultant), however as a rule of thumb (and I remind you that I am NOT MEDICAllY TRAINED) there are some genetic conditions that run in families that can pre-dispose you to getting uveitis. However, generally you would expect them to crop up somewhere else in the family. I think also you can reasonably assume that if your son has been tested for all the usual conditions that are associated with uveitis and they have been ruled out (I.e his uveitis is deemed ideopathic).  A genetic pre-disposition in your daughter is less likely.
3/post_text/0: It was noticed at five o clock on friday and we have an opticians appointment at 9.30 monday morning but in the meantime we are just praying. My sons eyesight went down hill very quickly and only when the uveitis was diagnosed and he was admitted to hospital for intense steroid treatment did they then look for an underlying cause. He was then diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. He has the arthritis in several joints and has had steroid injections in knee and ankle. My daughter has been complaining of leg ache for a couple months and the doctor said growing pains!!!!! she also seems quite tired even after plenty sleep. So these together have made me worried.
4/post_text/0: I know how you feel. I still haven't got over my son's loss of vision and I get the one thing after another. Cells, no cells then cataracts.  I really do get the worry and strain. Therefore,  I am going to tell you that we moved my son from Great Ormond Street. There are alternatives to MTX and Cellcept. The two can also be used in combination, there can be all sorts of different combination of drugs that can be used.  Different hospitals have different criteria for using treatments or combinations of drugs or altogether different treatments. My son is given folic acid in liquid form (he is 7) so we just squirt it into his mouth, so there are alternatives to pills. The prescribing hospital just asked our GP to prescribe it, so don't think it is particularly unusal or expensive. Believe me my GP surgery would have told me. They had to do a cost benefit analysis before agreeing to prescribe oral methotrexate. The folic acid is called "Lexpec" and he has it in a 2.5mg/5ml Oral solution. There is also anti-sickness medication that can be prescribed. My son received excellent care at GOSH but we decided to more him to a tertiary research centre where there treatment philosophy is just different. But I should add we are still under the periodic care of GOSH.
4/post_text/1: We saw my son's rheumatologist privately today for my younger son, though we have
4/post_text/2: requested a referral on the NHS, my nerves couldn't take the strain. Don't panic yet about your daughter I have had several discussions with specialist nurses and they told me that they rarely see siblings both presenting with JIA. Indeed, they said it would be very unusal. Take heart also if there have been no swollen joints.
4/post_text/3: One step at a time.... eyes first.... If you are really worried you could request a blood test for auto immune and inflammation markers. Given your daughters complaints and son diagnoses JIA it doesn't seem unreasonable. I just know how horrible blood tests are for little ones but it might help determine if anything 'unusal' is going on.
5/post_text/0: We also had the cataracts then both lenses removed then steroid injections then cells removed in both eyes. It's all fun!!!!! The folic acid liquid is well worth asking for to see if it makes a difference. He feels rotten for at least 24 hours after methotrexate and he hates the injections so it always makes me feel guilty for doing it. We asked about an anti sickness med but the only thing they offerred was pills for that too.
6/post_text/0: Well we have been reassured abit today. Not growing pains. Hopefully, just a transient sinovitis (can't spell that). Slim possibility that it might be systematic JIA but the good thing is that what ever is going on, it is not related to what happened to his brother. Don't know if this is good or bad but systematic JIA is only form of JIA that is not associated with uveitis. I was rather fearful that systematic is the worst form of JIA but apparantly not and we are only looking at a slim possibility. Number of reasons to be hopeful that it is not and we really have seen, a specialist, specialist. Don't think it would have even been considered if we were at out local hospital seeing a routine pediatrician.  As you say, just one thing after another.
6/post_text/1: Please do let me know how you get on with your daughter. I didn't think my heart could take two poorly children. Your son sounds a trooper. Have you looked at the treatment section of this site. There are other treatments beyond methotrexate and Cellcept. The biologics like Humira for example. Have a look and ask your Consultant about them, it would do no harm.
6/post_text/2: As I say let us know how you get on.
