8/post_text/0: Brenda,
9/post_text/0: There is an eye A and E department at Bournemonth. I tell you the reason why I would take her and I am probably completely wrong but as an uveitis old hand I would worry that cloudiness is vitreous haze which you can get with inflammation. This is when public forums (where people like me who have no medical training give dodgy or alarming advice) can be dangerous. I am probably completely WRONG but we both know how quickly sight can go and there is no point waiting and worrying until Friday. I have taken my son Riley to Eye A and E for much less... For example.. Seeing floating ice bergs. I would also lay everything on very thick - tell them about your son, throw in Consultants names etc (not because I think there is necessarily anything sinister going on) but because it can only help to make everyone take you seriously. Don't be fobbed off by grumpy receptionists or nurses.
10/post_text/0: My son has had severe vitreous haze and had two vitrectomy operations at st thomas' so I also was alarmed. He has floaters and rubbish floating around but after having his cataracts and lenses removed they arent cloudy any more but the debris gets worse with every flare up.
11/post_text/0: Hoping your daughters' eyes are all OK Brenda.
2/post_text/3: Today I have learn't that there are some conditions that can occur as a random/ spontaneous gene mutations which can again pre-dispose you to getting uveitis and this condition is outside of 'usual' group of conditions that doctors look for. However, for this to happen (I.e) the exact same random gene mutation to happen twice in the same family would would be extremely, extremely remote.
2/post_text/4: Also, with regard to your son: oral steroids, MTX and eye drops and multiple operations. Have you considered getting a second opiniom with regard to his treatment? We recently sought a second opinion for my son with uveitis and it has been like a breath of fresh air, for the first time I feel (and there has still been bumps in the road) that we might just get his uveitis under control. A referral on the NHS can take a couple of months but you can just ask your GP. If you approach your GP for a referral it is best to go armed with names. Don't know where you live but if you email OV I am sure they could give you the names of some 'uveitis' specialist that might be able to give you fresh perspective with regards to treatments.
3/post_text/1: My son sees the specialist at great ormond street and has had two operations in ipswich. but we are in bournemouth. The MTX makes him soo sick every week. He has to have injections as he cant swallow tablets so no folic acid to help. His weight ballooned to start with but then settled, but every time he has a flare up they up his steroids again. He used to be on cellcept but then he got chicken pox!!!!! so all together its bee a rubbish three years and as soon as we get a quiet spell with his eyes it all flares up again.
5/post_text/1: The specialist in GOSH seems to know his stuff but its such a trek to get there we go every eight weeks and see a local bloke in between. 0/post_text/0: Hi all,
1/post_text/1: Sorry, I don't know enough about Fuchs to be of much help. There is a Fuchs' support group and you are more likely to find others there who have been through cataract surgery with the risk of raised pressure afterwards.
1/post_text/2: If you haven't already found them, here's a link:
1/post_text/3: http://www.fuchs-dystrophy.org.uk/
1/post_text/4: My own cataract surgery reduced pressure in one eye but I don't know if that was to do with the surgical technique. I would think choosing your surgeon carefully is going to be the key to success. Your present consultant should be able to guide you in this choice. I'm not sure how long you would have to wait for NHS surgey, but with you having uveitis as well, then your eye will need to have been inflammation free for three months before surgery. It is common to prepare an eye before cataract surgery with steroid and given your problem with pressure, it would be a good idea to discuss this with the surgeon. The surgeon who did my surgery used avastin instead of steroid to provide anti inflammatory cover as well as treating the eye's cystoid macular oedema at the same time. (I should point out this was done through medical insurance, not the NHS).

0/post_text/2: The vision of cataract surgery scares me to death. Not because of the cataract itself - outlook is generally good, but the risk of glaucoma after it. 1/post_text/5: The web link below takes you to loads of articles about Fuchs' and cataract surgery. I understand very little from some of them but others are easier to understand with a little knowledge of the eye's anatomy.
1/post_text/7: Since you are being treated privately at the moment, perhaps asking for a slightly longer appointment in order to discuss your concerns with your consultant would give you a lot more peace of mind than we non Fuchs' experts can?
2/post_text/3: Also, how quick did your cataract progress after diagnosis? I feel like my cataract is more visible than 3 weeks ago but not sure whether it is duep to the fog.
3/post_text/1: Cataract isn't a chronic condition. You just state you want cataract surgery. I would be careful though because some insurance companies are using consultants whose fees are lower than those of the really good surgeons. I'd look at the insurance company's web page, see who does cataract surgery in your area and ask your uveitis consultant if those people have the experience to do your Fuchs' cataract surgery.
3/post_text/2: My cataracts were removed after 18 months as part of more complex surgery which was needed. Most take a few years before they interfere with sight. After about six months, a change in glasses prescription made a difference for a further six months for me. Unless yours had been growing well before you were told about it, you'd be very unlucky to notice a difference in sight in three weeks.
3/post_text/3: Good luck getting organised!
5/post_text/1: Not all consultants, in my opinion, see enough cases of uveitis to be able to treat properly. However, sometimes the best surgeons or Consultants only work for the NHS.... As Maxine says "private" doesn't always guarantee the best.

0/post_text/0: Hi,
1/post_text/1: Welcome to the forum and sorry you're here.
1/post_text/2: There are quite a number of us in this boat, either with uveitis or parents of children who have it. You'll get great support from the other parents who have been through the decision you're facing now.
1/post_text/3: As a uveitis sufferer with chronic disease, I had no trouble at all accepting MTX. For me the choice was stark - take it or go blind in both eyes. The choice is much harder to make if no loss of sight has happened and even harder if you're making the decision for your child.
1/post_text/4: JIA uveitis can be difficult to control using only steroid drops and in a way you have a warning right now of the danger that goes with uncontrolled inflammation with the stcking pupil. Continuation with steroid drops alone means cataracts are highly likely to develop and for the unfortunate ones, there is the risk of raised pressure and damaged optic nerves.
2/post_text/0: Hi there,
2/post_text/1: Sorry you have found the sight - thought welcome and I'm glad you have cause you've come to the right place for Mum's of children with JIA Uveitis.
2/post_text/2: My daighter Freya who turned 6 last weekend, was diagnosed with Oligo JIA aged two. She developed Uveitis aged 4 and a half and has been taking MTX ever since, as well as having had 10 joint injections and endless eye drops. She is currently awaiting 3 more joint injections and also being sscreened for Humira. If I thought the decision about putting her on Mtx was difficult, it now seems like nothing when considering adding in another hefty med. Having said that, I can completely understand your reluctance and the doubts you have. I think you have to read as much as you can about the subject, don't be afraid to ask the right questions and make certain you know the reasons why decisions are bing made/suggested. Once you get used to the meds, you can support you child through the problems which may/may not arise and take it as it comes, step by step. Don't be afraid to come back here and ask questions as you go - one of us will have already asked it before you and we'll be able to offer the pearls of our wisdom!
3/post_text/0: Hi, just thought i'd say hello and welcome. My daughter is 12 and has been on mtx for about 4 years now with no adverse effects, she has JIA and uveitis and it seems to control it well. Hope this helps I was really anxious when they first put her on it. Good luck :)

2/post_text/3: I wish you well - take time to adjust as a family and take all the help and support you're offered. I hope you find lots here.

0/post_text/0: Hi,
1/post_text/0: You likely have trace cells in the anterior chamber. It's likely that these are remnants of your original attack. They are not causing damage. Docs are monitoring you to see how stable you are. If you lean towards chronic it,  they may give you steroid drop each day
1/post_text/1: Because trace cells slightly raise probability
1/post_text/2: Of another attack. Steroids are toxic so they don't use them lightly.
1/post_text/3: The cells etc are front of eye so don't cause too much damage. The damage occurs mostly from the posterior inflammation. You need oral steroids to reach back of eye. You can have posterior inflammation without symptoms.
1/post_text/4: Everyone has very different experience with uveitis. Doc needs to see how your uveitis behaves. A second doc giving u steroids clouds the picture.
2/post_text/0: I c u found Dr fosters site. Age and details of meds u took, cell count etc important. People on net very lazy. Won't read total post.
3/post_text/0: Hi Caroline,
4/post_text/0: With my anterior uveitis, there is a bit of red for any cell count above trace. If I was not very familiar with the subtle red of my eye, I would not notice the tiny increase in red that marks cell count above trace. The last time I had iritis, there was a bit of red outlining the iris weeks after I had reached zero cells,however.
4/post_text/1: In one episode, I did get a ton of floaters because I delayed taking steroid until eye was completely red. Floaters obviously mean inflammation of the jelly. Not sure how common that is with iritis. Floaters are obviously one way to detect iritis and pan uveitis.
4/post_text/2: You may, of course, not have redness or floaters and still have posterior involvement.
4/post_text/3: Unfortunately, u will have to check for floaters regularly and be alert to changes.
5/post_text/0: To be clear, if the cells were new that would indicate a new episode and steroids would be indicated. Normally, steroids turn off the attack so inflammation only reduces from that point. Early intervention stops the snowballing.
6/post_text/0: Yes, blurriness is important symptom
6/post_text/1: Even for me who only has anterior uveitis. If I fail to detect minor red, the next symptom is blurriness. Blurriness occurs before the eye
6/post_text/2: Becomes really red. For anterior involvement, blurriness is caused by cells in anterior chamber. Very important to check your eyes one at a time using an eye chart.
7/post_text/0: Hello
0/post_text/1: My story so far; back in April I work up on Saturday morning with the hangover from hell; except I had only had a couple of drinks the night before and do not get hangovers; as the day went on I convienced myself that it must be a migraine;following day I was in bits pain each time I focused; trip to the out of hours doctor (viral conjuctivitis) , then GP, then Opticians (mmm...probably conjuctivitis but it is on the cornea) and a week later I am sat at my local hospital emergency eye client.  I go in thinking viral conjuctivitis; ten minutes later I am have xrays and some many blood tests....
0/post_text/2: Long story short bilateral panuveitis; I ended up on drops and oliment and then oral steriods...I spent a good six/eight weeks with my pupils dilated and now have full respect for anyone dealing with sight lost, just the anxiety alone.  To date they have not found an underlying cause; from my local hospital I was referred on the St Pauls Eye Hospital(Liverpool)in July... So i have had a couple of appointments there, the macular stars (scabs from haemorrhaging in my left eye) have got smaller and smaller from day one; so they are happy with that and then I have been tampered off all drugs.  A couple of weeks ago something did not feel right so I went to the walk in clinic at St Pauls (I wish I had known you could do that from day one!) and they checked, there was still cells in both eye, and scan showed that the stars have decreased again; the doctor said that she would not treat the inflammation as she has worked closely with the uveitis client and they will want to see if and how they develop.. I then received a letter from the Uveitis Clinic pushing my appointment back six weeks so I assume they were also happy with the scan..
1/post_text/5: Detecting uveitis early is important for u because posterior inflammation is damaging.  Myself, I have learned to detect early by checking eye often for redness. I know what is abnormal redness. For me, I don't have luxury of waiting for pain because by that time I need weeks of hourly drops to extinguish inflammation. You never wait if u know you have new episode. I only have iritis. Since u have posterior inflammation, there is no room at all for neglect.
1/post_text/6: You r in remission at this point.
1/post_text/7: There's a guy called Randall who has posterior uveitis. He posts at doc fosters site
3/post_text/1: Sorry you have pan uveitis. That's the type I have, no known cause. The no known cause is a relief for me after reading about the systemic diseases that can go with pan uveitis. Pan uveitis is a more serious type of uveitis but there are now good treatments for it. It's reasonably common for adults to get one off bouts of anterior uveitis, but don't know whether the same holds for pan uveitis.
3/post_text/2: One thing my specialist impressed upon me was that I had to tell him if I noticed anything changing with my sight. I learned to do that and he always saw me within 24 hours. Seems like you're already doing that!
3/post_text/3: It helps to have a basic understanding of the eye so you can follow your progress from one appointment to the next. When they look into your eyes, they will count the cells they see at the front of your eye. If there are only a few cells, they won't treat. They will probably have put drops in and upset your eye just by doing that! You can ask them for the cell grade -1,(5 cells or less) pretty good going, 4, very bad news. They will check the middle of your eye, vitreous (jelly) and the retina at the back.
7/post_text/1: Anterior uveitis is usually recurrent with acute episodes.

3/post_text/4: I can have anterior uveitis without pain and without any redness but I knew when something was happening further back through getting specks of black and grey strandy like things floating around in my vision. I also knew because there would be flashes of silver light at the edges of my vision and most obvious of all, my sight would get worse. If you experience these things, go in and get them checked.
3/post_text/5: I think the fact you had a scan and nothing troubled the doc is reassuring. The scan would have shown what is going on at the back of the eye. I suspect not treating the cells seen is either because these were anterior and so few they don't require treatment or the inflammation was in the vitreous which doesn't contain anything to cause you to lose vision.
7/post_text/3: 24*7 Best
4/post_text/4: Bright sky is best. Well lit mirror for Monitoring red. Reading glasses if necessary.
4/post_text/5: As far as iritis pain, you should not experience that again. You should be catching anterior involvement long before the iris sticks to lens causing pain. However, I do hear contrary accounts. Not sure why. Rapid onset? Absence of red? Neglect? Steroid resistance?

2/post_text/0: Assuming you'll see Prof A in the coming weeks to check this flare up has gone, I'd print out these questions and give them to him. He's used to our worries and won't mind answering them. I've tested this with him! With uveitis in one eye and episcleritis in the other, he is the best person to say whether your right eye is likely to escape uveitis.
2/post_text/1: Cataracts and steroid tend to go together but uveitis itself can also cause them. Cataract surgery cures cataract, but not uveitis. It's a shock to hear you have early signs of cataract but it can take a long time before a cataract affects vision with some uveitis patients seeing well for years before they need surgery. It's important that once vision is affected you tell Prof A how it's affected because we may see the eye chart well in a darkened room, but in natural light and artificial light, we don't see so well.  Specialists usually operate at the point everyday life is affected and the eye has been free of inflammation for three months. Prof A will schedule surgery as soon as you need it.
2/post_text/2: Glaucoma is a risk in uveitis but specialists are incredibly careful to prevent people developing it. High eye pressure, which often precedes glaucoma, can be reduced by drops and sometimes surgery to prevent glaucoma. Specialists do everything they can to prevent us developing glaucoma either as a consequence of steroid drops or because our type of disease is associated with high ocular pressure. You seem to be one of the lucky ones at the moment whose pressures aren't affected by steroid.

She was put on pred forte eye drops and then methotrexate.  Her knee has never flared up since starting the methotrexate but her eyes would always flare up once the eye drops were stopped.  Her eyes have recently flared while still taking the eye drops so her methotrexate was increased.  It has now been two months since increasing her dose to 10mg and her left eye was worse last week at her checkup so I have been told she will have to go onto humira or infliximab.
1/post_text/0: My son's experience between Humira and Remicade (infliximab) is pretty much posted all over OV. If I even mention the word Humira he gets extremely anxious and teary-eyed, fear-filled. He was the one to make the decision to start infusions. He tried Humira for several months. He finally told the rheumy he couldn't stand it anymore and wanted to try "something else". The rheumy explained infusions. Braiden has had tons of IV's previous to this so the process was familiar. He told the rheumy, "I've had IV's before. They're not bad at all. Let's do that". That was the sealer on the deal. Make it so that Kaydee has as much choice in it as possible so she feels like she has some level of power over her disease. Read my previous posts to see the comfort measures we use for infusions if you get a chance...sending HUGS from Braiden.

8/post_text/3: BTW finally after weeks of grumbling, eyes seem to have no flares. Only last week she was +1/+2 in both eyes. On the flip side she has to stick with 4 drops a day for six weeks before tapering.
5/post_text/2: It might help to speak to someone from the Bechet's Syndrome Society. They campaigned for these centres and having met a couple of them, one of the things they both said was how difficult it is for some of their members to receive a diagnosis because there is no one definite test for BD. They should be able to tell you more about getting a diagnosis and who to see in London.
5/post_text/3: Their helpline number is 0845 1307329. The ones I've met are lovely, upbeat people and you'll feel a whole heap better having had a chat with one of them.
9/post_text/1: The difference I noticed between Maxidex and the Minims is that the Minims come out of a much smaller tip! A drop of that doesn't flood my eyes and run down my face! 1/post_text/1: High pressure can cause blurred vision especially if using steroid drops. Sometimes after putting in a steroid drop this is a transient blurring, lasting less than a minute, about 10 to 15 minutes after the drop.
1/post_text/2: There are, however, many causes of blurred vision: dry eyes, effect of a cataract, flare and so on. The safest thing to do is to get his eyes looked at.

2/post_text/0: Hi Kaiser,
2/post_text/1: The injection is pretty good at clearing CME and people usually notice a difference within days or a couple of weeks. There is a little risk, but the ophths. giving these injections have given loads of them, so I wouldn't worry on that count.
2/post_text/2: You're right, cataract surgery may cause CME. Some of us receive a steroid injection during the surgery which prevents that from happening. The surgery itself is only carried out when the eye is inflammation free and has been so for about three months. This gives the best chance of complication free surgery without post op. CME. You could ask your ophth. how long it will be after an injection before a cataract starts to develop.
2/topic_title: Should i get a second opinion?
3/post_text/0: Hi maxine,
3/topic_title: Should i get a second opinion?
4/post_text/0: Hi Kaiser,
4/post_text/1: CME can reoccur. It's less likely to if the inflammation is controlled. A steroid injection can clear the CME and stop inflammation for a number of months. You may be lucky and find you go a considerable length of time without either CME or inflammation. Should either recur, that's possibly the point immunosupression would be reconsidered.  New floaters are a sign that inflammation is active again and if that inflammation isn't controlled, or it's very severe, CME might occur.
4/post_text/2: What happens in the future is a bit of guessing game and your ophth. is the best person to answer this. They can be fairly sure what's likely to happen when there is a diagnosed cause behind the uveitis and both eyes are affected, especially with some types of underlying disease.
4/post_text/3: Glad you feel a bit more comfortable about the injection now!

7/post_text/2: Like Tania, I tried blueberries but didn't like the things and could only tolerate them in a blueberry crumble smothered in cream, which probably wasn't the best thing to do! Blueberries are apparently high in either lutein or zeaxanthin or both. I found you could buy lutein in pill form and there are specially made eye pills which have been used to help with macular degeneration, so might help with the CME. You'll also find medical articles on saffron - some people add that to tea and adding it to rice is common practice. Other people follow an anti inflammatory diet and there's lots of information about such a diet on the web.

0/post_text/3: RHEUMATOLOGY UNIT
0/post_text/4: A Guide to your Shared Care Card.
0/post_text/5: What is a Shared Care Card?
0/post_text/6: The shared care card is the yellow card you will have been given at the hospital. The information on this card will help you, the doctors at the hospital and your own doctor (GP ) to share information about your condition and its treatment.
0/post_text/7: Why have I been given such a card?
0/post_text/8: In agreement with your doctor you will have been asked to take a type of tablet/injection, for your arthritis known as a second line agent, or disease modifying agent (DMARD). You will have been given an information leaflet about the specific tablet you have been prescribed. While you are taking this medication it is important for you to have regular blood tests. The information about the results of you blood tests will be put on your card and provide a valuable record for you and your doctors to refer to.
0/post_text/9: Where do I get my blood tests done?
0/post_text/10: You can organise an appointment for your blood tests to be taken at your local
0/post_text/11: surgery. It is your responsibility to make sure you arrange to have these tests at the right time.
0/post_text/12: How often do I need to have my blood tests done?
0/post_text/13: Information about how often you should arrange to have your blood taken is written on your drug information leaflet. The most usual routine is every 2 weeks for the first Information about how often you should arrange to have your blood taken is written on your drug information leaflet. The most usual routine is every 2 weeks for the first 3 months after starting the treatment, and then every month. Your doctor may tell you after a while that you need not have your blood taken so often.
0/post_text/14: Why are these blood tests important?
0/post_text/15: It is important to have your blood tested regularly. They help to tell you and your doctors if the medication is helping your arthritis or not, and if the medication is causing any side effects that you might not be aware of.
0/post_text/16: We would encourage you to keep this card on you at all times and to make sure
0/post_text/17: it is filled in before you see the doctor. If you telephone for the results of your blood tests, or are given a print out from the doctors with the results on please feel free to enter these carefully on to the card. It will help save time for the doctor or nurse in clinic.
0/post_text/18: What do all the different tests mean?
0/post_text/20: What is it measuring and why is it important?
0/post_text/21: ESR Can vary depending on test used.
0/post_text/22: This test reflects how much inflammation your arthritis
0/post_text/23: has caused. It is used to see how your arthritis improves
0/post_text/25: CRP 0- 8 This also measures inflammation, but can show changes
0/post_text/26: quicker than the ESR. It is used to show how you are responding to the medication you are taking.
0/post_text/27: Hb 11.8-16 Hb or Haemoglobin is found in the red cells in the blood.
0/post_text/28: It helps transport Oxygen around the body. A lack of haemoglobin means you are anaemic.
0/post_text/29: MCV 80-95 fl This measures the average size of the red blood cell.
0/post_text/30: Along with the Hb test, it may help to show the cause of any anaemia or reflect a side effect of the medication.
0/post_text/31: WBC 4-11 White Blood count. This is the total number of white cells in the blood. An increase in these cells can indicate infection or, inflammation. A decrease in these cells can show a reduction in the body’s ability to fight infection.
0/post_text/33: Neutrophils are 1 of 5 different sorts of white blood cells. They are measured as a percentage of all the white cells in the blood. A reduction of neutrophils makes it harder for you to fight infection, and may be caused by
0/post_text/34: your arthritis or as a reaction to the medication you are taking.
0/post_text/35: Plats 150-400 Platelets are another type of blood component. They are important in helping the blood to clot. A reduction in platelets among other things may show that you are having a reaction to your medication. An increase of platelets may be as a result of your arthritis.
0/post_text/37: These are tests to show any inflammation of your liver,which can occur as a side effect of your medication.Some changes in the results of these tests may mean that your medication needs adjusting.
0/post_text/39: 70-150 This test is a measure of how well your kidneys are working. This is also important, as it can be affected by your medication.
0/post_text/40: BP dependant on age. Blood Pressure is as a general test of your fitness.
0/post_text/41: Urine is tested for glucose, protein, and blood cells which may occur as a side effect of the drug or an infection.
0/post_text/42: C 2283 / M Cox / J Flynn / Rheumatology Patient Information/ Version 3 / December2008

Two years of uveitis, one eye only, never been off steroid drops as always active, had two orbital floor injections in this time, pressure suddenly soared one day to 55 but back down to 14 with two different drops (which i think aggravate the Uveitis) so have now accepted I have to go on Methotrexate which I never wanted to as only have one eye effected.  Been taking it for 3 weeks now.  I am now feeling desperate, I see hardly anything out of my bad eye (cant read anything} just all a blur and although I have one good eye everything is off balance with one side a blurr.  I have sub capsular cataract but just cannot believe that in the space of one year which is when it was first spotted I have gone from seeing to a complete blur and now finding it hard to work properly as glasses make no difference, live alone with my teenager so work is crucial.  I cannot have op as my Uveitis is never quiet and now I am convinced I have swelling at the back of eye again although they said they don't think so  but that it is hard to see through the cataract. Is it possible that just the cataract could make vision so bad in such a short space of time, 4 months ago I could see letters still if i put glasses on.  All the things I love doing have now gone out the window, is it like this for everyone or am I just not being positive enough?  :(
1/post_text/1: Sorry it's all feeling too much right now.
1/post_text/2: It can take some time for the brain to adapt to the different sight from each eye, but it does adapt and eventually you stop feeling so conscious of the blur on one side. It's a pain waiting for this to happen though - took me at least two months and even then, I could still upset myself by shutting the better eye and mourning, all over again, what had been lost.
1/post_text/3: Sometimes cataracts develop for several years before they affect sight and if steroid sparing treatment begins, the interval between first sighting and surgery can be lengthy. For a few people, they develop rapidly and some glaucoma drops accelerate their development as do steroid injections. My own cataracts developed very slowly for eighteen months, then it was a matter of only two months before the world was a blur.
1/post_text/4: Good for you making the move to mtx. You've spared yourself the danger from the steroid induced high pressure and once the mtx controls inflammation, you're in a much better position for cataract surgery with an immunosuppressant in place to help with the possibility of post op. inflammation.

8/post_text/2: No, I'm not on immunosuppressants, never have been, because it's nearly always been one eye only, and they tend not to go down that road with it.  As for my uveitis history, it was active from 12 to 18, and then flared up a little at 21. It's been quiet from then until recently, aged 34, when it suddenly came back, but as anterior this time (always intermediate when I was a teenager). I've also had an epiretinal membrane peeled off as they thought it was posing a risk to the retina.
8/post_text/3: I sort of hope you've given the steroids a try by now, as I'm worrying about your sight. If all else fails, a chat with your GP might help - s/he will have seen many people take steroids for many different things, and can perhaps help with a different perspective.   E x
5/post_text/2: With the anti vegf, pressure may rise, but they can compensate by letting down the pressure just before the injection. It's done with a needle - odd sensation, bit uncomfortable but not painful. The pressure rises again naturally over the next few hours. You do have to be aware that improvement doesn't last months like it can do with steroid injections and the underlying cause of the oedema isn't changed. I think there is a Lucentis trial going on at Moorfields for recalcitrant cystoid macular oedema, but I think you have to be inflammation free. By the way, if you can get on that trial, if you can cope with orbital floor injections, the anti vegf into the eye will feel like a piece of cake in comparison!
5/post_text/3: Have you taken that first pill yet?
4/post_text/4: If you do go for the steroid tablets, make sure your GP/consultant does the correct checks - I'm not sure of the full list, but I think blood pressure and some blood tests every so often.
4/post_text/5: Also, you mention worrying about the cataract.  Again, I can only talk from personal experience, but I do now have a cataract in both eyes. However, I took the steroids 16 years ago, and the cataracts have remained tiny for all this time. Now, my right eye vision has just dropped to 6/7. I am still driving, using a computer etc. Eventually I will have surgery to remove it, but it will probably be 20 years after the steroid tablets.
4/post_text/6: I hope this helps. You can read other peoples' experiences of steroids on the site. Take care,
5/post_text/5: Maxine

0/post_text/0: Olivia's Vision has been contacted by Arthritis Care to help produce a booklet for parents of JIA and JIA-uveitic children.  The aim of the booklet is to provide parents with advice, support and personal tips.  We are looking for parents to take part and help others through their own personal experiences.  Confidentiality will be respected, and anonymity can be retained.
0/topic_title: Does your child suffer from JIA associated uveitis?
1/post_text/1: My daughter, who is also named Olivia, was dxed with pauciarticular JIA at 16 months. Her joints were txed with cortisone injections at 20 months and have remained "quiet" ever since. She was dxed with uveitis at 23 months and was treated with Predforte drops for one year until she developped glaucoma-2ry to the chronic use of cortisone drops. Ever since she's been treated with MTX and off and on Predforte. She has also been on glaucoma drops for the last 2 years. My beautiful daughter is now 6 and we discovered last Wednesday that the inflammation in her right eye was at +2 and the pressure in her left eye was at 36. Further tests confirmed permanent irreversible damage to the optic nerve in the left eye with peripheral vision loss (tunnel vision). I don't know/understand how we got to this point seeing as she has had follow up visits every week to two weeks for the last 6 months but what's done is done. The dr said surgery to alleviate the pressure is inevitable to prevent further damage and that in order to do the surgery the pressure has to come down. She is now on Maxidex, Predforte, Xalatan, Combigan, Mydriacil, MTX and Diamox and her rheuma wants to start her on Humira. Devastated does not begin to describe how we feel. WHY??? IT'S NOT FAIR!!!How horrific is it to sit there in the dr's office and be told they want your child to start Humira and that the potential side effects include cancer and MS like symptoms? Insanely horrific. I have spent the last 3 days on an emotional roller coaster and a friend suggested I join some blogs. I don't know if this is going to help me or if it helps others to know my situation but at this point it's worth a try. We started her on the Diamox this morning with no adverse side effects thank God and we are still debating whether or not we will go for the Humira. I am terrified of my daughter loosing her sight but I am also terrified of loosing her. I wish it would just all go away.
1/post_text/2: Thank you for this website....
1/post_text/3: Eva
1/topic_title: Does your child suffer from JIA associated uveitis?
2/post_text/0: Hi Eva,
2/post_text/1: My heart aches for you and the difficult decision you now face.
2/post_text/2: With side effects, the only way forward is to remember they are potential side effects and to ask your doctors for the estimated percentages of children affected by them and after how long they become apparent. Those who treat us are well aware that safer treatments are needed and research is going on into these. One way of looking at humira is seeing it as a way of buying time for your daughter's sight until better, safer treatment becomes available, but there is no guarantee of when this might be.
2/topic_title: Does your child suffer from JIA associated uveitis?
0/post_text/1: This is a huge opportunity for awareness of uveitis to be raised and I hope that as many parents as possible will choose to participate.
0/post_text/2: If you would like to take part please email us at
2/post_text/3: If you are in the UK, there is a study going on into the use of humira in children. If you are part of this study, your daughter will be monitored closely for side effects and you'll have the assurance that the drug would be stopped should there be an indication that all is not going well.
2/post_text/4: Humira works incredibly well at stopping inflammation and getting people off the eye drops which themselves cause damage to sight. It's likely to save the sight in your daughter's right eye.
0/post_text/3: info@oliviasvision.org
0/post_text/4: Thank you
0/post_text/6:
-----
Dedicated to helping Uveitis sufferers
2/post_text/5: There are other mothers here who are placed in the same position as you with very young children offered, or about to begin, humira. They are better able to respond to you than I can. As an adult, in much the same position as your daughter, I didn't hestitate to start infliximab, a drug similar to humira. My uveitis had already given me periods of blindness and badly affected the quality of my life, so I knew the alternative. For me, the risks were worth it and these past three years, infliximab has given me back my life. I'm just grateful I was offered it.
2/post_text/6: Equally, this past year, OV was invited to visit the Royal National College for the Blind to see how the blind are rehabilitated, educated and trained for employment. The RNC is an incredible place and I know that I would have coped with my period of blindness much better, had I known such high quality help was available.
2/post_text/7: I hope the other mothers will respond to you soon. I felt raw reading your post and I expect it's hit the parents of very young children even harder.
2/post_text/8: Thank you for posting and opening this difficult discussion. Uveitis is certainly not fair and to use your words, devastatingly unfair where young children are concerned.
2/post_text/9: I'm saddened that you have to make this decision and I hope the other mums will do a better job of helping you with it than I can.

2/post_text/1: Posterior cataracts do cause vision loss, but it's unusual for them to do so within  four months unless you are really, really unlucky. 1/post_text/3: Sorry for the questions but I'm very concerned by the fact that you were told it was OK to stop and start the steroid drops as and when you felt you needed them over such a long period of time.  If steroid drops are stopped abruptly this can cause the inflammation to come back with a vengeance.  For this reason patients are advised to carry out a very slow taper - usually over a period of months.
1/post_text/4: I also don't understand how a consultant can state that your uveitis was likely to be HLA-B27 related without any testing.  A simple blood test can rule out whether or not you are ANA+ and also HLA-B27+ or not, indicating whether systemic disease might be involved.

4/post_text/1: Thankfully you have now had bloods taken, so the question of whether or not you are ANA+ and HLA-B27+ will soon be resolved.  It's not a given that because family members suffer from autoimmune diseases that you will too.  Over 50% of uveitis sufferers never find out what causes their uveitis, and although I agree with Maxine that some patients report a connection with stress, many patients seem to find no associations. Unfortunately uveitis effects people so differently it can often be tricky to find a common pattern.
4/post_text/2: Illness can exacerbate a flare, and many sufferers (my daughter included) particularly those who are ANA+, will experience this.
4/post_text/3: Concerning the inevitability of cataracts and steroids, the University of Illinois Eye and Ear Infirmary reported that a minimum of 2 drops a day for 10.5 months (or approx 750 drops) caused cataract formation in 50% of people.  Some are lucky and it takes much longer, some patients are far less fortunate.

6/post_text/0: Some info that may help you understand the condition better.
6/post_text/1: It is now believed through recent research that the immune system has 2 basic components. The initial phase is the inflammatory phase and is called the innate immune system and the second phase is called the adaptive immune system. Both work in conjunction with one another. The innate immune system is inherited and encompasses defense mechanisms handed down from your ancestors and coded in your genes. The adaptive immune system is a library of infections that you have experienced during your life and the antibody templates to fight them.
6/post_text/2: It's believed that the innate immune system is responsible for many of the conditions that we suffer from. The initial process is to induce inflammation and deploy cells such as phagocytes to clean up an infection. The inflammation is just an increase in size of the blood vessels to improve the deployment of fighting cells and to clean up after antibodies when the adaptive immune system has done its job.
6/post_text/3: However in these conditions the inflammatory process just continues and is called auto-inflammatory. The adaptive immune system cannot find anything and is not deployed. The system's start button  has been pressed but the stop button malfunctions.
6/post_text/4: In all cases it is a genetic coding fault. In some they can identify the gene that is causing the problem e.g. Ankylosing spondolytis. In many they cannot identify the cause.

5/post_text/1: Some people do find their eyes flare when they have a bad cold, but it doesn't happen to everyone. The thinking goes that an immune system revs up to fight the cold or virus and decides to attack the eyes while its at it. Some doctors believe that the body fighting an infection can be the trigger for some types of uveitis to start in the first place. Then there is infectious uveitis which begins with a pathogen getting into the eye and viral uveitis, such as when the herpes virus gets into an eye. For many of us though, there doesn't need to be a triggering infection for the immune system to have another go at our eyes - it just decides to hold a party there regardless of anything we're doing.

0/post_text/0: Hi how do I find a new local eye specialist the one I have is useless and keeps discharging us or we get forgotten about?
1/post_text/1: In general, if your uveitis is anterior and not chronic, even the big regional eye centres which have specialist uveitis clinics will treat you in emergency clinics and discharge you once a flare is over.
1/post_text/2: If you have posterior, intermediate or pan uveitis, most of us are treated in a specialist uveitis clinic. Those with anterior uveitis which is chronic and whose eyes have complications such as cystoid macular oedema, high ocular pressure and cataracts are also treated in specialist clinics. That's one option if your uveitis is chronic - referral to a specialist uveitis centre and you travel to it. An underlying autoimmune disease might also get you into a specialist uveitis clinic. Your GP will arrange this referral.
1/post_text/3: The other thing you can do is google local hospitals nearby and look at the services offered by ophthalmology. If you see a uveitis clinic listed, there is likely to be a fellowship trained consultant or registrar working there. While you may still have to attend an emergency clinic each time your eye(s) flare, there will at least be someone there with whom the general ophthalmologist can confer. If there is a patient review page for ophthalmology, it's worth looking at that.
1/post_text/4: One of our members with anterior uveitis visited all the emergency clinics in his area to find one he liked (he managed to visit 4!)and where he trusted the doctors. The one he liked has a specialist uveitis service so the emergency docs were accustomed to anterior uveitis and stressed out patients. He asked his GP for referral to this centre but ended up being referred to another local hospital with a uveitis consultant because of funding arrangements at that time.

0/post_text/1: My daughter has been diagnosed with JIA-associated uveitis.  We have been on steriods for about 5 or so months (Pred Forte), w/ 14 mg of MTX over the last 3.5 months.  Dilating drops are also a part of the treatment.  We had the inflammation controlled for a little while (4-6 weeks), but it has returned as we tapered off steriods.  Our next step will be to consider increasing the MTX dosage when we see the Rhuem in about a month, or to include Humira in the treatment.
0/post_text/2: The only positive test has been an IGM, presenting in P23 and P41 strands.  We were told this is for acute Lyme, but that it could be a false positive.  Nonetheless, we were initially put on amoxicillan (oral) for 30 days to treat acute Lyme first (before immunomodular treatment of MTX).  However, the results came back positive after antibiotic treatment, with no change in the IGM positive test.  She has no other positive blood tests, and has been tested for all the usuals (including ANA).
2/post_text/3: It's not the easiest of reads but it does discuss your very question.
0/post_text/3: Her condition is chronic uveitis, more prevalent in the right eye.  Infammation, posterior synch, and band kerathapothy are also present.
0/post_text/4: Does anyone have an understanding if the JIA can "cross-contaminate" the IGM test for Lyme?  Both ELISA and Western blot were conducted as well.  The specific positive is as explained for the P23 and P41 strands in the IGM.  Thanks.

0/post_text/0: To cut a long story short my beautiful baby boy was diagnosed with uveitis in both eyes. He has had a whole host of investigations, blood tests, chest x-rays. All was negative even for ANA and rheumatoid factor. I honestly don't know if this is good or bad. He has been on a corse of tapering steroid eye drops and has has dilating eye drops. Today, we took him to eye A & E and told that he has had a flare up. I am scared that a) some awful autoimmune disease will present itself and b) that the uveitis will move into the back of his eye. At the moment, the uveitis was caught early enough to prevent sight damage. I get the impression with this disease that it just goes from bad to worse!

1/post_text/0: In essence he says that this type uveitis is normally associated with some systemic condition like juvenile arthritis but he has been unable to identify the type of underlying inflammatory condition causing it.
1/post_text/1: However this is not unusual. They aren't always able to establish the underlying condition because in numerous cases the event can be caused by a minor injury. The key, as I recently found out, is that an inflammatory process has been initiated but not turned off. The science is advancing but this may be down to an inherent genetic malfunction. Hence they often have to resort to immuno-suppression to get a result.

3/post_text/1: When I was at Bristol recently the consultant was able to make this a lot clearer and I will try to explain more fully.
3/post_text/2: There are a number of conditions that have uveitis as a component part. They try to establish if what they are seeing is one of the conditions that is well known such as JIA.
3/post_text/3: However like me he has bilateral uveitis which is not common. The immune system has two components. The first part initiates basic body defense and is called the innate system. This alerts the body to danger when something unusual happens by bringing large numbers of macrophages (white cells) into the area and also triggering inflammation to increase the blood circulation to the area. This part of the immune system is ancient and is with us from birth and has components handed down about diseases our ancestors encountered.
0/post_text/3: The fisrt part i undersatnde the bilateral anterior uveits and synechiae but not the rest.  The 2nd part do you think they think that he may have jia or not?
0/post_text/4: thanks
3/post_text/4: The second part is called the adaptive system which identifies foreign invaders such as bacteria, viruses and foreign protein (as in transplanted tissue). This system manufactures antibodies to kill invaders which are then eaten by the macrophages in step one. The system library of encounters with invaders builds over a lifetime and allows the body to cope better. This is why the young and the old are susceptible to disease whilst the middle remain healthy (usually :) ).
3/post_text/5: Hence the cause of uveitis for many could be a simple injury that causes the innate system to induce inflammation (auto-inflammatory). Under normal circumstances the system should turn off the inflammation but for some unknown reason the genetics of that person has failed and the stop button fails.
3/post_text/6: Hope that helps you a bit.

1/post_text/1: If the only reason for switching from drops to tablets is to avoid cataracts then I would definitely stick with the drops. Steroid tablets have plenty of side affects themselves and as you say, drops are the better option if you wish to try for a baby.  I have had both drops, injections and tablets to treat intermediate uveitis and iritis at different times. I now have cataracts in both eyes, but I know that when they reach the point of driving me nuts (or stopping me driving) then they can be removed. I always like to remember the fact that in Africa, there is a bus that goes around, and people get their cataract surgery on the bus in 20 minutes - so I tell myself that if they can do that, then they can certainly do mine in a hospital. I know that when they do the surgery we will have to be careful not to cause further inflammation. Also, my consultant tells me that if I get pregnant the hormones might help to settle the iritis anyway, and so you if you are lucky you may come off the drops altogether during your pregnancy.
1/post_text/2: I know it is a difficult decision. I tried to get pregnant last year, but I find that when I come off my contraceptive it causes my eye to flare up. After 6 months I was fed up and not pregnant, so I went back on the pill for a break. We are trying again now, so every time my eye looks a bit pink I panic. Fingers crossed when I see the consultant in May, I've not got inflammation anywhere.

1/post_text/1: What a disappointment after such a good start with the Humira.
1/post_text/2: Infliximab has kept my eyes stable for the past few years. I had slight inflammation just before an infusion was due when I was receiving infusions every eight weeks. Reducing the interval to six weeks brought stability. It's important that the dose given is the uveitis dose rather than the RA dose which is a bit lower.
1/post_text/3: Infusions don't leave me feeling sick or tired and I'm good to go when they're over. This might be a bit different for children and they often receive an additional med before the infusion to help prevent any allergic reaction. I'm careful about avoiding infection of any type - infusions are put back a week and mtx stopped if I have even a cold sore. The nurses are strict about this. Blood checks are done before each infusion and the needle used for this remains in place for the infusion itself - no double stabbing! My infusions take two hours, but they may be a bit longer for children, especially when they first begin their treatment. The first three infusions are normally loading ones and are given much closer together than six or eight weeks.
1/post_text/4: One of the good things about infliximab is the leeway offered to adjust dose to suit the patient's inflammation.

5/post_text/1: I am sorry Humira didn't work for you. I am glad I logged in today. I haven't had time to check in with my OV friends in a while. Braiden was on Humira for 6 months. Initially it worked for a few weeks, then he had a big flare. They upped his dose and made it weekly. This still did not control the flare. We started infusions in (November?). We started out on 150mg every 8 weeks. That helped to reduce the inflammation a bit. He then had another tremendous flare. The Remicade was increased to 200mg, every 6 weeks and his MTX was increased to 25mg subcut every week. He is now cell-free for the first time in 2 years and starting to taper off of steroids.
7/post_text/1: I totally understand your situation.  My 5 year old daughter was diagnosed with JIA and Uveitis when she was 2 and a half.  Pred Forte eye drops were keeping her Uveitis away but it would always flare back when the drops were stopped so she was put on to Methotrexate.  However she was on the lowest dose and only 2 months ago got the dose increased to 10mg as her eyes were flaring while still on drops which had never happened before.  I feel that the Methotrexate needs to be a much higher dose to fight the Uveitis but the Rheumatology DR & nurse refuse to do this as they say the side efects will be much more severe.

3/post_text/5: They too come with side effects but are generally thought to be a bit safer than the anti tnfs. I have to admit that I didn't like the look of the potential side effects either, but I was losing sight and couldn't see to drive, so I was simply grateful to be offered infliximab and then when it had such a rapid effect (hours), I didn't care about the side effects. I could see again. The world brightened.
3/post_text/6: It is a very difficult to decision to make for your child and I hope further discussion with your consultant helps you with it.
5/post_text/2: I understand your frustration and feeling like nothing will ever work. We have been there with every new treatment. Remicade seems to be the trick, now that he is on the higher doses of Remicade and MTX. It has brought great relief that he is seeing better than he has ever seen and pain-free. He now doesn't mind going outside, whereas before, the sunlight was excrutiating. Humira is offered first because it is easier to administer, without needing the expense of an infusion clinic. Infusions are time consuming, 3 hours for us, where Humira is a quick shot at home. We go to the clinic prepared to keep Braiden entertained. I bring snacks, drinks, changes of clothing, my laptop for WiFi, movies, toys, music, etc. We ask for a shot of Lidocaine at the IV site so that placing the IV is pain-free, particularly if they have to dig around for a wiggly vein. I hope I have been helpful. I tend to ramble! You are in my thoughts as you prepare to make this decision.

1/post_text/1: please refer to your posting under General Questions where a couple of members have responded.
1/post_text/2: Nicki

0/post_text/0: Hi my daughter has anterior uveitis she's been on steroid drops for 10 months and every time they're lowered she flares again, we can get down to 2 drops a day but anything lower than that seems to cause problems.  Her eye pressure is fine but I found out yesterday that she has the beginnings of a cataract.  I asked the consultant whether she should come off the drops because I've read that using them can make this happen, but he said it was fine and that if things get too bad she can have surgery when she's older becuase it was more important to get rid og the inflammation.  I'm really worried that she'll end up losing sight, does anyone else have cataracts?
1/post_text/1: Steroid drops do cause cataracts and uveitis itself can cause them too.
1/post_text/2: It is important that inflammation is controlled and drops do a good job with anterior uveitis. Ten months is a long time to be on them though and unable to taper off. Does your daughter have an autoimmune condition to go with her uveitis which might explain why inflammation is so persistent? Have any tests been carried out? Are both eyes affected or just one?
1/post_text/3: It usually takes ages for cataracts to develop to the point sight is badly affected. Some uveitis patients I know are still seeing well despite a cataract having begun to form four years ago.
1/post_text/4: Reading the treatments section gives you some idea of treatments used after steroid.
2/post_text/0: Hi Sofie,
2/post_text/1: I too have a steroid-induced cataract and I remember my initial response to hearing that being exactly the same - wanting to stop all drops immediately. That was now three years ago and I still have that same cataract - and I see enough with that eye that I will wait longer before having the cataract op! As Maxine has already said, the drops are really the best way of putting out the fire of inflammation in the eye - uncontrolled inflammation can itself lead to loss of sight, which may not be as easily recovered as through a cataract operation. I know it's hard, but continuing with the drops whilst inflammation is present is important.
2/post_text/2: Maxine has given you some great advice about what to discuss with your doctor, and I agree that would really be worth doing some blood tests now if they haven't already been done. These often give a really good indication to what the best treatment approach may be, and what to expect.
3/post_text/0: Hi Sofie,
1/post_text/5: These are more likely to be considered if both eyes are affected. Perhaps a discussion with your daughter's doctor about her future treatment would be helpful?
1/post_text/6: Ask the doctor how much longer your daughter will be treated using drops before other treatment is considered. Tell the doctor you are worried about your daughter losing sight because the inflammation keeps coming back once she's off the drops. Most doctors are happy to give you a plan for future treatment.
1/post_text/7: Please stay in touch and let us know what happens at your next appointment.
2/post_text/3: Take care,
3/post_text/1: I hope you will come back with an update.
3/post_text/2: Our story is similar to yours.

0/post_text/0: I have had two bouts of Anterior Uveitis both treated with great effort skill and expense in Caen eye hospital in France. They did however have few ideas on preventing what they see as an almost inevitable recurrence, which I and by the sound of it many others are keen to avert.
0/topic_title: preventing a recurrence with Pineapple and Turmeric and nettle tea
1/post_text/1: I did go down this line when I got uveitis 3 years ago.  I actually did the Paleo diet for 8 months coupled with copious amounts of tumeric (you have to take black pepper with it to make it effective).  I also took saffron and juiced blueberries (also anti inflammatory) every morning.  I spent hours researching anti-inflammatory cures on the net.  A lot are along the lines of cancer therapies and advocate a lot of juicing.  I am convinced it helps but cure?  not sure...  I am in drug remission but I continue to not eat dairy or wheat (both aggravate inflammation) and eat blueberries and pineapples most days in a blender. There are a lot of articles on 'leaky gut' which are supposedly responsible for autoimmune illnesses.  Interesting articles on this theory some supported by medical people.  I think that whatever if you eat as healthier as possible it has to contribute to your body healing.  Although I am slim, I do kmow lots of research points to reducing calorie intake to improve and aid healing of cells, I just cannot restrict my intake as enjoy food too much.  Have a look at Jason Vale, juicing and blending cures and below is an anti-inflammatory recipe passed to me by friend who has reduced cancer with turmeric pills although I have not tried it yet so cannot vouch for it tasting good!  Anyway good luck with the turmeric and pineapple
1/post_text/2: 10 cm/4 in fresh turmeric, or 2 tsp ground turmeric (peel & grate if using fresh)
1/post_text/3: 3 tbsp coconut milk yoghurt (co yo) or cream from can of coconut milk
1/post_text/4: 50 g/2 oz gluten-free oats

10/post_text/4: Somewhere down the line of immunosuppression I developed arthritis symptoms too. I'd read about leaky gut too, as well as a specific theory for Ankylosing Spondylitis - and thought I'd test it for a few weeks. This coincided with some regular bloods for the MTX monitoring so I could see that changing what I ate directly impacted my ESR reading (inflammation marker) - and I felt much better. Interesting.
11/post_text/1: I know this is an old thread - any further info please?
11/post_text/2: I would love to believe that i could help my daughters eyes with natural methods.  She is 10 and experiencing a flare of Uveitis.  Currently on MTX and striods (drops and oral) and soon to start humira.
10/post_text/5: A close friend was going through cancer treatment too so I started reading alongside his wife - Chris Woolam's website
10/post_text/7: has a huge amount of information. It was info I was hearing from multiple sources, and when I thought about it my immunosuppressant was indeed also used (at very different doses) as a chemo drug - so applying some of the things he recommended made complete sense for me. I ended up changing what I cook with (no more non-stick), got rid of BPA, changed my skincare and make-up etc etc - and also doing things to help detox. Ultimately all drugs are toxins in some form, I want to help my body use the drugs effectively and then get rid of whatever it doesn't need. So I looked into ways to detox - epsom baths, occasional juice fasts (I too love Jason Vale - heard him speak earlier this year), also I like some of Patrick Holford's recipes which help the liver.
10/post_text/8: Our bodies are phenomenal - but I think of it as a tipping point. Years of not looking after myself too well (stress, not enough exercise, bad diet...) all likely contributed in some way. I for example needed prescription hay fever meds too for the first time in the year after I first had uveitis - now, I'm in a much stronger position (I've not even taken an OTC hay fever med so far this year!)
10/post_text/9: I encourage you to watch Jason Vale's documentary
10/post_text/11: if you haven't already... it was very odd to see Humira as one of the drugs in the documentary when it lives in my fridge too! Eye opening.
10/post_text/12: The leaky gut theory has been touched on already - but this is important, and there is more and more research now coming out about it (ultimately there is so much that medicine is still learning about!) I found the work of Dr Natasha Campbell-McBride very interesting - especially after hearing the difference diet made in a colleague's autistic daughter. So I actively work on continually doing things to heal my gut and keep it healthy and happy (bearing in mind that the drugs likely upset the balance a little) - good quality probiotics, prebiotic foods, kefir...
10/post_text/13: I'll have to admit that I don't watch my diet as much on Humira as I used to - but when I do, I feel better overall. The holistic approach makes the most sense to me - I absolutely needed the drugs, BUT I want to support that with a lifestyle. Sadly we don't (yet?) get any of this info from the doctors as a rule, they're just not trained enough in that area. I have also recently started taking turmeric supplements - after reading that it's thought to block the production of TNF-alpha... the very action that Humira is after as an anti-TNF... Fresh turmeric would likely be best, but this is easier and a lot more palatable to me.
10/post_text/14: There is a LOT of info here - sorry! This has been a journey over many many years, and I keep refining my thoughts (and struggling with putting it into practice ;) ) Baby steps is the way to go though, I'd always now recommend vitamin D and probiotics to everyone (with or without uveitis!) - and watch documentaries if you can!
10/post_text/16: is another really good resource with documentaries and information - I don't necessarily agree with everything on there, but some things just make sense to me and I'm willing to give them a go, especially if I here the same info from multiple sources.
11/post_text/3: Totally belive in leaky gut - just need to muster the courage to start the diet.  Anyone with any experience on this too?

1/post_text/1: Welcome to the forum.
1/post_text/2: Nicki gave you good advice about getting the dose of methotrexate raised. Your nervousness about Humira is shared by other parents here and I expect several will be along soon to share their thoughts with you.
1/post_text/3: In one way you are lucky to be offered a place in this trial because the likelihood is that if Helena receives the Humira, her uveitis will be controlled and you could get her off those drops, sagfeguarding her eyes from the side effects of steroid. However, other immunosuppressants agents can do the same job and the potential side effects of those may be more palatable than those listed for Humira. Equally, the monitoring for side effects for those on the Humira trial is stringent and the drug would be withdrawn at the first sign of a problem.
1/post_text/4: You can read about the other drugs in our treatment section and perhaps this might give you a clearer idea about alternatives to Humira and what you feel most comfortable about where Helena is concerned.

4/post_text/0: Hi Jacqui,
4/post_text/1: You're not being at all "dizzy".  You're absolutely right: 2 out of 3 children will be receiving humira and mtx, and 1 in 3 children will just be receiving the mtx and the placebo not the humira.
4/post_text/2: Every clinical trial involves a random proportion of people receiving the 'real' drug and the others a dummy drug.  It's the only way they can impartially assess the effectiveness and safety of a drug.  It's also a well known scientific fact that if people are given a drug and told it might cause eg their skin to turn purple (!) psychologically a proportion of people will actually think that their skin is turning purple even if that is impossible!  The mind is a powerful thing.
4/post_text/3: I'm pleased that you feel a bit more prepared having read up on the subject of potential treatments, this is going to become a bad cliche of a mantra but knowledge really is power!
5/post_text/0: Hi Jacqui, welcome to Olivia's Vision. My son is also just six and has been treated for JIA and Uveitis for only 6 months. He has been fast-tracked to the most aggressive treatments possible due to a very late diagnosis. He is on Methotrexate 20mg injection, predforte eye drops, atropine eye drops, and Humira 40mg injections. I would say that as far as what your child is taking, that is a very small dose! I did struggle with the decision to start Humira because of the potential risks. We played with the Methotrexate and predforte dose some before I decided enough was enough. A risk with JIA is kidney failure so the rheumy feared we would be heading down that road very soon if we didn't step up to Humira. That was the decision-maker for us was not only the threat to vision, but also other organs.

6/post_text/0: Thank you for sharing your story! I needed to read of your accomplishments, despite what you have been through, in order to gain some perspective of what my son's future may hold. He recently had bilat lensectomies with artificial lens implantations. I was told once the cataracts were gone and he had time to heal, we shouldn't have to worry about his eyes becoming inflammed again. Surprise! Today the inflammation is back, despite continuous aggressive drugs, and his eye pressures are 29/37. He has been an emotional mess since the start of all of this, but I would like to tell him about what you have been able to do so that he can feel like he still has a future.

8/post_text/1: I understand what you mean about having trouble looking directly at people while conversing, and you miss something when that happens, in your interactions.  Facial expression and understanding the nuances of body language mean a lot, not just words being said.   I was so near-sighted and shy about that when I was younger, I never knew what that cost me in self- confidence for years.  However, since getting contact lenses in my teens brought me ut of that shyness, I really knew what I had lost when my eye became deformed after losing vision.
8/post_text/2: I am a physician, and need to look at my patients, and not have them be distracted by worrying about me, my appearance.   So having a patch (annoying, uncomfortable, needed with the glasses I need to use for my right eye now) wasn't a good option, nor the shrunken eye whith zero pressure that would visibly deform as the day went by.  I could barely look at myself in the mirror, let alone ask my contacts to do so.
8/post_text/3: I WAS very lucky my ocularist was artistic, and knew how to make the prosthetic look good.  I know some are not as expert as he is, as have been told this.  The first day I met Dave, I was fortunate to be invited to meet another of his clients, ayoung college student who was seeing him for cleaning and inspection of the prosthetic.  She looked great!   I also met some others of hi clients later on, and felt their cosmetic appearance was just fine.  Yes, I could tell the prosthetics from the normal eyes, due to lack of pupil dilation, and subtle differences of eye movement.   Also, in my case, I had some minor strabismus ( inturning) of the eye and this was not corected by the surgery, though perhaps it could have been... In any case a lot of people have NO idea, unless I tell them, that this is aprosthetic eye.

7/post_text/2: My main question about the prosthetic eye was it's appearance and does it look natural.
7/post_text/3: The main reason i am thinking about this option is because i just want my eye to look normal because my eyes look so different and i find it hard to make eye contact with people because of it.
7/post_text/4: I have seen a few prosthetic eyes which quite honestly do not look good at all and it looks quite obvious that the eye isn't real and i don't see the point in having that.
7/post_text/5: I was also offered the shield, which i had made and fitted for me, but my eye pressure was too low and i could only ware it for 20mins because it started to become painful
8/post_text/4: The surgery one gets these days atempts to preserve the extraocular muscles that move the eye around, as they are anchored to an implant that is placed beneath the mucous membranes of the eye, if you get a complete enucleation.  A shield holds everthing snug for a while, then when stitches come out, you are left to heal a few weeks longer, letting swelling go down, etc.  I had been on prednisone for that time, and had swellimg of tissues that changed the prosthetic fit after I stopped steroids. sometime later on.  I was refitted with a new and larger prosthetic.  Because tis is a bit heavier, it has gradually stretched my lower lid and socket tissues have settled a bit more, so think I will now need a minor procedure to snug up the lid a bit, and think it will improve the appearance more---I hope insurance will pay for this!  I have some allergies making me have sticky lids right now, and wake with a sense of the lids sticking to the prosthetic surface, drying partly open while sleeping, and have to squirt in saline to "unglue"my lids in the morning.   I hope the oculoplastic surgeon can remedy this soon!

0/post_text/12: - Laser Surgery when i was 9/10 In both of my eyes
0/post_text/13: - Steroid Injection in my right eye when i was 14
0/post_text/14: - Vitrectomy in my right eye when I was 16, which eventually led me to go blind in my right eye
0/post_text/15: - Cataract Surgery on my left eye when i was 24
0/post_text/16: I have managed to cope very well only having 1 eye for the majority of my life. I got through Primary and Secondary school fine without any help.
0/post_text/17: Until i got to my GCSE where i needed a little bit of help because of the Cataract that was growing in my left eye and it was getting harder and
0/post_text/18: harder for me to read my school work.
0/post_text/19: When i left Secondary school i went to College and i needed a lot more help there with a Assistant next to me in every lesson to help me read my work.
0/post_text/20: This was around the Time i first started seeing Dr A (edited), i was 17. Dr. A (edited) first goal was to get me off of all types of Steroid treatment because it was causing the Cataract to grow in my left eye ( my only seeing eye ) as my vision was slowly getting worse And secondly was to get me through my education.
0/post_text/21: i Started off on Methotrexate and Cyclosporine, but i had problems taking to the drugs, they made me feel very sick. Currently i am on, Microphenolate and Infliximab infusions which have been working very well and i have kept my eyes very stable. Without the use of any steroid treatment.
0/post_text/22: It was a long hard road getting through college, my life changed alot. I used to be a very Sporty person, playing football all the time when i was younger, but i had to stop when i was around 17 due to the fact i couldn't see very well and that was quite hard to deal with for me.
0/post_text/23: We knew i had to have Cataract Surgery soon because of my vision slowly getting worse, so the goal was to get my eye in the best possible condition before the surgery (Something that it wasn't when i had my first Cataract surgery on my right eye)
0/post_text/24: Last year January, I had my Cataract Surgery in my left eye, it was a very hard decision to go ahead with the surgery because my left eye was my only seeing eye, and we didn’t know how the eye would react to the surgery, so it was very nerve racking.
0/post_text/25: I am happy to say the Surgery went very well with no complications and i currently have a lens implant in my left eye.
0/post_text/26: For the last year we have been traveling back a forth to the hospital to keep a very close eye on how it was healing. Starting off with every week then increasing that time.
0/post_text/27: January just gone, was a year after the operation, and my eye has been Fantastic, it has healed well and my Vision is great!
0/post_text/28: I have Legal driving Vision and have recently passed my driving test!
7/post_text/6: I just want something that make me feel more comfortable and looks natural.
0/post_text/29: It is Amazing to see where i am now to where i was 2/3 years ago, i Never thought i would be able to drive a car in my life or play football again.
0/post_text/30: Dr A (edited) has done an amazing job, and i owe alot to him for his patients and hard work.

7/post_text/10: Thanks for your comments. I know it can be difficult sometimes and it does get you down. I remember being in the same place before. I have always been like that from a young age.
7/post_text/11: One thing that stands out in my mind the most, is when i used to play football, when i was 14/15 years old. My eyes where quite bad at that time and i was playing a match for the team i played for. 50% of the time i could not even see the ball especially when it went up in the air. But i was so determined to keep playing because i loved playing football and it made me happy.
7/post_text/12: So i do think it's important to try and stay positive not matter how hard things get.
7/post_text/13: My pressures have also been very high at times, I'm not sure if your son is still on and type of steroid, but that can be one of the side effects from that. When ever i go on a high dose of steroid my pressure goes very high too. After My operation last January i was on 60mg and my pressures where in the high 30's. Once they dose came down, it all returned back to normal

1/post_text/1: Try not to panic.
1/post_text/2: Most cases of uveitis are what the medics call 'idiopathic'. Basically this means without known cause.  The belief is that it is an autoimmune response, where the body attacks its own tissue. There are various other autoimmune conditions, and when somebody first has uveitis, the medics like to rule them out.  I'm not going to list every autoimmune conditions here, as the list is long, and the risk is that everybody will google them, and we'll all be convinced we've got symptoms! Most of us never develop any of them.
1/post_text/3: I'm sorry you had to overhear the consultant explaining things to the junior doctors, that shouldn't have happened. Next time you see him, I would tell him what you heard, and ask him for a proper explanation.
1/post_text/4: Take care,
2/post_text/0: Just adding to Ellie's words, I think you have to take this in the same way as the suspected sarcoidosis - your uveitis shows some of the features of uveitis seen in both of these conditions and since they are serious diseases, your consultant wants to rule them out if he can. Where there is even a tiny possibility that the uveitis might be associated with MS, the more powerful treatment options for posterior uveitis are slightly different to those of ideopathic uveitis with some drugs ill advised and others working much better. Perhaps this further testing is another stage in deciding upon treatment as well as giving you good care?
2/post_text/1: I too am sorry that the appointment has increased worry and you're still going through a diagnostic process.

0/post_text/0: Hi all, my 9 year old daughter has been battling with this awful eye condition since it was picked up on a routine eye check at school when she was 5 years old.  For the last 4 1/2 years she has had various drops, methotrexate tablets, methotrexate injections, cellcept, a combination of methotrexate and cellcept, steriod infusions and we are due to have humira delivered tomorrow with the prospect of starting these injections in the next few days alongside methotrexate.  All the drugs we have tried have brought worry, plenty of tears and anxiety, but not like this one.  I am so scared of this drug.  I am trying to remain positive as this might be the one that works but the health implications are so frightening. Our doctors at Bristol are great, but I don't know what is coming next - is it a long term drug? does it control inflammation quickly? what if it doesn't work? What are the common side effects like?
1/post_text/1: Sorry you're having such a tough time getting your daughter's inflammation under control.
1/post_text/2: Humira can take two to three months before it fully controls inflammation - ie no cells. When uveitis is chronic, like the mtx and cellcept, humira is a long term drug. If it doesn't work, you are in the right place to be offered alternative treatment and I'm sure Louise's doctors will tell you what might be used next.
1/post_text/3: If you click the Humira trial link at the top of this page, you'll find information about side effects. Quite a number of mothers have posted their experiences of humira in these forums and if you read through old posts, you'll find lots of advice and tips on how to manage the injections.
1/post_text/4: I hope this is the drug that works for your daughter.
0/post_text/1: Any advice or feedback would be helpful.
0/post_text/2: Thanks
1/post_text/5: Take care,
