0/topic_title: Help please - my wife's condition is getting worse and I dont know how to help
1/post_text/1: This is a horrible position to be in and one several of us have experienced when our treatment did not control the inflammation well enough.
1/post_text/2: If your wife is not being treated in a clinic with a uveitis specialist, then an appointment with a uveitis specialist is going to be helpful. Prof Ayliffe sees people privately at the Lister hospital in London (02077308298)and often you can get an appointment within a week. He will be able to advise you about what's needed long term to control your wife's uveitis and what needs to happen now in order to get your wife's eye(s) in a state fit for surgery.
1/post_text/3: If your wife is being treated in a clinic with a uveitis specialist, it may be time to have a discussion about the long term management of her condition and whether agents other than steroid eye drops have a place in her care.
1/post_text/4: Unfortunately, there is no quick solution to the current problem. Whether your wife stays on steroid drops or her treatment changes, it will take time to bring her inflammation under control and allow surgery to take place.
1/topic_title: Help please - my wife's condition is getting worse and I dont know how to help
0/post_text/1: I'm so pleased to have found a forum which might be able to offer some advice. My wife has had uveitis for almost two years now and has been treated with steroid eye drops. She now has glaucoma and cataracts which have become so severe that her vision is beyond bad. She hasn't been able to drive for 6 months and is at the point where she cannot work anymore (ironically she works for the NHS). She had an appointment for the cataract surgery in June but at a check up yesterday they found that the uveitis had returned and as such the operation cannot go ahead. This sets the clock back and it will be at least 3 months before the surgery would even be considered again.
0/post_text/2: This is having a huge effect on her wellbeing.
1/post_text/5: Having been in a similar position to your wife, my consultant referred me to the vision impairment team from social services in order that I received help for everyday living. There was a wait and by the time of the visit, I'd already discovered how to manage many things - apparently nearly everyone does. If your wife wants to talk to someone who has been through this, just use the helpline number. You're right - it is an utterly miserable and frightening position to be in.

0/post_text/0: Hi,my son is nearly 5 and he has had chronic anterior uveitis since he turned 3. In the last few weeks we have been attending Moorfields childrens hospital for a second oppion.  He has been on steroid eye drops for nearly 2 years and when we first attended Moorfields they took him off the eye drops to establish wether it was acute or chronic uveitis. Very quickly it was established it was chronic as his eyes flared up very quickly.  Since attending Moorfields his eyes sight has deteriorated and now the doctors want to determine wether this is down to his uveitis or needing glasses and they are sending him for a eye test with the optician at the hospital.  My question is can they establish between uveitis damage and generally needing glasses and if the damage is down to uveitis can wearing glasses help him see better?
1/post_text/1: I'm sorry your son's uveitis is chronic.
1/post_text/2: The opthalmologists are able to see structures in the eye which, when damaged, affect eye sight. Sending your son to the optician suggests they haven't seen the signs of damage which would explain the deterioration.
1/post_text/3: When the damage to the eye (and sight) are caused by uveitis, quite a lot of the time it is reversible when treated promptly and the inflammation controlled in such a way that flares stop or reduce significantly.

0/post_text/1: I was diagnosed with acute anterior uveitis in my left eye in 2009, having never had anything other than 20/20 vision! I commenced the usual Pred forte 2 hourly drops and dilating drops twice daily and although stubborn, the episode did settle after a couple of months. Three weeks later my left eye flared but not as badly and I commenced the drops regime once again. A week after my first flare I started having problems with my bowel - passing lightly blood stained mucous - then my joints flared up on the right side of my body, mainly lower back, right knee and pain in my foot. I was given a blood test and told I am HLA B27 + and referred to gastroenterology re bowel and rheumatology re joints.
0/post_text/2: Therein commenced the nightmare I find myself party too as,far from ever getting a definitive diagnosis I feel as though nobody really knows.. Gastro found patches of granular mucosa with loss of vascular patternation on 1st colonoscopy but not enough to be indicative of Crohns. A 2nd colonoscopy, 8 months later found no patches of mucosa but microscopic inflammation, which once again didn't really point to anything!x-rays of my sacriolatic? joints showed no change and nothing suggesting anklosing spondilitis and a repeat 12 months later confirns no damage.
1/post_text/5: Maxine
0/post_text/3: In the first year I had 7 flares of uveitis with intermittent joint pain and bowel problems. The only thing that helped was a systemic injection of Depo Medrol which made me feel like a new woman. A second steroid injection didn't make me feel better but did make me feel like I was losing my mind with mood swings. This year I have had only 4 flares of uveitis and minimal joint and bowel involvement and my wonderful Rheumatologist decided to try me on methotrexate tablets. These made me feel incredibly sick and gave me a terrible upset stomach. I stopped taking this after two doses as I decided the benefit has to outweigh the side effects and this didn't. Ten months later and my rheumy decided that injecting methotrexate might avoid the gastrointestinal side effects and whoa what a difference. I injected it and felt fine for three days and then felt as though I was losing my mind and spent 5 days crying uncontrollably for no apparent reason. This was interspersed with volcanic anger which I just cope with. I now find myself wondering what next? I was told I probably have seronegative arthritis but that isn't definitive as a diagnosis. I can't take methotrexate and steroids terrify me when they are systemic, yet my eyes continue to flare. I don't want to return to the eye clinic as the consultant there is absolutely awful and I don't see my rheumy 'til January. I recent;y had an eye test and now need glasses for long and short distance but the vision in my right eye has changed already and I feel as though I'm not focussing properly
0/post_text/4: I am going to try a low starch diet and see if this helps and hope that my low mood is just a passing symptom of frustration at the round-a-bout I can't get off

3/post_text/1: My son was diagnosed with uveitis and I still feel like I have been hit by a freight train. 3/post_text/2: Not that this is much consolation but I can sympathise about the driving. I am having eye trouble of my own, 38 and keep experiencing posterior vitreous detachment which cause my eye to haemorrhage.  Normally vitreous detachments happen to people in their 50s or 60s as part of the normal ageing processes. Couldn't see 4 fingers in front of my nose, but the blood has slowly cleared. The trouble is that it has happened 3 times since November so I too, need a couple of blood tests. Me and my son are on first name basis with the nurses at our local eye casualty. The retinal surgeon who saw me told me it was going to be a bumpy journey. Think that can be said for uveitis. But don't loose heart yet. First line of defence treat, then try and find a cause if one can be found. If the uveitis keeps returning start looking at the treatment section of this site. With the right treatment, uveitis can be silenced with no long term damage. Also, as you know, it might clear up and fingers crossed stay away for another 9 years.

13/post_text/1: The use of dilating drops depends on the inflammation, so no set time scale.
13/post_text/2: Which dilating drop are you using? They come in different strengths and if you're on atropine, that does make life very difficult. I was on Mydrilate, a weaker drop, for ages because my uveitis was chronic. Using it three times a day meant sight was more or less blurred constantly, but when it was reduced to twice a day, I was able to time the drops so my sight was good for most of the day. Once my inflammation was controlled, the dilating drops were stopped.
13/post_text/3: I hope your next appointment shows the inflammation reducing. It's tough having to do the drops every hour but it's far better to treat aggressively initially than to ease off too quickly.
13/post_text/4: Hope the new lenses in your sunglasses help. I had polaroid transition lenses put in mine which transitioned down from very dark to slightly dark rather than clear indoors. They were brilliant in the artificial lighting found in supermarkets!

0/post_text/1: I was diagnosed with a rare syndrome called TINU (Tubulointerstitial Nephritis and Uveitis Syndrome).  I had my first flare last July, which was picked up by an optician.  I was referred to the Eye Pavillion in Edinburgh and treated with dilating drops and Maxidex.  I went on holiday and tapered the drops as advised.  On my first day home, it flared again.  I was again referred and the opthamologist was concerned that there was evidence of optic nerve swelling, so took bloods and referred me for an MRI the next day.
0/post_text/2: When I got to the hospital, a nurse came to ask if there was any reason my kidney function would be dropping.  I said no.  I was admitted and given what felt like every test under the sun (x-rays, MRI, CT scan, ultra sounds, lumbar puncture, kidney biopsy, blood tests and urine tests etc).  By the time they had decided on a diagnosis of TINU, my kidney function had dropped to 20%!

1/post_text/0: Hi, Bristol has a good uveitis centre and there is one uveitis specialist there who forum members highly recommend - I can't remember his name but you can search around and try to have an appointment with him.
1/post_text/1: I'm on immunosurpressant too and it did cause some side effects, including musle pain, chill, high ALT (still waiting my doctor's advice on this). But as many have pointed out, immunosurpressant when controlled well can be effective without long term effect. The alternative - steroid (pred forte) - looks effective in short term but will be damaging in long term use (and there is danger that those damages can't be reversed). There are also newer treatments in trial such as tnf but they are very, very expensive and not much chance of getting funding from nhs.
1/post_text/2: If you want to get a second opinion on private route, Prof. William Ayliffe (my doctor) is very good.
1/post_text/3: Wish you all the best.

6/post_text/1: My daughter has juvenile arthritis related anterior uveitis. We manage it with an anti-inflammatory diet and give her turmeric and eye supplements and also herbal remedies. She has never taken steroid eye drops. Or.methotrexate.  Now,the truth is that we can never know if Molly has.been lucky or the diet worked but I believe it has helped. My background is in clinical psychology so I read journal articles to inform our approach. Molly has had uveitis once when she was 3 after which we began the diet. She had 3 years remission. She now has had it off and on since July at age 6 but never more than level 1+. The BEH is fully aware of our dietary approach and supporting us to minimise the medicines which I view as last resort rather than first resort.

0/post_text/1: The first flare was quite scary as my eye became very red, my vision blurred and the eye very sensitive to bright light. A visit to the Bristol Eye Hospital A&E sorted the problem and I left with pred forte drops to administer to the eye at regular intervals, tapering off to nothing after 6 weeks. Familiar story so far I would imagine, unfortunately the uveitis returned frequently, resulting in more visits and more drops. I came off pred forte as it was increasing the pressure in the eye so I then took maxidex hoping to not elevate the pressure, this worked for a while but now when taking maxidex I have to supplement it with a pressure reducing drop as well.
0/post_text/2: After multiple episodes I decided with the help of the Bristol Eye Hospital to try Methotrexate to suppress the immune system. I started on a small dose and came off the steroid drop but the uveitis came back, the dose of methotrexate was increased several times and I stopped taking the steroid drop once the course had finished after having to resume the steroid drop regeme each time. Unfortunately when the oral dosage reached 17.5 mg was still not effective and the uveitis came back. At this point it was suggested to up the dosage to 25 mg via an injection. After all this time and my faith that this drug would be the answer to my problem my liver ALT value has risen sharply which means I have to come off this drug until the liver is happy again.

5/post_text/1: Things have progressed since my last post, the MTX has not been successful as it caused problems to the liver high ALT. I'm now taking cellcept 1g twice a day, but still on a steroid drop every other day. Hoping to come off the steroid soon and see if the cellcept will control it on its on.

4/post_text/1: Personally I'm thrilled that you put your foot down and made a fuss.  I think the problem with many secretaries is that they work in an environment where so many people are ill that they become immune to a parent or patient's panic.  I think they need reminding at times that they are dealing with people with potentially serious conditions who need a sympathetic ear and some action!
4/post_text/2: At present there aren't any drugs specifically licensed for uveitis.  All the drugs uveitis sufferers are prescribed are done so "off label".  Approximately half of sufferers will never find out what is causing the uveitis - it is said to be idiopathic.  The treatment a sufferer gets can depend on whether a systemic disease is causing the uveitis, but methotrexate is one of those drugs that can be made available to any chronic uveitis sufferer regardless of what is or isn't causing the uveitis.
4/post_text/3: You do not have to receive a JIA, or as an adult an RA diagnosis, to be prescribed methotrexate.

1/post_text/5: His eye pressure might have gone up slightly due to the steroid drops and reducing them might help bring the pressure down. 1/post_text/6: If Owen has had the synechiae for a long term then it's unlikely that the dilating drops would be able to break up the adhesions, but it's one of those thing that's always worth trying as there is a chance it could work.
1/post_text/7: On a positive note his uveitis hasn't worsened and the clinic is already considering what the next step of treatment might be, so they're on the case and not taking a wait and see approach.  It's quite normal for the rheumatology department to be the one that prescribes drugs such as methotrexate for uveitis, as they use it regularly for kids with JIA.
1/post_text/8: It's quite likely that rheumatology will order tests and remember they can get the results back within 24 hours if need be. Thankfully you've not got too much longer to wait, although I know that time drags terribly waiting for these appointments.

1/post_text/9: Owen is still young enough to take all the hospital visits and drops ... in his stride, and you're obviously doing a brilliant job of keeping calm in front of him so that he feels no reason to be worried - this is thanks to you and how you're handling the situation. 4/post_text/4: Blood tests are understandably scary for children, but unfortunately they have to get used to it.  Olivia has blood tests every 4 weeks and has had since she started methotrexate/ciclosporin/tacrolimus 14 months ago.  Every child on such drugs will receive similar monitoring.
4/post_text/5: All Olivia's blood tests are done by her amazing GP as she is the only person she trusts.  The key is finding someone incredibly patient who has lots of experience with kids who has been warned in advance that your child is going to freak out big time.  For some kids numbing cream such as Emla works.  For other it's a local anaesthetic spray, or just a bog standard freeze spray.
4/post_text/6: I know some Mums who have had their blood taken first to show the child it really is ok, and others unfortunately who have to restrain their child.  The sad reality is that for all of them it becomes a form of normality because it has to be done so often.
4/post_text/7: It's rotten for the child but sometimes even more rotten for the parents. One of the hardest parts of having a child with any disease is acceptance.  Acceptance that they've got it, acceptance that you're going to have to make some tough decisions, and acceptance that you're doing the right thing.

0/post_text/0: Hello there! My name is Tom. I am 10 years old. I suffer from a condition called Paediatric Uveitis. Before I tell you about my experience, I wanted to tell you what the condition is. Uveitis casues inflamation in the joints causing your eyes to go bloodshot. So, here is my experience.
0/post_text/1: This all started on my birthday, I went out for dinner and my mum noticed my eyes were bloodshot. So, she took me to my GP and she said that I just had conjunctiveits, an so did another GP. However, one GP diagnosed me with Paediatric Uveitis. My mum took me to hospital and the doctors ran a few tests. Then, I was sent up to Opthlamology and met a very nice eye specialist. Ever since I was diagnosed, I've had bloods taken, measured, eyes measured vice versa. However, in some cases, this condition isn't all that bad. On the 22nd December 2016, I went to Bristol to check out my eyes in CTO. I also had my BP done.
0/post_text/2: That's pretty much my story so far. A few tips for anyone having Uveitis. 1. Don't stress about this condition, it is temporary and not very serious. 2. If gets worse, see a Consultant in Opthlamology immediately. And 3. Ask your doctor if there is any treatment. For example, I'm on both eyes dexemethasone on alternate days and 12.5 mg of methatrexate every Tuesday. I want to be a Doctor when I'm older, I want to aim in my early years for Speciality Registrar, emergency medicene (A&E) so I won't be dealing with all this. However, I sure am learning a lot. Thank you so much for listening.
0/post_text/3: Tom :)

3/post_text/1: Riley has the meto jet pens too. From what I can gather HUMIRA is very effective but not an easy injection for already terrified kids and the 'possible' side effects are stomach churning. Nobody likes to read that there have been a few cases of an extremely rare, very different to treat lymphomas in teenagers who have used biologics. I have also read another paper that says there is no increased risk. That is the problem, we don't know other contributing factors. Drug companies have to label absolutely every possibility.... I know all this but and very worried for my baby. Terrified of him losing more sight and terrified of cancer but I do know him losing more sight is guaranteed, other side effects listed must be extremely, extremely rare or doctors just wouldn't be allowed to prescribe it. My own GP said that they (I assume other people at the practice who use it) have found it very effective. I have to say we have had great support at Bristol with regards to help control the uveitis, advice on using meto jet pen and access to phycologist.
3/post_text/2: But I do whole heartedly believe the benefits outweigh the risks. But am arranging to meet an opthalomogist privately without Riley so that I can ask lots of questions and process answers outside the usual hectic hospital environment - so I have time to process information and think of all those questions I forgot to ask. I not sure how much Riley listens but don't like asking all sorts of difficult questions about risks, side effects, success rates etc, etc with his big ears flapping... And I just don't know how reliable the stuff I read is.

0/topic_title: Advice on eye pressure problems re uveitis ?
1/post_text/1: Rising eye pressure alongside uveitis is scary.
1/post_text/2: It can occur independently of uveitis in the same way this happens in the general population, it can be caused as a result of inflammation and it can be caused as a side effect of steroid treatment. Asking your doctor tomorrow which applies to you will help your understanding of what to expect.
1/post_text/3: In many cases, the pressure will be lowered through the use of glaucoma drops and/or glaucoma pills. When the rise in pressure has been caused by steroid, if steroid is still needed for inflammation, some doctors will eventually suggest glaucoma surgery so that it's safe, pressure wise, to continue using steroid, others will try to balance the use of steroid with the pressure lowering therapy. The alternative to these is to be on effective systemic immunosuppressant therapy without steroid (or with very low dose steroid) to control inflammation.
1/post_text/4: I hope you are told that your eye pressure has reduced tomorrow and your doctor has a plan for moving forward.

4/post_text/0: Hi Maxine happy new year and thanks for your reply. The trabeculectomy surgery went really well thanks and after lots of follow up visits to the hospital to check the eye pressures, the pressures have now come down from the high 40's in both eyes pre-op to 15 in the operated eye and mid 20s in the other eye nearly 4 weeks post op. I got some fluid coming in behind my retina in the operated eye but there was no detachment of  the macula thank goodness and now the vision is slowly coming back to pre-op level. The vision is very foggy so I'm assuming its just the eye settling /something to do with the retinal fluid and /or the Maxidex drops that I'm putting in every 2 hours. I went to the hospital a few days ago and I do not have to go back for a whole month so after virtually living there over the past few weeks( or it feels like it anyway !) its a huge relief to have a break ! Im hoping this means that things are back on track and that the serous retinal detachments can now continue to resolve.  I also had cataract surgery in both eyes last year - so here's hoping this eye pressure stuff is the last of the uveitis complications, fingers crossed.As ever the medics have been brilliant and Im feeling so much more positive than a couple of months ago.

11/post_text/1: I was just having a look at the forum for the first time in ages yesterday and saw your post about your cataracts and I can really understand all your worries and concerns and I hope you are managing to cope okay given the circumstances. I ended up turning up one weekend at the hospital i was being treated at, and saying that I could not cope with the cataracts anymore and then it was all action stations. My consultant was very understanding.  I developed cataracts really quickly during the first 6 months of 2012. My hospital did cataract surgery on one eye in The May of 2012 and then in the other eye two month later. Although i was scared when the day of the op came i was so relieved as I could no longer see peoples faces etc and it was straightforward. I remember looking out of the hosp ward window the day after the op and marvelling how i could see cars going by and even though my vision was still blurry all i could see before that was a really horrible  fuzzy outline of houses and trees ie i could barely see anything.  Following the cataract operation, I noticed a gradual improvement in vision over a period of a couple of months . I also went onto the oral steroids and immunosuppression at that point (The immuno medication was Cyclosporin). I was wary of taking medication but I think it prevented further vision loss and my oral steroids have been tapered down to 15mg a day so i am now losing my 'moonface'look !. I do have macular odema in one eye which came on in August 2012 . i am not sure whether this was a result of cataract surgery though. I may get some steroid injections for that but i am a steroid responder so hosp are being cautious for now. Following the surgery from memory I was putting in Maxidex drops every couple of hours at first then 4 times a day. The eye pressure seems to be sorting itself out although goes up and down still but is more stable. Is your hospital managing your eye pressure entirely thrnough drops ? Have they talked to you about the inflammation and when the time mught be right for cataract surgery ? Sorry for the long email and hope this helps x

Also was on Cyclosporin but ended up in hosptial as didnt agree with me so am on mxt and 60mg of predisnolone and maxidex x6 a day since 5 days but not happy about it as am sure it makes cataract worse by the day.  Have lots of fluid at the back of eye but have Moorfields tomorrow so am going to ask lots of questions.  I was due for op in March for cataract but only if it had been quiet but it never is.  I am hoping the immunosuppresant kick in and then maybe it will be quiet enough for op.  I was hoping that I would be able to not keep taking oral steroids too (they keep me up all night) but I see you  on 15mg, will you get off them? 0/post_text/1: Sam our son was diagnosed with chronic uveitis in 2002,he was5 yrs old.He had an eye test at school which he said he couldnt see any of the letters when one eye was shut.I just thought he was messing about and really dismissed it until the school nurse rang me to confirm he appeared that he couldnr see in one eye.
0/post_text/2: we were totally in shock and had to wait for a hospital appointment.we knew it was serious when the opthalmic paediatrician rang me at work 3 weeks later and asked me to bring sam straight to the hospital as his notes had just landed on his desk.It was urgent.it was some time before uveitis was diagnosed.  Many operations, examinations under anaesthetic, two retinal re-attachments a visit to Moorfields and many many anxious months later we discovered the disease had flared in sams right eye too.His retina was lifting and needed laser surgery and steroid treatment to save his sight.We were told it was uveitis.His left eye already blind even before diagnosis.He endured cataract surgery  and had many flare ups and surgical procedures when his retins detached on 3 seperate occaions We were devestated and knew Sam hada fight on his hands and so did we!!There is so much I could write in between these lines of heartache and joy. However the best news I can give you all is that in 2007 Sam went into remisission, his right eye was 'quiet' and the battle for now was won.He caught up at school, did well in his SATS and is currently in yr 9 at secondary school. we still have regular check ups and the fantastic optholmologists at Sunderland eye infirmary have worked so hard and been so kind, we owe them sams sight and we have nothing but admiriation for them.We  know that Uveitis does not disappear but can stay in remission , we hope and pray that Sam's right eye will remain healthy and that he reaches adult hood with no further hick ups.He is an absolute star and we are very very proud of him.

0/post_text/0: My daughter was diagnosed with Uveitis 3 yrs ago and this year cold urticaria. she seems to have a attack in the early spring and late fall every year.  She is having one now and is completely depressed she is 17 yrs old and is missing school for complaining of bulging eyes, blurry vision and her eyes are bloodshot the doctor we saw is saying the eyes are quite but she is still having symptoms.  Crying because she can't understand how she can feel this and they say there is nothing there.  I have found a doctor that is a occular immune specialist and am hoping tomorrow to get an appt. had more blood drawn on Friday and have not got back the results.  Not sure what I can do for her in the meantime. The regular eye doctor gave her some allergy drops but they are doing nothing the veins in her eyes have not changed and she feels the same. I am so frustrated and sad not knowing what to do to help her. I am giving her advil for the headaches and she is using a warm moist eye pad.  she does not want to leave the dark room and says she feels pressure when her eyes are open.  Any one have any words of wisdom for me?
1/post_text/1: If there are no cells and it's allergy, maybe it takes a bit of time for the allergy drops to work. Some people can tell when their eyes are flaring a day or two before an ophthalmologist can see cells in their eyes so if the allergy drops are not providing relief, I'd go back. Better safe than sorry and there might even be an alternative allergy drop which could work better.
1/post_text/2: Glad you are arranging an appointment with a uveitis specialist. A few years ago a lady was in touch with us about her husband and teen aged daughter who both suffered from recurrent anterior uveitis. A rheumatologist who worked with a uveitis specialist in the same hospital finally diagnosed both with a very rare autoimmune disease which affects the skin and eyes - urticaria in response to the cold is one of the symptoms. While it's very very rare, it might be worth asking the specialist if it's worth investigating a connection between your daughter's urticaria and uveitis.
1/post_text/3: I hope this discomfort is allergy and the allergy drops have started to help now.
1/post_text/4: Maxine

7/post_text/1: My daughter was diagnosed with Posterior and Anterior Uveitis in Sept 2010.  She was given steroid injections and Pred forte plus various other eye drops/creams at a local hospital.  She was referred to Manchester Childrens Hospital and then Mcr Eye Hospital and had lots of test, no reason found for the Uveitis so its idiopathic.
7/post_text/2: In May 2011 she was put on Methotrexate which she remained on until the end of October 2011 but it didn't change anything and only made her feel very well.  She started off with 17.5 mg once a week which was then brought down to 15 mg and 12.5 mg as she was not tolerating it very well.
7/post_text/3: In January 2012 she was put on Cellcept as the cells were increasing in both eyes.  However, that isn't working either and she has had ulcers for some time on and off but had a lot when she went on a college trip.  She stopping taking Cellcept at the end of April 2012.   Her dose of cellcept was 500mg twice daily at first and then 750 mg twice a day.  Again Cellcept was not making any difference.
7/post_text/4: She has not taken any other drugs when she was on Methotrexate or Cellcept, only the eye drops.
7/post_text/5: Since diagnosis she has administered Pred forte eye drops every day, she is currently on 6 drops per day.  At some points throughout the 20 months she has been on maxitrol as well.
9/post_text/1: Whenever I see MTX mentioned as well as mouth ulcers I just have to ask about/mention folic acid! Folic acid is normally given alongside MTX to counteract some of the side effects (it must not however be taken on the same day as MTX) - I know I had a spate of terrible mouth ulcers a few years ago on MTX to the point of almost not being able to talk. Temporarily doubling my folic acid dose sorted that problem out for me - even this week I was able to stop an ulcer developing further by taking another folic acid tablet.
9/post_text/2: A friend of mine has also anecdotally mentioned that her son (not on any immunosuppressants) gets mouth ulcers too - unless they eat melon! Given this glorious weather it may be worth trying that to see if it improves her symptoms at all!
9/post_text/3: Sorry to hear your daughter is having such a struggle finding what works for her - I hope that changes soon and also wish her best of luck for her exams.
6/post_text/6: What type of uveitis does she have?
6/post_text/7: Has she tried Cellcept, Mtx alone and with Cicosporin or Tacrolimus, Humira, Remicade?
7/post_text/6: The Consultant said he is wondering whether she may have Behcets because of the ulcers and will next be seen on 1st June to discuss what symptoms she has had in the meantime and to decide what to do next. It may not be though, She has not taken any immune suppressant medication since the end of April 2012.  She has not had any actual vision problems other than when she administered eye drops which made her eyes blurry.
6/post_text/8: With the right drug and the right dose most cases of uveitis can be put into drug induced remission.
7/post_text/7: So thats where we are at the moment.  I am expecting that she will be put on something else as a result of the next visit.

0/post_text/0: Hey I’m not very good at telling quick stories but here goes. At the beginning of December 2018 I noticed I had completely blurred vision in my left eye and it flashed all the time even when I shut my eyes so the next day I went to my optician who after lots of tests referred me to the hospital ophthalmologist that day. After examining me he felt I’d had some kind of brain haemorrhage or stroke as I have a pre-existing life limiting neurological condition which causes haemorrhage but I didn’t have any headache or any of my normal symptoms. After a CT scan done a week later it was decided to do an MRI. I knew my sight was getting worse but didn’t know what to do, I went back to my optician after Christmas and he referred me back to the hospital the next day so I saw another ophthalmologist and after all sorts of tests, scans and bloods he told me I have intermediate uveitis and gave me 40mg of prednisone to start immediately. That was on the 28th December I’ve been taking the steroids everyday and I’ve been attending the hospital outpatients clinic weekly I’ve had an MRI, a chest x-ray an eye angiogram and weekly scans of the retina so I’ve to cut the prednisone down to 30mgs next week but I haven’t noticed any difference in my blurred vision and it flashes all the time. Will I get my sight back will the flashing stop and also the ophthalmologist is referring me to a uveitis specialist at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Glasgow does anyone have any experience of the clinic? What can I do to make this better I feel like I’m going crazy and nobody understands because to look at me I look just the same, please help. Thank you.

0/post_text/1: Hello,
0/post_text/2: My daughter, who is also named Olivia, was dxed with pauciarticular JIA at 16 months. Her joints were txed with cortisone injections at 20 months and have remained "quiet" ever since. She was dxed with uveitis at 23 months and was treated with Predforte drops for one year until she developped glaucoma-2ry to the chronic use of cortisone drops. Ever since she's been treated with MTX and off and on Predforte. She has also been on glaucoma drops for the last 2 years. My beautiful daughter is now 6 and we discovered last Wednesday that the inflammation in her right eye was at +2 and the pressure in her left eye was at 36. Further tests confirmed permanent irreversible damage to the optic nerve in the left eye with peripheral vision loss (tunnel vision). I don't know/understand how we got to this point seeing as she has had follow up visits every week to two weeks for the last 6 months but what's done is done. The dr said surgery to alleviate the pressure is inevitable to prevent further damage and that in order to do the surgery the pressure has to come down. She is now on Maxidex, Predforte, Xalatan, Combigan, Mydriacil, MTX and Diamox and her rheuma wants to start her on Humira. Devastated does not begin to describe how we feel. WHY??? IT'S NOT FAIR!!!How horrific is it to sit there in the dr's office and be told they want your child to start Humira and that the potential side effects include cancer and MS like symptoms? Insanely horrific. I have spent the last 3 days on an emotional roller coaster and a friend suggested I join some blogs. I don't know if this is going to help me or if it helps others to know my situation but at this point it's worth a try. We started her on the Diamox this morning with no adverse side effects thank God and we are still debating whether or not we will go for the Humira. I am terrified of my daughter loosing her sight but I am also terrified of loosing her. I wish it would just all go away.

1/post_text/3: My heart aches for you and the difficult decision you now face.
1/post_text/4: With side effects, the only way forward is to remember they are potential side effects and to ask your doctors for the estimated percentages of children affected by them and after how long they become apparent. Those who treat us are well aware that safer treatments are needed and research is going on into these. One way of looking at humira is seeing it as a way of buying time for your daughter's sight until better, safer treatment becomes available, but there is no guarantee of when this might be.

2/post_text/2: I have an 11yr old daughter who has JIA and uveitis and remember aggonising over the decision to start methotrexate. My daughter also has glaucoma and we had a similar situation a few yrs ago when the pressure in her left eye, shot up towards 50,i noticed that your consultant has said the pressures will have to come down before surgery have you asked what level they need to be at. My daughter was treated at Grt Ormand st hosp and surgery was arranged straight away for a wk or two later i can't remember exactly how long but i know i wasn't told the pressure had to come down and it was pretty quick,this scared the life out of me but she had a goiniotomy which went well but after 3wks the pressure shot up again to 38 so she was taken in for a trabectolectomy which was completely succesful and has kept the pressure at a normal level ever since,this was nearly 4yrs ago.I don't know whether it would be worth you checking with your consultant as to the level they need to be at,whilst i know surgery is very scary the longer the pressure remains high the more permanent damage is caused. I know your question was more about humira and i hope i haven't made your anxiety worse by talking about surgery but thought it might be useful to know it was definately the right thing for my daughter.

5/post_text/0: Hi Eva, I just had a frank conversation with my son's rheumatologist about Humira. I plainly said to him, "I would rather have a blind child than a dead child. Tell me what the chances are" He stated that in his 32years of practice as the only pediatric rheumatologist in this entire state, he had never had a single case of a child getting cancer while on Humira. He further stated that anything that happens to a child during clinical trials of a drug must be reported to the drug agency so anything that any child experiences will show up in the "potential' side effects, even if it only happened to one child. I also asked if the types of cancers that were seen were highly treatable cancers with good success rates or cases with terminal outcomes. He told me that they were reportedly all highly treatable cases. The best thing that I did to wrap my head around such a scary drug was to communicate as much as possible. Hope this helps.... Keep us updated, best wishes.
5/topic_title: Eva's message reposted by OV Child & Humira
0/post_text/1: Hello,
0/post_text/2: My daughter, who is also named Olivia, was dxed with pauciarticular JIA at 16 months. Her joints were txed with cortisone injections at 20 months and have remained "quiet" ever since. She was dxed with uveitis at 23 months and was treated with Predforte drops for one year until she developped glaucoma-2ry to the chronic use of cortisone drops. Ever since she's been treated with MTX and off and on Predforte. She has also been on glaucoma drops for the last 2 years. My beautiful daughter is now 6 and we discovered last Wednesday that the inflammation in her right eye was at +2 and the pressure in her left eye was at 36. Further tests confirmed permanent irreversible damage to the optic nerve in the left eye with peripheral vision loss (tunnel vision). I don't know/understand how we got to this point seeing as she has had follow up visits every week to two weeks for the last 6 months but what's done is done. The dr said surgery to alleviate the pressure is inevitable to prevent further damage and that in order to do the surgery the pressure has to come down. She is now on Maxidex, Predforte, Xalatan, Combigan, Mydriacil, MTX and Diamox and her rheuma wants to start her on Humira. Devastated does not begin to describe how we feel. WHY??? IT'S NOT FAIR!!!How horrific is it to sit there in the dr's office and be told they want your child to start Humira and that the potential side effects include cancer and MS like symptoms? Insanely horrific. I have spent the last 3 days on an emotional roller coaster and a friend suggested I join some blogs. I don't know if this is going to help me or if it helps others to know my situation but at this point it's worth a try. We started her on the Diamox this morning with no adverse side effects thank God and we are still debating whether or not we will go for the Humira. I am terrified of my daughter loosing her sight but I am also terrified of loosing her. I wish it would just all go away.
1/post_text/5: If you are in the UK, there is a study going on into the use of humira in children. If you are part of this study, your daughter will be monitored closely for side effects and you'll have the assurance that the drug would be stopped should there be an indication that all is not going well.
1/post_text/6: Humira works incredibly well at stopping inflammation and getting people off the eye drops which themselves cause damage to sight. It's likely to save the sight in your daughter's right eye.
1/post_text/7: There are other mothers here who are placed in the same position as you with very young children offered, or about to begin, humira. They are better able to respond to you than I can. As an adult, in much the same position as your daughter, I didn't hestitate to start infliximab, a drug similar to humira. My uveitis had already given me periods of blindness and badly affected the quality of my life, so I knew the alternative. For me, the risks were worth it and these past three years, infliximab has given me back my life. I'm just grateful I was offered it.
1/post_text/8: Equally, this past year, OV was invited to visit the Royal National College for the Blind to see how the blind are rehabilitated, educated and trained for employment. The RNC is an incredible place and I know that I would have coped with my period of blindness much better, had I known such high quality help was available.
2/post_text/3: Take care and i wish you all the best,

9/post_text/1: Sorry to hear your stories, but don't worry about the Methotrexate.  My younger son was diagnosed with JIA and uveitis when he was just turned 8.  We went through the emergency IV steroid treatment and all the eye drops you could think of (sometimes to be administered on an hourly basis).  But it was not really controlled until he started the MTX.  We worried about it for ages (and read all the research papers we could find) but chose to go with the injection route rather than orally because of the greater efficacy.  When he was 8 he hated the injections and sometimes it could take a couple of hours to persuade him that it was good for him (especially when he was feeling fine!) but he did not feel well afterwards.  We were given some folate tablets for him to take part-way through the week and he also now takes ondansetron to curb the nausea.  After a couple of years things were looking good and the medication stopped, but 8 months later the uveitis returned.
9/post_text/2: He tried the oral methotrexate after that, but it wasn't very effective, so he chose to go back onto the injections.  There would always be some eye drops from time to time, but the important bit to focus on is preserving the eyesight.
9/post_text/3: Moving on several years later (he is now 19), we found that eventually the MTX was keeping the joints in check, but was no longer effective in stopping the uveitis.  so he is now on Humira too (having been on the trial at Bristol) and is doing all his injections himself.  Taking control of the injections really helped him deal with the pain and he has found his own way to deal with the routine.  Injection day can be moved around so it doesn't interfere with special events etc.
9/post_text/4: We worried about the MTX initially, but it is far better than losing his sight.  As a result of all this - from going to not being able to read the top line of the Snellen Charts - his vision is now far better than mine!
11/post_text/1: I'm new to this board.  My daughter (now age 10) was on MTX for a few months last year. We started with pills and moved to injections.   BMTX didn't work for her,  but it also didn't have any negative side effects.
11/post_text/2: She has now been on Remicade (infliximab) for almost a year with only one recent flare.  Fingers crossed that her eyes have quieted again with the help of Durezol drops and her infusion a week early.   We'll know more next week at the next eye doc appointment.
12/post_text/1: Becca x
11/post_text/3: Beginning MTX felt like a big step and moving to infliximab infusions even bigger.  However,  the chance of side effects beats the reality of blindness every time for me.  Not fun choices and certainly lots of tears shed here, but onward we go!
11/post_text/4: With best wishes to all of you and your little ones,

1/post_text/1: Welcome to the forum.
1/post_text/2: Some people do only ever have one bout of uveitis, but when it occurs with JIA, I suspect only the very, very fortunate get away with one bout. However, if your boy was being treated with mtx for joints, they might have expected that to prevent future flares in the eyes.
1/post_text/3: The fact that he had a flare when mtx was stopped suggests that the mtx was probably keeping his eyes in remission.
1/post_text/4: As far as the school is concerned, I wouldn't say he no longer has uveitis, but would consider saying his uveitis is in drug controlled remission for the time being. If he's old enough to make this sort of decision, what would your boy prefer you to say?
2/post_text/0: Hi Donna,
2/post_text/1: Unfortunately for now there is no cure for uveitis so technically he's in remission albeit drug controlled as Maxine said.  I also wouldn't tell the school for the time being only because it's so hard getting them to work with you at the best of times, if they think his eyes are fine it's all too easy to "forget" his joints are still an issue.
2/post_text/2: Take care

0/post_text/0: Hi, my daughter who is now 8 1/1 was diagnosed with oligoarticular at 2 1/2, she had repeated flare-ups in both knees and ankles so was put on methatrexate (15mg) for 3 years. She was weaned off this last year and she had 6 months in remission.  She had never had uveitis that we knew of as obviously the methatrexate would have kept this at bay.  However, in November 2011 her joints began to flare up for which she had joint injections.  These have worked thus far but she has developed uveitis in January 2012 which has upset us so much.  She is on Prednol but apprarently this was discontinued in October last year temporarily and not due to be reproduced until May this year.  Her doctor tells us nothing and I have just found out although it is improving in her left eye it is persisting in the right eye yet they have reduced the dosage in both eyes.  I am worrying sick, I just wish they put her on MTX again as she had little side effects other than a bit of sickness after the injection.

12/post_text/1: Kimberly:
12/post_text/2: Trough levels are measured in the blood 12 or 24 hours after taking a med to see how much of the drug is still in the system and how much the body has gotten rid of.
12/post_text/3: So on Tac, O's 12 hour trough level must be under 9 to prevent toxicity issues, it usually sits at about 3 because her body fails to absorb the drug (common theme with O which why we have problems finding a med that works) but it went up to 15 - 5x her 'normal' trough level hence the big problems!
12/post_text/4: Anke - so sorry to hear joints giving you trouble again, are you still on Humira alone or is mtx/tac still in the mix?  Has Dr helped? When are you back at Rheumy?

2/post_text/0: Hi Sarah,
2/post_text/1: Assume you have an appointment once your son finishes this course of drops. When you attend, ask if the examination of your son's eye showed features which are suggestive of viral, parasitic or other causes of infectious uveitis if you haven't already done this. (Children can both pick up infectious causes themselves such as the cold sore virus, toxoplasmosis or chickenpox and inherit an infection from their mother while in the womb). If there were features suggestive of an infectious cause, this will explain why the full panel of testing was not carried out. If they saw no clinical features of an infectious cause, then ask for the auto immune marker blood tests and x-rays for TB and joint problems to set your mind at rest.
2/post_text/2: At the moment, technically, your son does not have recurrent or chronic uveitis in his eye. One course of steroid drops has failed and this is not uncommon. Should your son's eye be clear once off the drops and then flares up again a third time within days or weeks, if he were my son, I'd be pushing for referral to specialist care and I'd still be pushing for this if his eye flared again within three to four months.
2/topic_title: Can anyone advise me on how I get my son referred please?

If I catch it early, a few drops will turn it off.

6/post_text/0: Bit confused, Sarah. Was the high ACE score present in October or was it found in a more recent blood test?
6/post_text/1: I think I would be pushing for NHS referral to a specialist centre - Bristol. Your son's uveitis now seems to be chronic, his ACE is raised and he has a rash. Ophthalmology in Bristol is combined with rheumatology so uveitis and underlying conditions are treated together and children are seen by both an ophthalmologist with Fellowship training in uveitis (what your son needs) and a rheumatologist.
6/post_text/2: If a local paediatric rheumatology appointment is offered quickly, keep it, otherwise you'll worry yourself to death waiting for referral to find out what has caused the high ACE. When you're told what's behind it, if it's sarcoidosis as you fear, it's even more reason for your son to be looked after by specialists with years of experience and research behind them.

He was prescribed the usual dilating drops for two weeks and the maxidex which he was weaned off by the end of August. 5 days later the uveitis was back and they have repeated the process again and we are on week 5 of the maxidex.
0/post_text/2: We are based in South Wales and have heard really good things about Dr Catherine Guly in Bristol. However, our GP seems reluctant to refer our son at this stage. We pushed for blood tests to find out if there are any underlying factors that may be causing the uveitis. They carried out the blood tests then couldn't tell us if there are any genetic markers for JIA as it turned out that they were just looking to see if he has any viruses, etc.
2/post_text/3: Nearly all anterior uveitis is treated with steroid drops initially with other agents added for infectious uveitis if necessary, so your son is being treated adequately at the moment. The problem comes if he flares a third time. I would want a specialist involved at that point. Has the eye clinic given any indication of their stance on referral? At the very least, you need to know the point at which they'd make such a referral themselves.
2/post_text/4: Sorry you are having such a frustrating time with this.
3/post_text/1: I hear some doctors say that iritis must be hit hard with a minimum 1 week of hourly drops and I do often hear that iritis comes back because not enough steroid was used. However, a doctor does not initially know how your iritis behaves so trial and error may be needed to figure out optimal dosing. Some people need very few drops even with full blown iritis. For me, I self limit and there is no chronicity. For others, there may be a tendency towards chronicity but the chronicity can be avoided by hitting the iritis hard.
3/post_text/2: I will say that I have learned to manage my iritis with no thanks to my doctor or fellow patients on Internet. You must be proactive.

1/post_text/1: http://oliviasvision.org/what-is-uveitis/complications/cataracts/
1/post_text/2: Your son's consultant is the best person to advise you about how long it's likely to be before your son's sight begins to be affected. Generally, these types of cataracts develop slowly.
1/post_text/3: When googling, the type of cataract you are searching for is a posterior subcapsular cataract. This means the cataract is developing on the back of the lens and scattering the light that enters the eye so that it doesn't fall on the retina the way it should.
1/post_text/4: The most important things to keep in mind are that eyes need to have been inflammation free for three months before surgery so that the risk of post op. complications is reduced. Secondly, you need to keep your son's consultant informed when the cataracts start to affect his vision. The visual acuity check at appointments is often conducted in conditions which enable people to see the best they can and does not always reflect the sight people have in different light conditions when there is a posterior cataract. Keeping the consultant informed of symptoms, helps the consultant to decide when best to schedule surgery.
1/topic_title: Hi my 16 yo has acute uveitis and is developing cataracts - any advice please?
1/post_text/5: Sorry this has happened and given you and your son something else to worry about along with the uveitis. The good thing is that your son's treatment seems to be working and all being well, there shouldn't be a delay in scheduling surgery at the point it's needed.

1/post_text/1: Maxine knows more than me, but I would say the following;
1/post_text/2: 1. Don't think it is guaranteed that you will get AS. But I would ask for a referral to an uveitis specialist. They will know the answers to your questions. However, they probably will not give you a definitive answer on that one. Given that you have had to have a steriod injection I really think you should see a specialist. Don't delay on that one particularly because you are worried, it might help settle some of your very understandable anxieties.
1/post_text/3: You can email OV and they can point you in the right direction with regard to uveitis consultants. You can get a referral direct from your GP. Just be warned don't get lumbered with any old ophthalmologist - not all specialists are made equal. Probably, also shouldn't write this but also do some homework with regard to excess steriod use, as little as 750 drops can contribute the the start of cataracts. Though uncontrolled uveitis can do the same.
1/post_text/4: 2. Do as exactly as the Doctor advises with the eye drops despite what I have written above. The quicker you tapper them, the greater the chance of a flare. However, I know that it is very tough and that sleep deprivation and uveitis would make anyone feel depressed but don't be tempted to take short cuts.

4/post_text/0: Regarding health insurance, my experience is that it isn't much help. And as this is now a pre-existing condition would cost you a fortune if you could even get cover. The scheme that I am in with my work gave a very limited choice of hospitals and consultants. Even getting to see a local Ophthalmology consultant privately in the clinic that he practices from was a load of hassle. And it also transpires that the specialists (
4/post_text/1: http://www.uveitis.org/patients/list-of-specialists/international
4/post_text/2: ) that are closer to me in Birmingham and Bristol all practice exclusively for the NHS. Also remember that some Health Insurance schemes won't cover chronic diseases.
4/post_text/3: My recommendation would be to get an appointment with Ophthalmology consultant and if you're not totally happy with your treatment (validate it against your own research) then ask for a referral (either from your GP or Consultant) to a regional Uveitis specialist. You're a young guy and have the right to get the best possible treatment to preserve your sight.
4/topic_title: Advice for my Acute anterior uveitis AAU
5/post_text/0: Dear Rebecca, Maxine and Pete
5/topic_title: Advice for my Acute anterior uveitis AAU
6/post_text/0: Hi Matt,
6/post_text/1: I can sympathise with how you feel. One of my friends immediately blamed the condition on me "eating too much meat", which hurt me so much I couldn't talk with him for several days.
6/post_text/2: Hope your eye has improved by now. Others have given all the details, so I just want to second the idea of getting an uveitis specialist ASAP. Because uveitis is a rare condition, not many opthmalogists have enough experience and training to deal with it. Therefore, with a good specialist you will have the best chance to: (1) locate the cause; and (2) administer the steroid dosage (which is very important if you are getting several flares per year - you wouldn't want to get steroid - induced problems to add to the list). In my experience the consultant fee is lower than Maxine's estimation, and once the condition settles down you'll only need a check-up once in several months, which is not too scary.
6/post_text/3: Like Pete, I also think Prof. Aliffe is a reliable specialist.
6/post_text/4: I'm not an opthmalogist to advise about this, but perhaps you may try to notice unusual things before a flare? For example in my case, very often eye pressure rises after staying up late (I used to be a night owl). I'm now going to sleep before midnight everyday and seems like my eye pressure is a lot more stable during a flare. Researches haven't found the links between flares and foods or stress yet, but I think if we could see a pattern in our own condition then there is no harm trying.
6/topic_title: Advice for my Acute anterior uveitis AAU
0/post_text/1: I'm 26 and an architect and i have never had any health issues, however, since last year i've had 3 attacks of AAU in my left eye - managed with cyclopentolate and maxidex. The 2nd attack wasn't managed as well as the doctor started me on drops 3 hourly and its flared up till i needed a steroid injection under my eye lid. most recently they put me on hourly drops for a week - as of this week. Few questions:
0/post_text/2: 1) I took a private blood test and i have HLA B27 - is it guaranteed i'll get AS?- i'm really worried about this and wanted to know if i should see a rheumatologist - even though i have no symptoms
1/post_text/5: 3. Doubt very much drinking or smoking have any links with uveitis. Though I do know that smoking can contribute to sight loss, particularly macular degeneration.
1/post_text/6: 4. Don't hope for burn out. Might happen, might not and a lot of damage can be done while waiting for burn out, so again... Get a referral to a specialist.
1/post_text/7: Look on the treatment section of this site. Don't be scared (though I was terrified on my sons behalf), but look so that you can ask your consultant questions with regards to other treatments, like Methotrexate. Please don't worry about that though...  But you need to know about it so that you can have an informed discussion with a consultant.
1/post_text/8: Do you know what I wish I had done in retrospect. I wished I had pushed for immune suppressants sooner for my son. I know that sounds hard hitting and MIGHT well NOT apply to you but I can't tell you how much I wished I had pushed much harder and much faster for MTX for my son. So make sure you know about this stuff early on. If it all clears up great but if it doesn't you are not playing catch up.
3/post_text/1: Becca's given you comprehensive information already, so just adding a bit more sympathy really.
3/post_text/2: The HLA B27 means you have a higher than average chance of developing one of the auto immune conditions associated with it, not that you will develop one. It's worth seeing a rheumatologist should you notice joint pain, bowl changes, or skin problems.
3/post_text/3: People with AK uveitis say that a slow taper off the drops works best, so with you having the HLA B27 even though you haven't got AK, it's best to keep going with the drop every hour for a week. (Specialists keep some of us on drops for 2 weeks for each stage of the taper to reduce the chance of a flare up shortly after the dropping finishes).
5/post_text/1: I never expected responses so quickly and so detailed. Thank you all for the guidance and help :)
0/post_text/3: 2)I've only ever had to do hourly drops for 3-4 days - if i feel the uveitis has cleared after this time is it safe to go to 2 hourly or shall i do a whole week of 1 hourly as advised? - i'm not sleeping well and feel depressed as a result
0/post_text/4: 3) do alcohol or smoking (socially) have any links to uveitis?
0/post_text/5: 4) will i get AAU every year from now or is there a chance it will burn out? I'm worried about this due to my work where my eyes are important
0/post_text/6: 5) whats the best health insurance? or will they not cover me know ive been diagnosed?
3/post_text/4: My specialist says smokers have a harder time with uveitis, so if you can cut out the social smoking, it will help.
3/post_text/5: Steroid drops going into the eye every waking hour might be contributing to your sleeplessness if the steroid is getting into your blood stream. Putting a finger over the tear duct corner of your eye for a couple of minutes after a drop goes in reduces the chance of steroid getting into your system and this might help a bit. Have to say though, that wouldn't have helped me because it was the worry that stopped me sleeping.
3/post_text/6: The frequency of flare ups varies from person to person. If you're getting flare ups several times a year, you should see a specialist to find out if other treatments are more appropriate. Specialist uveitis clinics are generally reserved for those with uveitis in both eyes and those with chronic uveitis in one eye. It's worth seeing a specialist privately if you can't get NHS referral to a specialist clinic - does wonders for peace of mind and learning about the treatment options best suited for you.
5/post_text/2: So glad i found this forum, i was feeling so alone, all my friends and family are so ignorant with the condition, that all they ever say is 'it's about time you should go and get it sorted out' or 'it must be an eye infection just get some drops'
5/post_text/3: thanks again, and i hope with my journey i can help someone else on here also
1/post_text/9: Your uveitis might well clear and it is only in one eye but honestly, it can be persistent but only a specialist will be able to advise you about the specifics of your case. Uveitis is very individual.
4/post_text/4: If you need to see someone privately then you can ask your GP for a copy of your notes then self refer yourself to Professor Ayliffe in London (or another private Uveitis specialist). This link might help you understand how Private and NHS are allowed to work together

1/post_text/2: If you are putting in the Mydrilate twelve hours apart, it possibly means that the pupil is not always dilated since Mydrilate has an effect for four to six hours. Sleeping won't affect how that drop works.
1/post_text/3: Sleeping for a long time all in one go might affect how the Pred drops work, but we really can't advise you on this - only your doctor can. Some people, but not all people, are told to wake themselves up every few hours to put in drops. The number of drops is also monitored incase they cause eye pressure to rise. Doctors probably assume that we're asleep for eight hours when they make the decision about drops and don't tell us to use them during the night.
1/post_text/4: Are you going back to clinic early next week? I would tell the doc how long you are spending asleep just incase it's relevant in your case. If the appointment is more than a week away, it's probably best to ring and ask for advice.

4/post_text/0: Hi Eve,
4/post_text/1: Welcome, and glad the Easter bunny wasn't confused by your visit to the eye hospital - although sorry that you had to go there! Hopefully, the drops will be effective and there will be a big improvement by the time you go back.
4/post_text/2: I have both AS and uveitis, both well controlled at the moment, although in my case the uveitis preceded the back issues by a number of years. I remember being highly confused why the eye hospital was asking about my back when I went to see them about my eye! Turns out that yes, in my case they were connected...
4/post_text/3: It sounds like your rheumatology referral is already in progress, as Maxine has said definitely mention that at your next eye appointment. If any tests are done, try to get hold of a copy of the results yourself to take to the rheumy - at least that way you'll know they've seen it! The investigations that were done after my 3rd uveitis flare were blood tests, including screening for the HLA-B27 marker (which I am +ve for... although it is possible to be -ve and still have AS, although harder to diagnose - and being HLA-B27+ is only one of the factors of the AS diagnosis, on it's own it means nothing!). I think they also checked for rheumatoid factor and inflammation markers for completeness, but HLA-B27 was the most useful there. X-rays were also done of my sacroiliac joint and chest. The problem with x-rays is that they may not show anything, as it can take years for radiographic changes to show up, even if inflammation is present - once I got to a rheumy he sent me for an MRI which clearly showed SI inflammation. I would suggest that you see if they want to send you for tests next week and ask specifically to be screened for the genetic marker HLA-B27 - one recommendation for B27+ uveitis is to taper off the pred drops quite slowly!!

0/post_text/2: I have been diagnosed this morning with Uveitis, so not the best Easter but I have had great help so far. 1/post_text/5: There are a couple of members with AK and uveitis and they'll probably be along soon to share their experience and wisdom with you.
1/post_text/6: Being an informed patient helps a lot dealing with this disease and as you read the information on the site if there's anything unclear, ask whatever you want. We've all been in your position and many of us found it really difficult in the early months to understand much at all.
1/post_text/7: I hope there is a reduction in the number of cells when you go back and that you are sent off for blood tests and x-rays.
2/post_text/3: Hope everyone got lots of easter eggs, the Easter bunny has been very kind to me this year!
3/post_text/1: The x-rays are to look at bones and joints and the chest x-ray looks for signs of autoimmune conditions or infections affecting the lungs. If signs of TB are seen, for example, this can affect future treatment stronger than eye drops.
3/post_text/2: 3+ cells means more than 30 inflammatory cells. The scale runs from 1 to 5 in units of ten cells with 5 being 50+ and 1 being between 10 and 19. The doctors can usually tell if you've had it before since signs of old inflammation can be  left in the eye.
3/post_text/3: Some people are lucky and only ever have one attack of uveitis, or have attacks with years of being inflammation free between them.
5/post_text/1: I've already had two x-rays on my back one 6 years ago and one a month ago and they have compared them and found that there is thickening in the sacroiliac joints, my lower back does not move much anymore however as I am one of the lucky bendy people (hyperflexibility) so my hips and rest of my back do the bending for me :) and I am excerise mad so when fatigue or pain does not get me I'm really active.

13/post_text/1: Went to my first visit (and hopefully not too many more) to the eye clinic today. Down to a drop ever 2 hours now, then next week 3 and so on.... and another visit in another 2 weeks. Got sent for bloods for all the common things and a chest x-ray (for TB like someone kindly explained before) so got all that done when I was there :) Spend from 9:30- 1:45pm there and I'm not the most patient of people, I like to be doing something all the time. The Dr seemed to have some ideas of things to investigate further to try and rule out (or in) included AK and ?marfans!?  It really helped tat people had replied earlier so I knew what to expect.
13/post_text/2: As I'm still waiting for appointment letters that the GP requested so the Dr today said he would refer me directly to rheumy and I should see them pretty quickly :)
13/post_text/3: The kids at school have been funny when they clock my dodgy eye they are either 'URRgggh! what you done Miss, that's like a vampire?' or 'Arrhh, that looks really cute!' Not found it too hard at work just feel a bit 'confused' when rushing around. 15 year olds can be really sweet when you explain you have a headache and they need to be quiet...think I will need to have a 'headache' more often!
13/post_text/4: Hope everyone else has managed to avoid the showers today!
4/post_text/4: In a (very) roundabout way I'm grateful for the AS/uveitis combo - the uveitis definitely helped me get the AS diagnosis quicker, and to get onto effective treatment (after we'd tried to control the eyes with mixed success for some years already...) I was sleeping on the floor when I started this treatment as I got too sore in bed so I do remember those days of having to psych myself up to get out of bed - that's (thankfully!) all history now!! I'm not sure if you've heard of Carol Sinclair or the low starch diet - she's written a book (which I was able to find in my local library) which I found very interesting - and which really helped my back when I followed it - really useful for me to help control symptoms before diagnosis! Swimming also helped a lot - I could tell if I hadn't swum once or twice in a week.
4/post_text/5: Hopefully, this uveitis attack will soon subside and not bother you again!
11/post_text/3: Off to London this weekend so that will be a nice distraction. Then work on Monday, still not quite sure how I am going to cope with the projectors and whiteboards as they are pretty bright, think I will be wearing sunglasses in the classroom!
15/post_text/1: Glad things have improved and you can reduce the drops a bit already - hope the headaches are completely gone too! Much as it's frustrating hanging around hospitals a long time, it's really good that they're doing the investigations. I think many of us take stuff to do along to clinic appointments - I even sometimes take a snack along..!! It sounds like your school kids are also being considerate - I like the thought of a "headache" there more often though...! :)
15/post_text/2: With regards to your question - I think it's quite likely that your vision will return to normal in time - in my experience it just takes ages though!! My eyes blur quite a lot too, and like you I wear glasses already (although I am rather short sighted!). After one of my first flares, I asked the same question and was told my vision shouldn't really change any more - I think by this stage I may even have been on my last steroid drop or even off them - so duly went off to get another prescription made. As I'm so short sighted though, thin lenses are really expensive so I didn't actually order new glasses - just as well as a few weeks later they were back to my normal! I think my prescription now is the same as it was before all of this started, even though I've had some pretty severe flares along the way - there is early cataract in one eye from steroid use but it currently doesn't affect me too much. Hopefully, the same will be true for you - otherwise yes, you could just replace the lens in one eye (but I would wait...!)
15/post_text/3: Many of us take lists of written down questions in to appointments as there is the tendency to forget things (especially if you've been waiting ages...) - although I've even managed to forget to ask a question which WAS written down in front of me! :) The theory to counteract that problem is to hand the questions over as you go in (make sure they're prioritised though)
15/post_text/4: Hope your appointment letters come through soon!

2/post_text/3: If I can help you and him out in any way, I will be more than willing. I know that for someone going through this, it is easier to relate to others in the same situation rather than your family or a doctor who has no idea what it feels like. I still battle with the emotions at times, and I've dealt with this for almost 15 years now, so if there are any questions that you have I will give you honest answers.  Braiden will probably go through years of denial, anger, and self-destruction before he realizes that his life is worth living.. It is such a sad reality. It was horrible for me to go through it. The best advice that I can give you now is to try to give him a reason to want to live.. Give him something that makes him feel useful, I trained with horses and honestly it was one of the best experiences of my life! But even something as small as growing his own garden, or helping to train dogs for service to other low-vision people. If there are any opportunities for him to help out and feel like he is making a difference in someone else's life then that would be good for him too. He will have to figure out on his own that he is still able to live a full and happy life, I know it is hard to watch, but I pray that he will soon.

1/post_text/2: Uveitis specialists are trained in immunology but GPs and eye clinics can also order tests to determine underlying causes of uveitis. Unfortunately, a significant number of us still end up with a diagnosis of idiopathic - cause unknown. Have you had the blood tests and x-rays to rule in, or out, systemic underlying causes?
1/post_text/3: Non specialist eye clinics can refer you to a specialist uveitis clinic. The main specialist clinics are in London, Birmingham, Manchester, Sheffield, and Bristol. GPs will also make referrals to specialist centres. If you're in Scotland, Aberdeen is the place to go. If you want to see someone quickly, privately, Moorfields has a private clinic in London and OV members say Mr Pavesio and Dhanes Thomas are really good. There is also Prof Ayliffe at the Lister hospital who is also really good.
1/post_text/4: Referral to a specialist on the NHS is generally when the uveitis affects the back of the eye or anterior uveitis is chronic with complications such as macular oedema.

1/post_text/1: Anyway, It is all about finding the right combination of drugs. Sounds like you might need something else added to the methotrexate (other than steriods - have a look at the treatment section of the site), to help control the uveitis.
1/post_text/2: Also, I might add 15mg/week of MTX doesn't sound a very big dose. My son is 7, sure he is tall for is age (and may I say very handsome, I am his mum) but I am guessing that you are probably a bit bigger and heavier. Might be worth questioning your dose with your current consultant. Given that 15mg/week is the maximum for Riley and he is only about 128cm tall. I am sure your maximum dose for height/ weight could be more. Larger doses can be given as injections which tend to help bypass some of the more unpleasant side effects. Also, MTX can take up to 6 months to work.

4/post_text/0: There is something to be said about involving to many people. What's that too many cooks spoil the broth! Get the referral and drop the local hospital, much better to just have specialists and I guess in your case the military doctors. They must replace your GP.
4/post_text/1: Also, when you see your rheumatologist, you could ask about injections of MTX rather than tablets, might make you feel less dodgy. Also, memorise or write down a couple of the drugs names on the treatment section like Cellcept, HUMIRA etc and just ask if you should be on them. See what they say....Also, ask about the floaters, I have problems with them in one eye not from uveitis but from a couple of vitreous haemorhages, you can have surgery to fix it but I am not sure if it would be applicable as you have uveitis. No surgery can be done until you have been inflammation free for at least three months.
4/post_text/2: You can also have steriod implants in the back of your eye but the problem with them is that they will cause other problems like secondary glaucoma and cataracts eventually,  which can be as debilitating as the uveitis in the long run. It would appear to me, from being an obsessive uveitis forum stalker, that all the people who have had chronic uveitis and now have glaucoma and cataracts wished they had moved on from steriods sooner. I would echo that sentiment with my son.
4/post_text/3: There is thinking from America that if you can stabalise you eyes (e.g no flares) for a period of two years on drugs, like MTX and Cellcept (not steriods) then slowly wean yourself of them, should hopefully stop the uveitis.

6/post_text/1: I'm sorry this third taper has resulted in another flare. What to do next is a really tough decision.
6/post_text/2: I think I would be guided by what the ophthalmologist says. Three flares in ten months is distressing, you don't know how the uveitis will progress and this latest flare without obvious symptoms as you rightly say, worries you. Has Maya's specialist treated many children with unilateral uveitis for years with steroid drops and the children retained full vision, sustained no damage to structures in their eyes and undergone no surgery at the point the uveitis came to an end? Although your daughter has no underlying disease, there are JIA and uveitis statistics on the internet concerning the sight retained by children treated only with steroid for years. Looking at these might give an additional perspective on treating with eye drops alone.
6/post_text/3: Another way of looking at is to think that the mtx therapy now might be only for two years plus weaning off time and your daughter's immune response is altered so that the uveitis comes to an end and her eye is undamaged by the complication of cataract and the possibility of raised ocular pressure. Staying on a drop a day means you are waiting for the uveitis to run its course, however long that takes, and each flare has the potential to cause damage. You've already seen a little of what uncontrolled inflammation can do through your daughter's pupil sticking.
6/post_text/4: I'm more ambivalent than many others are about the issue of 'one eye only,' especially where the young are concerned. They have a life time of seeing ahead of them, the majority will live far longer than we can expect to and who knows what will happen to the good, non uveitic eye, as the child grows and ages. I think, on balance, I'd want my child to grow older with two fully functioning eyes!
