10/post_text/0: My son was initially under the care of the Morefield and we had a year of drops from varying spells of hourly drops right through to once daily drops. Methotrexate was always in the background but we were hesitant to start that course of treatment. Our family moved to be nearer grandparents as they have Alzheimer's so his care was moved to bristol. They pushed the idea of methotrexate and so we went ahead, however it was evident after just a few months that it wasn't working for him so we had to rethink his medication and he moved onto HUMIRA. I wish we hadn't delayed the decision for methotrexate. I'm not saying this to scare you as this medication does have amazing results for most people. Our delay was wondering how he would cope with it but he copes amazingly well and it soon becomes 'no big thing' as he says. Sometimes he had sickness but strawberry laces and orange tic tacs work! There are good anti sickness drugs available to help if needed although he manages to cope without. We have found that pre filled pen injection is better although we do help him administer it he is now working towards doing it independently as he still has to have the methotrexate to support the HUMIRA. It's really not as scary and daunting as it seems.

1/post_text/1: I'm sorry to read that your daughter's uveitis is proving to be stubborn. Until the inflammation is controlled, everything to do with uveitis is so demoralising.
1/post_text/2: It sounds as though you have already done that really difficult parental weighing up act of deciding which is more important - the fear of beginning an immune suppressant or the fear your child will lose sight.
1/post_text/3: Children are generally started on methotrexate as an immune suppressant. At the low doses required for uveitis and with careful monitoring, it's a generally safe treatment. The side effects parents report include their child feeling very tired the day after the weekly pills or the injection. Some children may also experience nausea. Many parents choose Friday evenings to give the drug so that the child has the weekend to get over it. I take my own methotrexate just before going to bed and because it hasn't tired me out or made me feel sick, I assume I sleep through any immediate side effects. On occasion, when I've forgotten to take it before bed and take it in the morning, then I feel a tiny bit off during the day and don't fancy eating at all until the evening. Folic acid is prescribed with mtx to help with side effects.
1/post_text/4: If Bristol decide your daughter should have methotrexate injections instead of pills, this can cause a problem for some young people but there is a brilliant paediatric uveitis nurse there who will help you and your daughter manage this.

1/post_text/5: The other good thing about your referral to Bristol is that the paediatric rheumatologist who works with the uveitis team may be able to get to the bottom of the knee problem. You probably already know from your own research that the most common cause of uveitis in children is JIA and sometimes the uveitis will develop before the JIA. I would certainly talk to the rheumatologist about the symptoms and ask what other rheumatoid condition might be behind them if he agrees that it's definitely not JIA. With Bristol being a referral and research centre, they do tend to see the really rare diseases. It might be helpful to take some photos of your daughter's knees in flare up just in case her knees are not swollen or hot on the day of your appointment. This might provide some clues about what's going on if there's no physical evidence of a problem on the day and the x-rays done so far have shown no damage to the joints, or evidence of JIA activity.
1/post_text/6: Who knows - Bristol may be able to diagnose an underlying condition to explain the uveitis. Even if this remains a mystery, you might be able to go forward knowing that one drug is treating both eyes and joints.
1/post_text/7: I hope you don't wait too long for your referral appointment. Please come back and tell us how you get on.

1/post_text/1: Yes, a number of us will have had genetic testing done. In my case genetic testing showed that I was HLA-B27 positive, leading to a HLA-B27-associated uveitis diagnosis initially, which later became ankylosing spondylitis. This test was very helpful in understanding how my uveitis was likely to present and how best to manage it. It must however be said that...
1/post_text/2: "The HLA-B27 test is not a definitive test that can be used to diagnose or rule out a disorder. It is used as one piece of evidence in a constellation of signs, symptoms, and lab tests to support or rule out the diagnosis of certain autoimmune disorders, such as AS and reactive arthritis."
1/post_text/3: There are of course many other genetic markers which can be looked at, and many new markers/associations for various conditions are being discovered through research!

0/topic_title: Can iritis smoulder without there being cells in the anterior chamber
1/post_text/0: It's probably more accurate to say that treatment, rather than inflammation, lasts 6-8 weeks for most people. Steroid puts out the inflammation quickly and cells disappear. The redness, if you have it, may disappear in a day or two but that's not to say there are no cells inside the front of the eye which are seen during the slit lamp exam. Treatment means reducing the drops slowly over 6-8 weeks. Reduce the drops too quickly, or stop them suddenly, and rebound inflammation may occur. The iritis, generally, only goes because steroid is going in and the eye has to get used to less and less steroid and then none at all without flaring up again before you can say the iritis has gone. There is also subclinical inflammation in which the ophthalmologist can't see cells but there is still inflammatory activity going on.

0/post_text/0: I was diagnosed with uveitis in December 2009, after my GP treated me unsuccessfully for conjunctivitis - my optician eventually refferred me to Gloucester Eye Clinic where I was treated with steroid drops and tablets.  Each time they tried to reduce the dose the inflamation returned and I was then transferred to Bristol in September 2010.  After various tests they put me on tacrolimus and cellsept to suppress my immune system because I was having an auto-immune response.  They called it VKH syndrome.  I've been very grateful for the the way my problems have been dealt with, and know that things could be much worse - my condition was caught in time and my sight seems stable.  We are now reducing the steroid dose gradually.  My problem is that I seem to be getting a migraine type response every now and again - nasty thumping head and vomiting followed by nausea - which my GP is treating with increased omeprazole and standard migraine medication.  Could this be linked to the other medication I'm taking, or is it something unconnected?  Does anyone else get this?  I can't identify any dietary reasons.

2/post_text/1: Your daughter's problem is very common:  the steroid drops work in a manner of speaking because they quell the inflammation while they're being used and for a short time afterwards, but then the uveitis comes back with a vengeance.
2/post_text/2: Due to the nature of the side effects of long term steroid use, the more modern way of thinking is to use a steroid sparing approach, such as mtx, instead of going round in circles for years.  Rheumatologists have been using these drugs and others for many years very comfortably, with excellent results, however it seems that a few ophthalmologists still have a little catching up to do.

2/post_text/0: My son was diagnosed at 4 with JIA, uveitis and band keratopathy. He started on Methotrexate but suffered severe vomiting (even with anti sickness drugs). He could barely walk and his Uveitis was severe. He has now been on Humira (adalimumab)for 3 years and is living life as a normal 8 year old. We call it the miracle medicine as he can now run around and participate in sports with his friends, his arthritis has been unnoticable apart from the odd flare up which has lasted no more than 24 hours and his uveitis has settled tremendously. It is a painful injection according to him, but he is more than happy to receive it 2 weekly as the results far outweigh the sting which only lasts 5 minutes. Hope this helps.

0/post_text/1: I have suffered from repeated episodes of uveitis over the past 2 years. My attacks can be controlled with steroid eye drops and dilating drops. To clarify I don't have "infectious" uveitis; I do have quiet periods in between flare ups. I have the HLAB27 gene but the standard tests have not found related disease. Having a science background I have read and researched thoroughly to try and find new ways control this horrific disease.
0/post_text/2: I seem to have found a real breakthrough, as simple as it sounds, by cleaning my eyes twice daily with antiseptic eye wash. Please note I have first thought of this as there is a significant amount of research linking antibacterial infection as a trigger / cause of autoimmune disease. I also noticed that each time I had an attack of uveitis, my eyelids became inflamed too (this condition is known as blepharitis) and I could get my eyelids under control by using antiseptic wipes- this got me thinking this could work for my eyes too. Ankylosing spondylitis - a form of arthritis linked with HLAB27 gene has been linked with bacterial infection. Interestingly this and other forms of arthritis have been brought under control using antibiotics.
2/post_text/3: I have also heard nettle tea is a good anti-inflammatory idea - and am doing it- I really don't want a recurrance!
2/post_text/4: Will keep posting any positive results - especially non-negative ones, hopefully.
0/post_text/3: It is early days but I can tell you when I first used the antiseptic eyewash my eyes felt "normal" for the first time since I first experienced uveitis. Fellow sufferers I'm sure can relate to how exciting this is. I also noticed that I felt better and that the gland that has been swollen in my neck since a bad flare up a year ago has virtually gone. Thinking back I first experienced uveitis a couple of days after visiting a beauty salon where they used face clothes over my eyes - looking back probably an ideal way to pick up an infection! The irony of going to a beauty salon for a relaxing facial and ending up with something as horrendous as uveitis hasn't escaped me!
0/post_text/4: So this is what I have been doing cleaning my eyes twice a day using  eyewash (I use Optrex Eyewash Superdrug also do one with similar ingredients). I also clean my eyelids with blephaclean wipes(other antiseptic wipes for eyelid hygiene are available). I have listed some of the ingredients in the eye wash and how they may be helping:
0/post_text/6: benzalkonium chloride- keeps eyes free from microbes
0/post_text/7: witch hazel - anti-infllammatory agents, tannins have anti-bacterial and anti-viral properties
0/post_text/8: It is early days but I am really excitied by the difference this is making to my eyes so far. I really hope this may offer hope to my fellow sufferers. I'd be keen to know your thoughts and how you get on should you attempt to try this. Of course I'm not advocating this instead of treatment but something that can be used alongside. I wouldn't use the wash immediately after other treatment drops to avoid interfering/ diluting treatment.
0/post_text/9: Fingers crossed this improvement continues. I pray that this might help some of you suffering this cruel disease too.

1/post_text/2: If the redness is in the inner corner next to the nose, it might be conjunctival blood vessels, rather than uveitis inflammation. They can burst if there's been sneezing and coughing. This type of redness clears up in about five days by itself. It's often a spectacular reddening though rather than a tiny reddening when this happens. The drops can cause a bit of reddening too. If the redness is around the iris, I'd definitely advise you to go in. Perhaps a telephone call to the clinic for advice is the best action if it looks worse this morning?

1/post_text/1: Sorry that macular oedema has developed. Sometimes the oedema is mild and will resolve, other times it's more serious and requires treatment beyond steroid drops and in a few cases it can persist.
1/post_text/2: There are treatments for it - various drops, steroid pills and injections, anti vegf injections and when inflammation is chronic, immunosuppressant treatment may help. A couple of glaucoma treatments which work by clearing fluid, such as Azopt drops and diamox pills, can be helpful for some people.
1/post_text/3: A discussion with your doctor concerning what has caused the oedema, the degree of oedema and a treatment plan is the best way forward. Generally, the cause needs to be dealt with in order for the oedema to resolve and stay away.

1/post_text/1: When I was first diagnosed I must have spent every spare minute on the internet googling every single word I'd written down during my appointments.  It's so confusing and when I found this site with it's Glossary I cursed that it hadn't existed all that time ago!
1/post_text/2: You're right that synechiae is the same as the sticking you've been told about. Basically (and yes I've stolen this straight from the glossary on this site!) synechiae is like scar tissue which forms after the eye in question has suffered alot of flares.  It can make the iris stick to the cornea and then it's called anterior synechiae, or / and it can make the iris stick to the lens and then it's called posterior synechiae.  But both are to do with Anterior Uveitis.
1/post_text/3: It's a confusing term but having posterior synechiae does not mean your son has posterior uveitis it just means the sticking part has happened in a different part of the iris but still at the front of the eye - and when uveitis happens around the iris that's part of anterior uveitis.
1/post_text/4: The synechiae can "pull" the pupil into strange shapes which is why Owen's is square.  The dilating drops can break up the stickiness but from my understanding it's not always successful but it's one of those thing that doesn't cause any harm in trying.  I was on dilating drops for over a year.

3/post_text/1: Owen may not have noticed anything odd with his sight. Some people with anterior uveitis don't notice anything at all even when inflammation is bad. Others do. It's even more difficult with young children because they assume everyone sees the way they do and so don't say anything until it's obvious to them that others see better. Even then, some may stay quiet because they don't want to wear glasses.
3/post_text/2: Owen's visual acuity should have been tested by a nurse before he saw the doctor and you should have been told what it was. I think they have a special test for children Owen's age when knowledge of the alphabet cannot be taken for granted. If you weren't told and can't wait for the next appointment, then visiting an optician would give you an answer. Since Owen's eyes are dilated, it would be wise to tell an optician this, because looking through a pin hole compensates for the effect the dilating drops have on sight.
3/post_text/3: Whether Owen's vision has been affected all along, or whether it hasn't, he will notice a difference in what he sees now. The dilating drops blur vision and in bright light, such as sunlight, you'll notice his pupil doesn't become small like your own. He'll see better in places like underground car parks than he does in places like supermarkets with their artificial light. A pair of polorised sun glasses will be helpful outside.
5/post_text/1: feel free to call me anytime on the numbers I gave you in the email, you'll find the Helpline number on all the website pages or email me on

0/post_text/0: Anyone had a problem with their child? Are there links between early Uveitis and dyslexia?
1/post_text/0: Hi Lindsey. I've personally never heard of any links but it's good to ask these questions as you  never know. I've always wondered if there is a possible link between orthodontist treatment and Uveitis since my own daughter's condition triggered off. She's since had allergy tests done and tested highly sensitive/toxic to Nickel. So lets keep asking these questions and thank goodness for this website! xx
2/post_text/0: Hi Lindsey,
2/post_text/1: It's well worth asking around but I've not come across it.
2/post_text/2: Take care
3/post_text/0: Hi Lindsey,
2/post_text/3: Nicki
3/post_text/1: Whether or not there is a connection between dyslexia and uveitis when sight hasn't been affected, I wouldn't know. However, I do know that loss of sight and reduced central vision do affect one's ability to read and suspect that if this occurs when a child is learning to read, there are consequences.
3/post_text/2: My own uveitis affected my sight and for quite a long time I couldn't read easily, or even at all. Once sight was restored, I found that I read differently. I no longer see spelling mistakes easily and put this down to having spent such a long time struggling to read and guessing words from the odd letters I could make out. I would think that if sight is affected while a child is learning to read, then there  will be an impact on reading and the development of reading skills. While this is not dyslexia, at the very least, a child struggling to see and therefore reading ever so slowly, is not a child who is necessarily going to enjoy reading or even want to read. It's very hard work. As an adult who loves reading, I eventually found it too frustrating and would only attempt to read what was necessary for every day living, like a bill or bank statement.
3/post_text/3: A friend found me a 'books online' website and I could enlarge text like you can with Kindle etc these days. To the fully sighted, it sounds easy, problem sorted. However, even though you can see huge text, it's still frustrating because the size of the text means only so many words per line and the ability to skim read is lost with this. You go back to reading like you did when you were five or six, two to three words at a time, unless the text appears on a huge, wide screen.

0/post_text/0: The message below was received in our inbox.
0/topic_title: Communicating about pain workshops - London and online.
0/post_text/1: Dear Olivia's Vision team,
0/post_text/2: We are a London based, NCRM funded research project that aims to explore new methodologies for communicating Chronic pain. Currently we are looking for participants to join 4 workshops, led by artists, where we aim to explore collectively and through creative means what it is to experience chronic pain and to live with it.
0/post_text/3: We would be very grateful if you could pass along this message to people who might be interested, or post in your forums on our behalf if appropriate.
0/post_text/4: Anyone with chronic pain or an interest in treating people with pain is welcome.  All workshops will take place at Pulross Intermediate Care Centre, 47a Pulross Road, London, SW9 8AE.
0/post_text/5: Workshops are free to attend and are open to a range of mobility requirements.  The site is accessible and parking is available.  Lunch and refreshments will be provided.  We can also help to cover travel costs; please get in touch to discuss what you might need.
0/post_text/6: To register, please visit our website
0/post_text/7: www.communicatingchronicpain.org
0/post_text/8: or contact us via this email
0/post_text/9: info@communicatingchronicpain.org
0/post_text/11: We really hope you can make one or more workshops, but if it is not possible to attend, we are also running a workshop/community online, where people are invited to share work in new media in our site. More info at
0/post_text/14: Below is a short description of the workshops, more info at
0/post_text/17: Many thanks for your interest and very best wishes,
0/post_text/20: Imaging and Imagining Chronic Pain – 1st February 2014
0/post_text/21: In the workshop, we will consider how neuroimaging techniques, such as MRI, have helped to progress our understanding of pain. We will also explore how these images reflect the quality of an individuals’ pain experience.
0/post_text/22: To tackle this challenge, we will call upon the power of metaphors, visualisation and image making. Guided through a Body Scan Meditation, we will invite you to focus attention around your body, being curious about your experience and observing the body sensations you become aware of. Using a range of arts materials and mono-printing techniques, you will give visible form to these internal observations by adopting your own unique visual language for the imaging of your bodily and emotional experience; in the presence or absence of pain. Calling upon the power of imagination and creativity, these body scans will bring us closer to the subjective experiences of our bodies and allusive sensations of pain that conventionally relies on verbal accounts.
0/post_text/24: Pain can be conceived of as a material with many differing qualities. During the workshop, we will be exploring these qualities together through techniques of body awareness and visualisation and mapping. Participants are invited to bring an object to the session which represents some aspect of their experience of pain or treating pain.  We will be using these to create ‘portraits of pain’ through shared discussion and photography.
0/post_text/25: We will also explore the relationship between the aspects of pain visualised through the objects and the experience of pain held within our bodies.  Using our bodies and building on spontaneous awareness of pain through Alexander Technique to look at psycho-physical aspects of pain, we will attempt to reposition pain as more within our control.
0/post_text/26: A Soundscape of a Body in Pain – 1st March 2014
0/post_text/27: How might we communicate pain – though dissonance? Atonally? Dull, monotonous? How do we hear chronic pain?
0/post_text/28: This workshop will be framed around the concept of a radio channel (Chronic Radio) and a ‘sound play’ which offers a space where individual stories of pain can be heard and shared, leading to a collective participant led sound collage (soundscape).
0/post_text/29: The sounds of pain do not necessarily have to always be negative associations, but may also encompass the sounds one might like to hear, the soundtracks and soundscapes that allow one to cope, that soothe, or help to take the pain away. We will explore these sounds through a live group improvisation through the use of conventional and unconventional instruments, as well as experimenting with the use of normal sounds ‘treated’ electronically.
0/post_text/30: Spatial mapping of chronic pain 22nd March 2014
0/post_text/31: What spaces do we associate with pain? How does pain affect our relation to space? How does pain shape spaces? How can we visualise spatial experiences of pain?
0/post_text/32: Space can be described as produced by the interaction between bodies: experiences, emotions, thoughts and movement. In this workshop we want to explore how spaces are transformed by experiences of chronic pain and how our understanding of space is shaped by our thoughts and sensitivities around our own pain or that of others around us.
0/post_text/33: We will start from individual perceptions and memories of specific places and work together towards building a collective mapping of our bodies in pain/space.
0/post_text/38: London School of Economics and Political Science

0/post_text/0: The Following might be of interest to some other Uvitis sufferers.
1/post_text/1: Sorry to hear that you've had such a long battle with uveitis.  Infection is just one of the many causes of uveitis including eg trauma to the eye and auto-immune diseases.  In your case the antibiotics kill the infection and steroid drops take away the inflammation temporarily, but testing positive for HLA-B27 it seems possible that the root of the problem has never been addressed.
1/post_text/2: However it must also be stressed that although you have certain markers this does not mean that you will ever develop any systemic disease whatsoever.
1/post_text/3: At present there is  no "cure" for uveitis, just the hope that with the right combination of meds it can be put into successful long term remission.
1/post_text/4: Despite the longevity of your uveitis you don't mention any vision loss which makes me hopeful that you have suffered several bouts of mild uveitis, which has not caused any complications. You have also illustrated the need to jump into action each time a flare occurs regardless of how many years have passed since the last flare, and ensure you receive a treatment which works for you.
2/post_text/0: Hi Nicki
2/post_text/1: Thanks for the kind thoughts (and also to Maxine who also expressed sympathy).  In actual fact when I had my first attack I was given a quite small chance of keeping the sight in my right eye (which was the first affected).  Following the administration of antibiotics I recovered so quickly that I counted myself very lucky.  The next attack I was a bit slow in demanding antibiotics plus the Doctor treating me forgot to sign me up for intensive dilations (I was again an in patient in hospital)so I have some damage where my iris stuck to my lens.  Neither attack was mild and was in fact was extremely severe and rapid but the inflamation was confined, I think, to the front of the eye.  After that I demanded antibiotics at a very early stage and have not suffered any further damage to either eye.
2/post_text/2: I actually think myself very lucky in that I could have lost my sight some 40 years ago so I have had all that time of normal life which was "stolen" from fate; I try to live my life accordingly.  The odd reoccurance now is nothing but a mild nuisance and I feel very reassured with my letter (I have copies everywhere) from my friendly Proffessor saying I need antibiotics when required.
3/post_text/0: I think, although, it has never been proven that my uveitis was caused by antibiotics (I am allergic to pretty much every antibiotic known to man). In 1998, I was seriously ill with an infection of my liver and gallbladder and I was on antibotics for several months before and after the operation I had to remove the offending gallbladder.  It was in November of that year that my eyes started to become red and sore, my workplace sent me to Selly Oak casualty who thought I had scratched my cornea.  Needless do say my eyes did not improve and my boss was increasingly distressed about the state of my eyes because he said they made him feel quite sick.  I decided to take myself to the Birmingham & Midland Eye Centre where uveitis was diagnosed and then I found myself in the Eye Hospital on a regular basis.

5/post_text/0: Hi Denise,
0/post_text/1: I had my first attack of Uvitis when I was 21.  It was very severe and I was hospitalised.  After about 2 weeks or so I could no longer see out of my right eye due to exudate (pus!).  I was treated with steroids and Atropine by the bucket load and the usual conventional treatments, injections in to the eye etc. but all to no avail.  Eventually someone suggested trying antibiotics which worked like magic; within a day or so my vision started to return.  I had several more attacks over the next ten years or so, all following the same pattern.  Each time because of the itinerant nature of hospital Doctors I had enormous difficulty in persuading them to give me antibiotics. Eventually I got a letter to carry around explaining the situation .  It was presumed that I had a bacterial infection, which was not located.  My last attack followed Scarlet Fever, a bacterial infection.  I had several bouts of mouth ulcers prior to my first attack and after each attach I suffered from very severe exhaustion.  May be indicating Bechet's Syndrome? I am Lactose intollerant, again this might be relevant.
0/post_text/2: I had no more attacks until relatively recently.  I am now 63 years old; I have moved to a different part of the country and in any case my old hospital notes had been destroyed.  Also thinking I was cured I had foolishly thrown out my letter.  The first recent attack was cured very quickly because the hospital Doctor I spoke to believed my story and gave me antibiotics.  The next time the Registrar treated me as an idiot and I walked out.  She would only give me drops and wanted to sign me off for two weeks.  As I knew how much damage could be done in two weeks I went to another casualty department and the Doctor I saw was sympathetic but would not give me antibiotics straight away.  However, he promissed to see me in a couple of days to review the situation.  As it happened I had been having bouts of what I thought was Neuralgia and remembered the investigations into my Dental Health the very first time I had Uvitis (incidentally these all proved to be negative). So I went to the Dentist.  She carried out some X-rays and found that I had an infected tooth under a recently fitted crown, so I got my antibiotics from the Dentist and the Uvitis was also cured.  Subsequently I (very reluctantly) went back to the original hospital at the insistence of my GP.  I saw a Professor (the lady Registrar's boss!) who not only listed to me but actually gave me a new “To whom it may concern” letter.  He was a bit scathing about Doctors who do not listen to their patients. He also said that at one time a standard attempted cure for Uvitis was to remove all the patients teeth!
1/post_text/5: I'll keep my fingers crossed that the uveitis has now been banished from your life never to return!
2/post_text/3: Best Wishes Peter
3/post_text/1: I have had steroids injected into my eye and into my leg, I have been on drips of steroids in hospital too when my eye pressures have gone through the roof.  In 2002, I had my first trabulectomy on my left eye because my pressures had increased to 32 and I was given some pretty awful tablets to take that made my extremeties go numb (this made life difficult because I felt as though my fingers had been substituted for a pound of sausages). I have been taking various drops ever since.
3/post_text/2: Since then I have had various operations on my eyes - my left eye in particular as that was always the worst myopically.  I no longer have any central vision in my left eye due to glaucoma.  In 2004, I had a headache for a few days that I could not shift and that necessitated a trip to the hospital on my return from a long weekend and the pressure in my right eye had rocketed to 53 - I was not allowed to leave the hospital and ended up on a drip to reduce the pressure to a limit where it was safe to operate.
3/post_text/3: Although I have not been discharged from the glaucoma clinic, I no longer attend it as my pressures are monitored by the uveitis clinic and my consultant Prof Murray.  In 2009, I had a cataract removed from my left eye and I was hoping that I would get a decent lense but Prof decided to make it short sighted to balance out my other eye which is also short sighted - the op was done for medical reasons as I don't really get any benefit.  My eye pressures have gradually increased too - I was averaging out 4-6 in each eye and now I am back in double figures (10).  My uveitis is under control and I have Minims and take one drop per day to each eye.  I attend clinic every 3 months.

However they were concerned about inflamation in the back of the eye and I had photographs taken almost every week to monitor it.
2/post_text/2: I was taken off the Azath in Aug 2010 because of low bone marrow then they put me back on it Oct 2010 to give it another go. Same thing happened so stopped Azath in Nov 2010 and waited for bloods to recover.  The bone marrow and white blood count took until April 2011 to get back to normal.  At this point the opthamologist decided not to start TAc but to try and taper the steroid dose I was told these things sometimes "burn themselves out".  Once I hit 15mg I started having cloudy vision but the opthamolgist couldn't see much activity in the eye so he dropped me to 10mg followed by 10 mg / 5 mg alternative days.  He was reluctant to start Tac and delayed me over the summer period because he was away on holidays. In Sept 11 I had a flare up because the steroids were reduced.

6/post_text/0: Maxine hit the nail on the head about UV sufferers needing emotional support along with the physical support. Braiden has been on steroids for 10 months. He is also autistic and lacks the ability to communicate how much his medical issues are affecting him emotionally. We went to a psychiatrist to seek medication management for his behavior, as he has raging outbursts and long, mournful crying spells. The psych remarked that his emotional/behavioral state was not a psychiatric concern, but an anxiety-based behavioral manifestation due to his delicate physical state. He started no new meds but referred us to a psychology clinic that specializes in treating children with chronic medical problems to help Braiden learn to cope with the anxieties of being a sick child, and a child who is rapidly losing his senses of sight and hearing.
6/post_text/1: Suz, you are not nuts. You are not going crazy. You have a very serious medical condition that is being treated with high-risk medications that quite frankly, make you feel more ill in order to make you better. It is maddening what UV sufferers go through. As far as I have read, Maxine is right. The fact that you are still working in a high-demand workplace shows tremendous grace and strength on your part. I, as just a parent, could not cope with my workload and had to reduce my hours and withdraw from college in order to meet the demands of helping my child. You have superseded a well person's abilities to cope! I sincerely hope that you get the care that you so desperately need and that you will find comfort and emotional support from the friends here at OV :)

8/post_text/1: I've been to the hospital today with my list of questions for the opthamologist.
8/post_text/2: Good news the inflamation has decreased and I'm dropping from 40mg steroids to 30mg monitoing in 2wks.  I've also been referred to a Rheumatology consultant to try alternative treatments.
8/post_text/3: The opthamologist spend almost an hour with my husband and I explaining the condition, prognosis and treatment options. he explained that I have intermediate uv and I have a lot of debris in the vitreous - the good news is that there it is not cystoid and under the retina so the retina isn't being stretched. He said that's why he has delayed in offering alternative treatment. I mentioned MTX and he said that MTX would not be his preferred option but that there are lots of alternatives that the rheumatologist could offer. He mentioned biological agents and said the funding in our area was usually good which is a positive. He also mentiond the possibility of a vitrectomy however this is a major operation and it would be a last resort.

However since 2012 I have suffered on and off with unilateral uveitis, but more recently bilaterally. Always the same routine cyclopentalate and pred forte. This time it has been resistant to this treatment and I have been prescribed oral prednisalone. It is noted that corticoid steroid treatment appears to be avoided according to Dr Foster & that eye injections of kenalog appears to be the treatment of choice.
1/post_text/1: Sorry to read you've had this for such a long time.
1/post_text/2: Treatment for intermediate uveitis varies and when it affects both eyes, you need to be under the care of a specialist who will know the best treatment for you. People with the more severe inflammation may be offered immunosuppressants. For others, the potential risks of such treatment may not outweigh benefit when sight is not at risk and intermediate uveitis goes on for years. For a few, surgery (vitrectomy) may help.
1/post_text/3: Steroid is used to quell inflammation quickly. When only one eye is badly enough inflamed to require either pills or an injection, an injections is often used. When it's both eyes, some ophthalmologists prefer to prescribe the pills to spare the patient a double injection.
1/post_text/4: When you have your next appointment, it might be an idea to ask about long term treatment and your options.If you're already under the care of a specialist s/he won't mind you initiating discussion about your long term care.

1/post_text/3: Everybody responses to other treatments differently, which I assume you mean by 'other treatments' as the drugs that help to control the immune system, since you have already received (what sounds like a steriod injection). Some people hardly seem notice they are taking a new medicine. My son was one of these, others do however experience some side effects. It is impossible to tell until you start. But If you do experience side effects there are other things you can do or take to help lessen them.
1/post_text/4: The thing is to keep in mind that everyone who have been offered 'other treatments' for uveitis are apprehensive about starting them; who wouldn't be - you only have to read some of the other posts on here. None of the treatments options for uveitis are easy.

0/post_text/0: Iluvien for Adults with non-infectious uveitis. A NICE appraisal.
0/post_text/1: NICE is investigating whether Iluvien is cost effective for uveitis in adults.
0/post_text/2: Iluvien is a steroid micro insert placed into the vitreous (jelly) of the eye. It’s put in as a painless injection. The steroid is released slowly over three years.
0/post_text/3: It will be mostly used for intermediate, pan and posterior uveitis. It is helpful if you keep getting macular oedema, or immune suppressants don’t work, or you can’t tolerate them. Sometimes oral steroid and an immune suppressant are used with it. It has a category C pregnancy risk - it has not been tested for safety in pregnancy but steroid is generally considered the safest uveitis drug to use during pregnancy.  If you’ve already needed several Ozurdex implants (a shorter acting steroid implant) this new insert may be an attractive alternative for you. The main side effects are cataract and raised eye pressure. Raised pressure affects about 34% of Iluvien recipients but this can, mostly, be controlled with pressure lowering drops.
0/post_text/4: Olivia’s Vision is nominating Alison Richards as our patient expert because she has had a very hard time with her uveitis and Iluvien has changed her life. We are also nominating Archana Pradeep as our clinical expert, the uveitis consultant in Nottingham, who is one of our former, successful OV Uveitis Fellowship trainees.
0/post_text/5: Our two experts, and OV, want to give NICE a full picture of the difference Iluvien will make to the vision of people with uveitis and to the quality of life of those with the disease and people close to them. If you have uveitis or you’re close to someone with it, please help us tell NICE everything about uveitis by emailing OV with your comments on any (or all!) of the following:
0/post_text/6: •	What it’s like living with any type of uveitis, either as a patient or someone close to a uveitis patient.
0/post_text/7: •	Vision and quality of life experienced with steroid (the good and the bad) – pills, injections, Ozurdex.
0/post_text/8: •	Vision and quality of life experienced with immune suppressants and adalimumab or other biologics (the good and the bad).
0/post_text/9: •	Whether you would have an Iluvien implant or encourage someone close to you to have one. Reasons?
0/post_text/10: •	If you have taken part in an Iluvien clinical trial, the good (and bad) points for you.
0/post_text/11: Email:
0/post_text/13: If you prefer to talk to OV, please email your phone number and a good time for OV to ring you.
0/post_text/14: The NICE committee meeting, which we will attend, is early March, 2018. If approved, expect it to be funded in the summer of 2018.

0/post_text/0: My daughter (8) was diagnosed with juvenile arthritis at 2, uveitis at 4 and ulcerative colitis at 5 (though I think she's had the UC since age 2 or earlier).  Her JA has been pretty quiet (two flares in six years otherwise no activity).  The UC is now in remission thanks to dietary changes and low dose naltrexone.  But the uveitis has returned and won't go quiet without steroid drops.  She had to start back on Humira and the doctor then upped it to weekly.
1/post_text/1: There are two parents posting on
1/post_text/2: uveitis.org
1/post_text/3: the support site associated with Dr Foster, Renee and Glen. Their daughters are patients of Dr Foster and both girls have been in remission, off drugs, for several years now. The two years without flare is followed by a slow weaning off the drugs which may take about two years. Renee and Glen are probably the people best placed to help you with this question and both respond to others on the parents' forum at
1/post_text/4: uveitis.org
2/post_text/0: Hi Susan,
2/post_text/1: Yes this is the entire point of using these drugs: to attain remission, long term hopefully permanent remission.
2/post_text/2: Prof Will Ayliffe at the Lister Hospital in Chelsea, London follows this very approach, thanks to him and Dr Foster who referred us to him, my daughter has sight.
3/post_text/0: Thanks Maxine, Nicki - We've been told repeatedly that the same drugs won't cure juvenile arthritis or ulcerative colitis (the doctors say that she'll be on them for the rest of her life), so I was surprised to hear that they would "cure" uveitis.   If I can get the JA and UC quiet through dietary changes, then I'll accept a few years on the biologics to control the uveitis if there is hope that we can get her off all meds by the time she reaches teen years.  Dr. Foster didn't mention the slow weaning, but good to know.  I will definitely post my questions on the
0/post_text/1: I took her to see Dr. Foster in Boston for a second opinion and he said we needed to put her on a weekly adult dosage of Humira.  She's small and I really worry about her being on a weekly adult dosage -- not happy about the weekly pediatric dosage.  She was on Methotrexate for five years and Humira for three years and still had break-through uveitis flares, so I am not sure Humira is the right drug.  Anyway, Dr. Foster said we need to be aggressive with Humira or Remicade and do whatever it takes to get her off steroid eye drops.  He repeated this multiple times.  He said if she goes two years on Humira or Remicade without any break-through flares, then we start weaning her off and she will be cured *if* it was the right drug.  I had never heard this before and wondered if anyone else has heard this?
1/post_text/5: . Glen is familiar with the use of humira weekly.
1/post_text/6: Remicade sometimes works when humira doesn't. It has the advantage that dose is more easily adjusted to suit individual need.
1/post_text/7: I doubt any of us, suffers or parents, are happy about the drugs used to keep us sighted. I wish it were simpler and less frightening.

3/post_text/1: Darcy has Anterior Uveitus. It was discovered totally by chance. My husband and I are both short sighted and darcy was complaining of sore heads at school so we took her in to Specsavers for her first eye test. They discovered she has astigmatism in one eye (which she now wears glasses full time to correct) but they also saw that one of her pupil was heart shaped and she was referred to the hospital initially for that. There they then discovered the Uveitus. So it definitely is by chance that we discovered it...then you read that it can bring on glaucoma and cataracts and it doesn't even bear thinking about 😓

0/post_text/0: My daughter was diagnosed with Anterior Uveitis nearly 3 years ago at the age of 10, in her right eye. At that time we were in the process of emigrating to france, and over night our plans changed due to this diagnosis. Since then, we have been through a long process of trying to keep the Uveitus at bay, with very little progress. Ellys Uveitus is Idiopathic, so she has no related inflammatory disease, but now 3 years on, she is still on Maxidex, and has a partial stuck pupil to the cornea that can never be corrected! I feel some hospitals have failed us in some way. The first hospital, took her off the dilation and maxidex drops too quickly to see how her eye would respond without them, and hence thats why her pupil stuck. From there, i then decided to move to another consultant, and to another hospital, and we are still no further in getting her off those awful drops. 5 weeks ago, the consultant told me to take her off the drops again, to see how her eye responds without them, but an appointment last week confirmed, that the eye started to inflame again, and started to get get active cells...we are now back on the maxidex drops!!! I feel that sometimes i dont get any answers from any of these consultants, they tell me that she could have this for the next 10 years, but avoid telling me what damage and the long term effects that the drops will give her. A decision has been made to now seek a second opinion and we have an appointment booked with Professor Ayliffe in 2 weeks to see if she can be offered any other treatment. I feel that she is 13 now,next year she picks her GCSE's, and coming up to some of the most important and crucial years of her life. My fear is that this can come in her other eye too, but every time i ask this, they cannot give me any answers, which i know, but this doesnt make this any easier. My husband has a very different approach to me, sometimes i think he buries his head in the sand, has only been to a few appointments with me, not because he isnt a great dad, which he is, and loves Elly very much, but just doesnt get the seriousness of this. I have insisted that he comes with me to see Professor Ayliffe, hopefully he will tell it straight, not beat around the bush, and maybe then my husband, will understand. I know Elly is lucky that she only has this in one eye, and she is currently well (apart from bad hypermobility, where she was treated at Gosh for at their clinic) and to look at her you would never know that anything was wrong. This doesnt stop the pain and suffering we go through as parents, and as a mother.....you just want it to go away, and know their future will be as best as you can hope for.

0/post_text/0: Hi, I was told last week at our 3 month eye check, that the surface of my daughter's eyes are very dry, and it may be due to blepharitis,(inflammation of the eyelids interfering with the tear production). I had not imagined inflammation affecting these, he said to use a lubricating eye drop if it continues to feel uncomfortable, which I will buy today as she is saying it feels like there is something in her eye now, and I can't see anything. Last week at Gosh for her JIA infusion the reg said he would ask their opthalmologist to see her when we go again in 4 weeks or 8 weeks. Does anyone else have any experience of this ?? Thanks, Anita
1/post_text/1: Yes, it's not uncommon for dry eyes to go along with other autoimmune issues. I've now learnt to use lubricating eye drops if I start to worry about a uveitis flare in one of my eyes - and often my symptoms go away with that! The best ones to use are the single use vials as they don't have preservatives which may also irritate the eyes. I hope the irritation in your daughter's eyes subsides!
1/post_text/2: Take care,
1/post_text/3: -Anke

2/post_text/1: Having just read Anke's post I think I'm redundant!  I can only agree!
2/post_text/2: Take care
3/post_text/0: Hi Anita,
4/post_text/0: Hi,
4/post_text/1: Dry eyes are very common with all of the autoimmune illnesses, and if there is dryness in the mouth, throat, skin, and nose ( sometimes can cause nasal sores too) it's worth having a check to see if there are Sjogrens antibodies present, as Sjogrens syndrome happens secondary quite often to RA and other similar rheumatological illnesses. It does cause blepharitis too. It is also very common to feel as if there is something stuck in the eye, and despite the corneal dryness, Sjogrens can make your eyes water too!
4/post_text/2: I hope by now that things have improved for your daughter
4/post_text/3: best of luck, and keep us informed about how you get on

2/post_text/3: Nicki
3/post_text/1: It's happened to me too - coincided with the use of multiple eye drops, all with preservative. If your daughter is using lots of drops each day, it's just as likely to be the preservative in those drops causing the problem as an auto immune problem. You could ask about preservative free steroid drops. I use Celluvisc lubricating drops. These are single dose, don't contain preservative and stocked in Tesco. (You have to ask for them at the pharmacy counter).

0/post_text/1: I have an 11 year old daughter Tanisha who has JIA and uveitis along with hypermobility,glaucoma and is now forming a cataract in her left eye.
0/post_text/2: She was diagnosed not long before her 3rd birthday with JIA after nearly a year of doctors telling me there was nothing wrong with her,this was my first battle in her care and there have been a few more since then! Not only with doctors and nurses there have been teachers,social services,the council(obtaining a blue badge),not to mention the endless forms for DLA.This condition is draining emotionally and at times can be overwhelming without having to fight for support in school etc. Never give up if you think you are entitled to something and never hesitate to ask for more info or to question your doc/consults course of action.We have done the eye drops to the point where i had to put a chart on the wall for each eye to keep track of them and thankfully are well past the days when i had to pin her to the floor to give her them,where ever we were including the middle of sainsburys! She has had 2 surgery's for the glaucoma about 4yrs ago and it now seems well controlled,she has had numerous steroid injections to her joints and currently she is taking methotrexate by wkly injection,folic acid tabs and nurofen when needed. At the moment everything seems fairly settled so the methotrexate seems to be working. One area where i think there isn't much support is the impact this has not only on the parent but also the child.I know i've gone from mother on a mission on the way to appointments to a crumbling heap once i've put her to bed. I've sat and listened to my daughter at the age of 7 or 8 asking me if this condition will kill her, will she be able to have children and will she go blind my heart would break knowing these are things she has thought about. Outwardly she copes very well with her condition but i know there are a lot of emotions going on inside its a constant battle for our kids too,from putting up with treatments,endless appointments to teasing in school and trying to fit in which i think most kids of her age find difficult enough without all the extras! This is why i think this site is so fantastic not only has it given me the chance to talk to other parents but it has enabled Tanisha to find Olivia, tho they haven't spoken as yet she is so excited to be able to meet someone the same age as her who shares the same battles. I'm hoping they will become good friends and can offer some support to each other in between chatting about Justin Bieber lol.

0/post_text/1: I'm glad I found this website, as my daughter was diagnosed with uveitis last Friday. She first started having symptoms of exhaustion late last year. We were out one evening in February, and she complained of a sore wrist, and her hands went grey and purple. The duty GP suspected Raynauds and ordered blood tests and a rheumatology referral.
0/post_text/2: The initial bloods only showed hypothyroidism, and repeat bloods were requested four weeks later, in which her hypothyroidism had worsened and her thyroid antibodies were extremely high. She was started on thyroxine.
1/post_text/5: Do let us know how you get on in the coming weeks,
0/post_text/3: The same day as the blood tests, she complained of a sore right knee, and the GP identified a swelling on her knee. This effusion was confirmed by ultrasound a few days later. We were repeatedly told it was most likely a post-infectious inflammation and it would go away. This hasn't happened and almost all of her joints are now painful.
0/post_text/4: At the same time as the joint pains, she complained of stinging eyes and shapes in front of her eyes. Rheumatology told us to take her to an optician, who did various checks and said she was fine and it was just normal floaters, but made an opthamology referral anyway. She had her initial appointment last Friday, and she has bilateral chronic uveitis, which so far is quite mild and has not damaged her sight.
0/post_text/5: She was reviewed by the opthamologist at the rheumatology clinic on Thursday, and they no longer think it is juvenile arthritis, which was the focus of their initial investigations, but a systemic inflammatory condition. She had loads more blood tests taken, a chest x-ray, and she will have an ECG in two weeks.
0/post_text/6: Since the first opthamology appointment six days before, her uveitis had worsened in her left eye (it was initially worse in the right eye). She has been started on Maxidex drops until the results of the tests come back, as the rheumatologist doesn't want her on steroids which may mask the condition which is causing all her problems.
0/post_text/7: She struggles to walk to and from school, to get up into bed, and has constant pain. She hardly ever complains though. I didn't realise the extent of her eye problems because she loves reading, and is a fantastic reader. Even when they told us it was uveitis, I didn't realise it was a fairly rare problem in children, and this site has been really useful in getting my head around what she is dealing with. She is being millions more brave than I am. She is so little to be going through so much. It has been a confusing and stressful journey so far. She is in the hands of a very, very good team now, but having gone from being almost entirely dismissed as post-viral by her GP, to all the unknowns right now, is a lot to deal with.

0/post_text/0: What does "pale optic nerve" mean for uveitis sufferers?
1/post_text/0: Is it permanent? Does it have any bearing on sight?
2/post_text/0: Damage to the optic nerve is not usually reversible.
2/post_text/1: Many nerve fibres make up the optic nervehead and it depends on what has caused the damage as well as the nerve fibres affected whether there is bearing on sight. Various tests can be conducted to determine this.
2/post_text/2: As Nicki said, you need to ring the doctor who observed this and ask for explanation.
3/post_text/0: Apparently the damage is presumed to be due to prolonged, uncontrolled inflammation and secondary intraoccular pressures. The opthamologist Finally is starting him on a plan to reduce and eventually (hopefully, depending on his reaction) eliminate pred forte.
4/post_text/0: I hope the weaning off Pred goes well. Were they able to tell you if Braiden's sight has been affected by the damage?
5/post_text/0: They weren't able to say much of anything. They say his vision loss could be scarring, could be atrophy, could be because his brain forgot to see properly from being blind too long, could be any number of things I guess...
6/post_text/0: Hope the new plan goes well. I'll keep my fingers crossed for you both that his sight improves. x

3/post_text/1: The chest x-ray is standard. For most of us  it's used to find out if certan auto immune conditions might be present and also to check for signs of TB. In your case, there is an additional reason for the x-ray.
3/post_text/2: Inflammation at the back of the eye is more serious than inflammation at the front of the eye, but there are some effective treatments for it these days. The blood tests and x-ray may reveal a cause and that will help in the choice of further treatment if it's needed. Since you have had uveitis before, you're in the waiting game period to see if it resolves and to find out if there is a cause that requires treatment.
3/post_text/3: If you experience anything unusual happening with your sight in the next two weeks, it's important that you go back in.
5/post_text/1: Checking for are the important words - I found the 'checking for' really stressful. You sound much more relaxed than I was!
3/post_text/4: Being able to continue working helps a lot and it's good that your colleagues and employers are so understanding.
3/post_text/5: Please keep posting and let us know how you're doing.
5/post_text/2: Hope you see some improvement in your eyes before your next appointment.

1/post_text/1: It sounds as though you have quite a lot going on in your eyes and five flare ups of anterior uveitis in one year must have been trying, to say the least.
1/post_text/2: Steroid pills are often effective for the back of the eye, but as you write, unpleasant to take. You may have already gone for your appointment now, but I'd be inclined to ask what type of treatment will be used in the future and if your uveitis with retinal vasculitis requires treatment to prevent future flare ups, rather than being treated when flareups occur. A long term plan can go some way to easing worry.
1/post_text/3: Not wanting to worry those around us when we're worried ourselves is understandable but I think those closest to you will notice the effects of high dose steroid. Some people feel brilliant on it, others don't. Even if you don't pass on worry about your eyes and sight, it might be helpful for your husband to know something of the side effects of steroid.
1/post_text/4: I'm sorry that you have this disease and I hope after today's appointment you have a clearer idea of what comes next. My own uveitis had similarities with yours, but I still see and drive today.

0/post_text/3: I have been diagnosed with bilateral anterior uveitis approximately 2 years ago (February 2010) after suffering from photophobia and painful red eyes. My vision was blurry too. I was put on pred forte for about 2 months without any improvement. I sought another doctor for a second opinion and I was told to have intermediate uveitis as well as anterior uveitis in both eyes. I had done all the required investigations and all were negative. I was advised to have steroid injections in my eyes. I was asymptomatic at that time so I refused the injections. After a short while I came to the UK to study a master’s degree. I had another flare up of my uveitis and I was referred to Moorfield's eye hospital by my GP. I was put on Maxidex eye drops and was told that I don't need the injections anymore. I was also diagnosed with chronic retinal vasculitis which I didn't need treatment for because it was not active.  In the past year I have had 5 flare ups of my anterior uveitis and was on and off the maxidex and the dilating drops. I consider myself lucky because I don't usually have any symptoms when I flare up except for one time where I had floaters, but it's also a disadvantage because the inflammation can get really bad without me noticing. That’s why I have frequent follow ups more than other patients.
0/post_text/4: I had a follow up appointment last week where my doctor suspected my retinal vasculitis to be active again. I had a fluorescein angiogram done and it showed that my vessels are inflamed and leaking. The doctor prescribed me oral steroids for the first time but she suggested I get investigated for TB and sarcaidosis before starting on the steroids- although she's suspecting it to be idiopathic but just in case. I started developing floaters and my vision is a bit blurry but the blurriness improves when I wear my glasses.
0/post_text/5: I'm going back again tomorrow to know the results and get my steroid prescription.
0/post_text/6: I'm so glad that I have done my master’s degree before all of this have started. I'm applying for a PhD degree now and I hope the floaters and the blurred vision doesn't get in the way.
2/post_text/5: I'll start the prednisolone tomorrow and I’ll see how it goes. Fingers crossed.

Hi, my name is Marie, I am 51 years old.  I had my first attack of Uveitis 10 years ago. I hadn't realised that the clouded vision to my right eye was serious until I developed severe pain and throbbing in it (I thought I had a sinus infection).  I fortunately live near one of the country's leading eye infirmary's and was referred to the A & E department by my Optician after he had examined me.  This was where I was first diagnosed, my Iris had stuck to the eye lens and has left a scar to this day.  I was immediately started on Pred Forte  and 2 hourly mydriatic drops.  I had to return after a few days to have the inflammation cells counted.  Luckily? as I am a steroid respondent the drops worked really well therefore the attack was quickly cleared up.

0/post_text/1: I had no further problems util 6 years ago, after a seriously stressful time of my life (I lost my beautiful 25 year old daughter).  Since that time, I have had recurrent attacks (now bialateral) of Uveitis.  The frequent use of Pred Forte caused Cataracts, these were removed from both eyes 3 years ago.  Glaucoma was my next visitor, it came so quickly - even though I was monitored  very regularly, "spikes" of increased pressure caused considerable permanent vision loss to my right eye - I had to have an emergency operation to have a "bleb" drain inserted in my eyeball to prevent further damage, 3 months later this occurred in my left eye requiring a "bleb" to that eye too - in the meantime (and still am) having to take the Prednisone drops (now preservative free as my eyes have become very sensitive after all of the various steroids, antibiotics etc) and tablets to control the flare ups!  After a year on 60mg of steroids and various attempts to taper, to no avail without another raise in inflammation - I have started immunosuppressant treatment to try and put me in remission, I am only 2 weeks into the course of treatment so early days and fingers crossed. I am terrified that I will end up losing all my sight (I now have a certificate of severe sight impairment), driving license now gone too. I am sure people look at me and think there is nothing wrong!  This is a horrible disease which I hadn't even heard of and hadn't realised the seriousness of it when I had my first attack. 5/post_text/2: I'm glad you've had a visit from Action for the Blind and I hope this group will be able to help you stay in work. Another group which will help is the Macular Disease Society which is very well versed in the law and in keeping their visually impaired members in work. A lady who works for them was in touch with us recently and told us that our members would be welcome to make use of the Society's expertise in this area. You find their webpage here:

5/post_text/4: and there is a helpline number on that homepage.
5/post_text/5: Depending on your degree of visual impairment and the progressive nature of sight loss that comes with glaucoma (if this applies in your case), you may be referred to social services. From my own experience with social services during a period of blindness, the help offered may not be the help you expect. They are excellent in helping you overcome the problems of visual impairment in daily life, getting you out and about, helping you adapt to loss of sight and helping you apply for the DLA allowance. However, if you are over fifty, you may have to make clear that you want to continue working, you want to learn how to use adaptive software and/or learn braille. Assumptions are too readily made concerning work and those aged over 50 when visual impairment strikes. Having made a bit of a song and dance about working, (couldn't see my feet at the time!)I was offered a general IT course at the local college. Most local authorities have web pages which detail the help given by social services to the blind and visually impaired.
5/post_text/6: I hope next week's bone scan shows the Adcal has been protective.

2/post_text/0: How to use Lubricant Eye Drops
2/post_text/1: Follow all directions on the product package. If you are uncertain about any of the information, consult your doctor or pharmacist. Do not use a solution that has changed color or is cloudy. Certain brands (containing glycerin with polysorbates, among other ingredients) may have a milky appearance. This is okay as long as the solution does not change color. Some eye drops need to be shaken before use. Check the label to see if you should shake your product before using.
2/post_text/2: Usually, drops may be used as often as needed. Ointments are usually used 1 to 2 times daily as needed. If using an ointment once a day, it may be best to use it at bedtime.
3/post_text/0: Hello
2/post_text/3: To apply eye ointment/drops/gels: Wash hands first. To avoid contamination, be careful not to touch the dropper or top of the ointment tube or let it touch your eye. Always replace the cap tightly after each use. Tilt your head back, look up, and pull down the lower eyelid to make a pouch. For drops/gels, place the dropper directly over the eye and squeeze out 1 or 2 drops as needed. Look down and gently close your eye for 1 or 2 minutes. Place one finger at the corner of the eye near the nose and apply gentle pressure. This will prevent the medication from draining away from the eye. For an ointment, hold the tube directly over the eye and gently squeeze a small strip (one-fourth of an inch or roughly 6 millimeters) of ointment into the pouch. Release the eyelid, close the eye, and slowly roll your eye in all directions to spread the medication. Blot away any extra ointment from around the eye with a clean tissue.

0/post_text/0: Hi all,
1/post_text/1: Horrible position to be in.
1/post_text/2: If your eye is inflamed, surgery is a risk and perhaps this is why your ophthalmologist is holding back. Ideally, eyes are inflammation free for three months before surgery. If your eye isn't, a discussion about how to get it inflammation free and fit for surgery is needed.
1/post_text/3: If it is inflammation free and has been for several months, then yes, push for the surgery but I'm not sure how far the NHS takes personal circumstances into consideration when scheduling surgery. Cataract surgery seems to scheduled according to visual acuity. With the type of cataract we get, visual acuity can be reasonably good in the clinic but outside is a very different matter. It might help your case to describe in a lot of detail the ways in which your sight is affected.
1/post_text/4: Another OV member who was in the same position as you had exactly the same problems with sight when one eye had a cataract. There is not much you can do apart from shutting the cataract eye and that's probably scary with it being your right eye when driving.
2/post_text/0: Hi Renee
2/post_text/1: I completely sympathise with your position having been there myself.  It was agreed to operate on my cataract, fairly early on but they could not because the inflammation from uveitis was not under control.  It took a long time to get it under control and have four months free of inflammation by which time I could not see in that eye.  Given you are still on steroid drops it will only get worse - just wondering why you are still on steroid drops after so long and another option is not being looked at given it looks as though you are also on a drop for raised pressure.  I wonder if you should be questioning this first as no doubt a cataract op will inflame your eye as even non uveitis patients get inflammation after surgery.  After this I would most certainly push for the op as I know how miserable it is not seeing in one eye - everyone just assumes that because one eye sees fine this is ok but having experienced it I know how this is just not true.  I also found it so hard to drive and work.  When I had myop done I was on immunosuppresants and it only flared up briefly then settled back down pretty quickly.
3/post_text/0: Hi Renee
4/post_text/0: Hi there,
4/post_text/1: I am so sorry your going through this.
4/post_text/2: I just received my cataract surgery even though my eyes were still inflamed. I ended up with really high pressure and my eyes were even worse. My doctor during the surgery gave me a steroid injection as well as a steroid drip in hope of the uveitis staying at bay but unfortunately it didn't.
4/post_text/3: I totally understand your frustrations but unless it's absolutely necessary don't have the surgery unless your uveitis has settled for a few months.
5/post_text/0: Update - I had my cataract surgery on 10 December, and after taking a whole raft of drops initially I'm now just back on the pred forte, currently on 3 drops a days and slowly reducing back to my maintenance dose of 1 drop a day. All seems good at the moment; there are a few cells in my eye but nothing major and everything has healed well. I managed to get the surgery done through the public system in the end, and although I was told it could be up to 4 months wait, it was only a month after I went on the list that I got my surgery. It took me a while to adjust to the new dual focus, and I had a bit of "strobe" effect initially, but it's all looking pretty good at the moment.
6/post_text/0: Thanks for letting us know you're doing well, Renee. So glad you only waited a month once on the list. We had a talk on the surgery and a video of the actual surgery at the last Birmingham patient group meeting and our specialists said they take a lot of notice of how cataract sight is affecting daily life to help them decide when to schedule the surgery.
6/post_text/1: Sounds like you've adapted to the dual focus really well and all the best getting back to that one drop a day, and even off it!
0/post_text/1: I have had chronic uveitis in my right eye (auto-immune related) since September 2012, and have been on and off (mostly on) pred-forte and hysite since. Predicatbly, I've developed a subcapsular posterior cataract in my right eye, which is get blurrier quite rapidly and causing me issues with computer work (my full time job) and night driving in particular.
0/post_text/2: At my last appointment, my opthalmologist said he wouldn't refer me for surgery yet as my vision was not sufficiently affected to make the benefits outweigh the risks. But with all the things I'm now struggling with, including headaches that ibuprofen doesn't really touch, and having dented the back of my car due to warping of my distance judgement, I think I should push for it. I'm 35, work full time, have a 6 year old daughter, and a decent commute - so surely that should be taken into consideration?

Hi! My name is Anna and my 12 year old son Filip was diagnosed with uveitis in April.All started in January when Filip got conjutctivitis and after that we noticed that something is wrong with his right eye.We waited more than 3 months for consultation with ophtalmologist.After few visits and blood tests all I heard is "Inflammation". In July the paediatrician said that Filip has uveitis.So then I begun my research.Later we were send to Cambridge hospital to see different ophtalmologist.Filip was on steroids (drops and tablets).The final diagnosis was,that there is nothing they can do,he will loose his eyesight eventually and he need to be on steroids drops all the time.I was shocked!Then I heard about Professor Ayliffe and made an appointment.Now Filip is on methotextrate,has his first dose on Saturday and so far he is feeling good.I'm so glad for this website to give all the information and support!
1/post_text/1: Welcome to the forum. Sorry you have had to join us.
1/post_text/2: So pleased that you took Filip to Prof Ayliffe and something is being done. Do you know the type of uveitis Filip has and have any tests been done to find a cause for it?
1/post_text/3: With you getting Filip under the care of Prof Ayliffe, you have given your son the best chance of keeping his sight for life. Thank goodness you researched and did that.
1/post_text/4: I hope Filip copes with the methotrexate and I hope it controls his inflammation. Please tell Filip 'Good luck' from the adult members here.
2/post_text/0: Hi Maxine!
2/post_text/1: Filip has Idiopathic chronic anterior uveitis in his right eye.Also he developed cataract.His blood was tested twice.First time in Welwyn Garden City hospital and second one in Cambridge hospital.All came back normal.As far I know there were tests for:toxoplazma,toxocara immunoglobulins,ANCA and ESR and other.Also chest X-Ray was done.
2/post_text/2: It is very hard for me,as I don't understand medical words they are using,and also its difficult to find translation.
3/post_text/0: Hi Anna,
4/post_text/0: Welcome, Anna! I am so greatful that you have found a doctor who will treat Filip. I hope you will find this group helpful. There is a lot of information and support here.

6/post_text/2: Fingers crossed Filip had a bug last week and normality is resumed, but if not the tablets should really help.  Hope your shoulder is also less painful today.

3/post_text/1: I'm so sorry that your son has been diagnosed, but so pleased he is no longer under a doctor who was resigned to letting him go blind, I'm shocked that this was their attitude, and also very scared for all of the other patients still being seen by this doctor.
3/post_text/2: There is a glossary on the website to help with medical terms, but please feel free to ask on the forum if the definitions are still difficult to understand and we'll try and explain them in a different way.
