5/post_text/1: Sorry for late reply,but it seems as we are having very bad year.First Filip's uveitis and now I got trapped nerve in my shoulder-very painful!
7/post_text/1: First of all-well done Olivia!This video is amazing!Both me and Filip had tears in our eyes when we were watching!
8/post_text/1: Glad you like the video, it will be going on YouTube and FB, Twitter etc next week.
8/post_text/2: School can be such a problem!  O was stopped from taking her Tac the other day by a teacher who refused to let her bring a bottle of water into his classroom!  I was so angry.
8/post_text/3: Olivia was on 20mg of mtx the past 18 months but her dose has recently been reduced to a holding dose of 10mg as it does nothing for her except make her sick!  The 8mg of Tacrolimus is what makes the difference to her eyes.  As a word of warning Olivia did actually lose a lot of her hair on 20mg, many people just experience a little thinning, she was particularly unlucky.
10/post_text/1: welcome to the forum! My daughter also has anterior uveitis in the right eye, and is also under Professor Ayliffe. (our kids have been chatting here on the kids forum, Elly has tried to reassure your son that all will be okay!)After 3 painful years with Elly, and going to 2 different hospitals that certainly would have made her blind in her right eye, are now thankfully getting the right treatment she needs through Ayliffe.We were also never told that elly had a catarax by the last hospital (they obviously never felt the need to tell us!!) We know that if he cant help her, there is certainly knowone that can!Elly is on 22.5mg methatrexate, as well as 200mg of ciclosporin twice a day now. She has also just finished a course of oral steriods, which made her really ill, something she doesnt want to ever take again!
10/post_text/2: Like filip, when elly started the chemo, she was really ill, she couldnt even lift her head off the pillow, slept all the time, and i think for the first 6 - 8 weeks hardly went to school. i can only feel for you, i know the pain you are going through, the anxiety, and the upset watching your child go through so much pain. I think i slept with elly most nights for weeks and weeks. At the time, not alot of her friends knew she was sick, and a crowd at school, were nasty and mean, it was a painful time all round.
10/post_text/3: Believe me it does get better!!! It may not seem like it now, but it does, the anxiety and stress of it all doesnt fade, but you learn to cope with it better as the days go on. We still have days ( like tonight!!) that i sleep in her bed with her, she just feels more comfortable that i am with her....its hard going!
3/post_text/4: How is your son doing on the Mtx?  If he feels sick you can get a prescription for tablets which will help, they're called Ondansetron and come in two strengths: 4mg and 8mg.  My 11 year old daughter takes the stronger dose 2 or 3 times a day for two days to reduce the nausea.
3/post_text/5: I'm so pleased Filip is now under Prof Ayliffe he's wonderful and will fight like crazy to save your son's sight.
5/post_text/2: After two doses of Mtx Filip was feeling absolutely fine,but now after third dose he is being sick for two days now and I was called to pick him up from school.
5/post_text/3: So I'm waiting for my GP to call me back and hopefully get prescription for some any-sickness drug.
7/post_text/2: So definitely not bug.We got prescription for Ondansetron 4mg and we had to do "emergency" blood test.
7/post_text/3: So far Filip was sick on Tuesday,Wednesday and Thursday,but only in the morning after breakfast and it lasted only 2 hours so its still not bad.
7/post_text/4: Had problem with school as his form tutor didn't pass my letter about chemotherapy to other teachers,so on Wednesday I received three phone calls from three different members of school staff about his treatment.
7/post_text/5: One lady even asked me if Filip will loose his hairs and what type of cancer he is having :-)
8/post_text/4: Hope the ondansetron does the trick, if 4mg doesn't work double up to 8mg on one of the doses and see if this helps.  During her sickest phase O was on 8mg 2x a day plus 4mg 2x a day spread over an 18 hour period, and then the same again the next day.  You'll just have to play around with the dose and timings to find out what works best for Filip
10/post_text/4: After after nearly 6 months, i have finally persuaded elly to change to chemo injections, as her stomach aches have got very bad, hopefully once i learn how to inject her myself, all these horrible symptoms may get less.
11/post_text/1: Thank you very much for your comforting messages.
11/post_text/2: Filip at the moment is full of anger.I don't know is it because of drugs or hormones,but he keep asking me,why this happened to him! Keep telling me that he lost his will to live and wants to die! And I can't really find the answer for myself,why this happened to my perfectly healthy boy!
12/post_text/1: There have been some cases of gum disease and tooth infection being considered as possible causes of uveitis, but again without thorough research who knows.  Anything that causes the immune system to go into overdrive can cause uveitis, we just don't know why it only happens in certain people - ie what makes them susceptible and others not.
12/post_text/2: I'm so sorry Filip is feeling so awful.  The mtx is, in my opinion, responsible for a lot of negative emotions.  O is constantly angry at the world, and I also never know whether it's hormones...It's so difficult trying to work out what's normal pre teen behaviour and what's the meds.
13/post_text/2: Rising a teenager is quite a challenge for me :-) find it very difficult sometime but also very funny.
13/post_text/3: Not very easy to be a single mum with a boy,but Filip is a very good child most of the time so I consider myself lucky!
13/post_text/4: What about E-bay? Filip is selling some old stuff and wanted to donate money trough Ebay,but Olivia's Vision is not listed as a charity there,so he was very disappointed :-(
13/post_text/5:
Hate and mistrust are the children of blindness.
William Watson
10/post_text/5: The ciclosporin, has made elly very hairy, i have had to resort to all sorts of waxing, and hair removal creams, lucky its coming up to the winter time, at least she can cover up!
10/post_text/6: We also have had all the blood tests, and nothing is connected to ellys uveitis, although, at the moment, she is finding it very hard to walk, some days, i find her crawling up and down the stairs, or limping, so this is something i am going to have to now investigate further.
10/post_text/7: I hope filip starts to cope better on the drugs, its still early days, just have to try and stay strong, and have hope. I watched the video on here for the first time tonight, and also was in tears, its just so close to all our hearts.
10/post_text/8: I hope this has all helped, and please tell filip, if he wants to chat again to Elly, she is more than happy to answer any of his questions, or anxieties he has....
10/post_text/9: keep well, and stay strong, your doing great, keep telling yourself that!
11/post_text/3: I'm trying to stay positive and strong even when I have to deal with it alone as my whole family is in Poland.
11/post_text/4: I posted link to Olivia's video on my Facebook page and asked all my Facebook friends to watch it.Did the same at my work :-)
5/post_text/4: Also we are waiting for the blood tests results to come back.
5/post_text/5: I'm little bit down with all this.Filip missed many school days and he only started secondary school in September,I have to take days off from my work for all the appointments and now I'm having physiotherapy on the top of all that. 24 hours and 7 days its not enough time for me for all this :-(

15/post_text/1: I'm sorry to hear about the problems you and your son are coping with its so heartbreaking to read your story. I too have a daughter who suffers with this dreadful condition and she recently underwent glaucoma surgery as a result of high pressure caused by all the steroid drops. She is having such a hard time at the moment and at times refuses to leave the house because she is so self concious. We hope in time things will settle down.
15/post_text/2: You mentioned a girl in Poland having something wrong with her teeth that may have caused the uveitis, this caught my attention because I have always said my daughters inflammation problems seemed to start around the exact time when she had some dental work done but was dismissed as co-incidence by the doctors. 1/post_text/0: I have to say that your symptoms don't sound unusal side effects for oral steriods. My son (who does not have uveitis) but asthma occasionally has to have oral steriods and he jumps off walls and cannot sleep. Extreme emotions, steriod highs and lows are well documented for intravenous steriods. It sounds extreme for eye drops but small amounts will enter your blood stream, there is some trick where you cover or press your eyes near your nose to close your tear ducks when you do they eye drop. There are other eye drops Lotemax but contains less steriod than Pred forte or Maxidex. So therefore, maybe  less effective in the short term.
1/post_text/1: There are other treatments which dampen the immune systems but only 8 flares since 1998 it doesn't sound necessary. It is normally only considered when uveitis is chronic.
1/post_text/2: Maybe what you are experiencing is just normal for you, particularly if you have experienced it before, and you'll just have to ride the storm.  Don't know about mydrilate. I'd have a close read of all side effects listed. Sorry not to be more helpful. Just as an observation most drugs nearly always list heart palpitations and anxiety or shakes as a side effect.

When there is an obvious problem with glaucoma eye drops getting into the blood stream, why should steroid drops be any different as far as side effects go?
2/post_text/4: You have my sympathy. It's a pity that the non steroidal anti inflammatory drops aren't much good for uveitis.
3/post_text/1: Thanks so much for your reply. I got a call back from the drug info line at Moorfields and they said it could be the Mydrilate as it can cause psychological effects and told me to go to Moorfields A&E - They also thought it would be unlikely to be the Maxidex.
3/post_text/2: Just got back and they've told me to stop the Mydrilate and Maxidex. Starting Lotemax tomorrow. The Uveitis is very mild so I don't need the dilation. The doctor also said he thought it unlikely to be the Maxidex but I did mention that maybe I'm hyper sensitive and he agreed it could be a possibility. He also mentioned that next time I get a flare I could try something that is non steroidal, similar to Ibuprofen. I'l definitely give it a go.
3/post_text/3: Another bit of information I found out is, the dilation drops they use to examine have the same or a similar ingredient to sudafed which I've also had a bad time on.
5/post_text/1: Hope the Lotemax is giving you a calmer day! Your information about mydrilate made me shiver - used that for about 18 months.
7/post_text/1: It was a preventative measure for one eye since immunosuppressants were not fully stopping the inflammation and the pupil stuck at one point. Mydrilate three times a day for a week bounced it free, so continued twice a day until cataract surgery.
8/post_text/1: I definitely have had side effects with maxidex when I had to put them in every 2 hours recently.  Not so bad during the day but at night my heart was racing and I could not sleep and felt agitated but I knew it was the drops as I have taken oral steroids before with the same effect although more severe.  If you press the inside of your nose when you put the drops in, it definitely helps as it does not enter your system as severely.   Some of the consultants will dismiss it at Moorfields but I have to say mine does agree it certainly can have this effect given it is basically entering your system.  I don't use any other drops so I knew it was absolutely this and it went away when I stopped the drops.  I think when you don't know what is causing it the anxiety of not knowing what it is definitely makes it worse I found, still annoying though trying to get to sleep when your heart keeps racing.
10/post_text/1: I have had non steroidal drops like Acular but unfortunately they alone were not strong enough to do very much for me although they did not cause side effects.  Are you taking any other medication that oould contribute to this?  I get a similar effect from pain killers with coedine and coupled with the steroids it's a disaster.  How many drops are you putting in a day?  I think they also have an accumulative effect on the body and for sensitive people it takes a while to leave the system, although I know doctors will dismiss this because it is not 'text book'.

12/post_text/1: I completely sympathise with this as I absolutely hate all forms of steroids both drops and oral because of the ghastly side effects I too have esperienced.  If you can hang on in there until the flare has calmed down it would be better as the options if non steroidal drops don't work are systemic drugs.  I am not sure if you have uveitis in both eyes, if so of course you have double the amount going in your system.  I have it in one eye but 6 drops a day was enough to keep me up all night with heart beating fast and give me anxiety.  You may find by tomorrow with lotemax which is really not as strong it will calm down.  I wish I could be more helpful but if it gets you through a flare without having to take systemic drugs try to get through it as this in my opinion is better,  so long as you do not take the drops for too long.

0/post_text/0: My daughter Kirsty now 8, has been receiving treatment for idiopathic Uveitis since it was diagnosed following a routine eye test at Nursery. She has coped brilliantly with the endless different treatment including a major eye op for Secondary Glaucoma due to excessive steroid drops. She is now receiving 15mg Methotrexate by weekly injection topped up by Pred Forte whenever inflammation appears. My wife and I are being advised to seek other forms of treatment including Adalimumab and Infliimab, we would be keen to hear from any other parents with experience of these drugs.

0/post_text/0: just had a letter from doctors with jacks blood results and it says jack has secondary glaucoma .They never mentioned that to me in the appointment.
1/post_text/1: Glaucoma (optical hypertension) is the result of pressure buildup in the eye. Because the inside of the eye is effectively a closed vessel this pressure buildup can reduce the flow of blood to the retina and the optic nerve entering the eye.
1/post_text/2: In this instance it is likely that the cause is the use of corticosteroid treatment. They can give you drops to control the pressure. It should not pose a serious problem.
1/post_text/3: I have had a genetic form of glaucoma since I was 40 and been on treatment for 20 years and suffered no eye damage at all in this time. Even though I have been on corticosteroid drops for 8 months the pressures have remained good. The treatments are very good and they should control the pressures adequately.
1/post_text/4: Hope this reassures you.
2/post_text/0: Hi Caron,
2/post_text/1: With what you have written about Jack's treatments, the secondary glaucoma is probably Jack's high eye pressure which is already being treated by the xalatan and the other glaucoma drop you've mentioned.
2/post_text/2: There is a difference between high ocular pressure and glaucoma. High ocular pressure over a period of time can cause damage to the optic nerve. This damage can be seen on examination and through high quality OCTs. I think your doctors would have told you if Jack's optic nerve had been damaged by the high pressure and he now had glaucoma.

1/post_text/5: Regards
2/post_text/3: I think what is described in the letter is what you already know - high pressure caused by steroid, not actual glaucoma. Lots of people, and some doctors, call high pressure which needs treatment with drops, glaucoma. It can be confusing.

0/post_text/0: Hi, I wanted to introduce myself and maybe see if anyone can give me any info? By the way thank goodness for sites like yours i don't know what i would do without the info you provide. I'm 30 yrs old and I was diagnosed with Iritis in febuary. It came on all of a sudden and id never even heard of it. I'm currently on my 6th flare up since feb, this doesn't include every time i have one it goes over to the other eye. Each time i have either just maxidex (1st time Predforte) or maxidex and the dilating drops. The last time i had a flare up i was in so much pain i went to a normal A&E as our Eye Hospital A&E here in B'ham closes at 7pm and i begged them to give me pain relief in tears as they didn't stock steroid eye drops and it was late at night, they couldn't help. I had to wait until the next morning to get help! Worst night of my life! I've had blood tests for everything they say is connected and they cant find any underlying cause as to why I have this and so suddenly also it just wont go. Other than this im mostly healthy apart from IBS. The most i've been all clear with Iritis is about 3 weeks since feb. Its really upsetting me now, so what i'm wondering is do you know of anything I can do? Any suggestions at all! Any treatment, anyone i can see? I surely cant have this constant? My husband and I also want to start a family but I'm worried about the medication. This is all really new to me and reading a few things on this website has helped because the doctors cant seem to answer my questions so i'm hoping for help here? They have told me i must just have it stand alone with an unknown cause.
0/topic_title: Recurring Iritis with no known cause.
1/post_text/1: Sorry to hear that your iritis has been so persistant. I think the majority of cases do not have a cause. People may be able to give you some advice about asking for anti-TNF drugs which can be used in some long term cases. These are a problem though if trying for a baby as they do not like you being on them due to them being a relatively new drug and not knowing the long term effects on pregnancy. I think steroid drops in the eyes are good for not getting into the blood stream so are ok.
1/post_text/2: Coming from a someone that had uveitis related to AS, I have also read quite a lot about the other related auto-immune diseases. Mild Crohns can sometimes be mistaken for IBS and there are cases of people developing Uveitis that suffer from Chrohn's so it might be worth mentioning your IBS to the Dr and seeing if they think there could be a connection? Just a thought.
1/post_text/3: I was given 3 bottles of steroid drops and one bottle of dilating on my first prescription. So I had a spare bottle of unopend steriod drops at the end of treatment when I was clear 2 1/2 months later. I keep them stored just incase (it is important they are unopened). Maybe it would be worth asking them to prescribe an extra bottle next time you go explaining your reason? I think with your eyes flaring they will be happy to do this for you and means you will not be in pain if it flares at the wrong time.
1/post_text/4: I'm sure someone who knows more will be along to offer some advice soon x

3/post_text/0: Hi Kerry. It is possible to get a false negative reading with Celiac tests. i.e one could be Celiac yet still test negative for it. Eliminating Gluten from your diet over a trial period is usually the best way to identify any sensitivities. If no improvements are seen or only slight improvements are had, it might then be worth cutting out dairy for a while to see if that helps, as often these go hand in hand.

5/post_text/2: The colour issues could be due to the uveitis, that's to say the complications of uveitis.  During the time Olivia had CMO (cystoid macular oedema) and bad flare up (for about a year and a half) she was totally colour blind ie saw green as blue, red as orange and couldn't distinguish between any pale colours - they all looked grey or blue to her.  We didn't know until tests were done, but having seen some of her wardrobe choices I'd been suspicious to say the least! Being blind in one eye with inflammation in both also affected her balance and perspective.  I'd always thought she was "just" a clumsy child, and when we were told she had no 3D it all kind of made sense.
5/post_text/3: Uveitis can cause so many problems which only piece together on diagnosis.  Of course Owen's colour confusion could be something else entirely, but it's worth considering and asking further questions.

4/post_text/4: Well i have been in so much pain, and although not rheumatoid, i can empathise with anyone who has constant pain, and it does knock you for six, tired all the time, depressed, and disabling.
5/post_text/4: Concerning your own health I'm just sorry that you're having to go through this personally as well as trying to look after Owen and his needs. May I ask what kidney disease you have?  When you say the rheumatoid factor came back as OK do you mean that levels were elevated but still within normal range?  What about ESR, are you ANA+, although as I'm sure you know the latter's not always indicative of whether someone has a type of arthrits...
5/post_text/5: The aspiration should really help so I hope you're able to have this if it's needed in 10 days.  I can empathise with you concerning hypermobility as I've suffered from this all my life, and 2 pregnancies certainly did me no favours, BUT fingers crossed it's really improved the last 5 years.  Both of my children are also hypermobile to varying degrees, so I often feel awful watching them struggle at times.
5/post_text/6: You have every right to feel depressed.  Constant pain alone is debilitating and can cause depression very easily, without having the extra worry over your child's health.  Everybody going through what you're experiencing has times of feeling isolated, and angry and very down - it's a perfectly normal reaction.
5/post_text/7: Please contact me at any time if you want to talk about this further away from the Forum, sometimes just being able to pick up the phone can give you that bit of extra strength needed to face the world that day.

15/post_text/2: Basically he says that I have chronic intermediate uveitis but the appearance suggests that it will not cause long term damage and may rumble on for some years.
15/post_text/3: However there are certain aspects of the systemic condition he is not happy about and is going to ask the GP to run a whole battery of tests and see what comes out. 15/post_text/4: I am very glad I saw him and at least can make some kind of progress to establish what is going on.

0/post_text/0: I have a steroid induced cataract (been on maxidex for 2 years for Uveitis at back and front and had injections too for inflammation at the back.  Only one eye is affected.   Have never taken oral steroids as have been frightened to because of side effects and getting fat but cataract is really bad now so Moorfields are going to operate if Uveitis stays quiet for 3 months but I will have to take oral steroids then for 10 weeks.  I am petrified of both op and taking the steroids as if side effects happen I am always guaranteed to get them - any advice welcome from anyone that may be on predisnalone and had cataract op.  thank you
1/post_text/1: The clinics are used to terrified patients and the nurses do a brilliant job of calming people. Since you've had injections for posterior uveitis, believe it or not, you're already a pro in terms of eye procedures. I once sat in a waiting room of post op patients who were discussing their cataract ops. They all agreed that the scariest thing was the injection of anaesthetic before the op. and all of them were chuffed at the sight they regained.
1/post_text/2: The risks of post op inflammation and cystoid macular oedema make the use of steroid necessary. I imagine the dose of steroid will slowly decrease over the ten week period, so the side effects will lessen. You could ask if it's possible to get your steroid through iv just before the op. Having it that way means you don't get fat, but you still get other side effects, like insomnia. I've had it through iv and felt euphoric for about 36 hours, then depressed and nauseous (perhaps that's why you don't get fat when it comes through iv?). It's not a pleasant drug but it hugely reduces the risk of sight threatening post op complications.
1/post_text/3: Take care,

0/post_text/0: By eliminating gluten, dairy, egg and soya from my diet I have been uveitis free for over one year (without the need for ANY drugs). If any of these foods slip into my diet I can see the inflammation starting. I would urge you to try this approach (most people with food sensitivities are unaware they have them) yet they have been implementd in a number of autoimmune diseases. You can try a simple elimination diet or have IGg blood tests carried out (YorkTest is the most common in the UK). I can't over emphasise the importance of diet, you should aim to alkaline your diet/eat a Stone Age diet for any autoimmune disease. It is worth visiting Dr Sarah Myhill's website to understand more about treating autoimmune disease and controlling inflammation through diet and supplementation
0/topic_title: How I control uveitis with diet
1/post_text/0: I think this makes total sense.  After going on steroids I went on a strict diet of vegetable, fruit and fish  only so as not to bloat then realised this was similar to the Paleo diet being followed by lots of people who have succeeded in comabatting autoimmune illnesses.  Too early for me to tell yet what outcome will be but the good thing is it has avoided any weight gain from steroids so far and I'm sure can only do good.  Going to do it for the longterm and see if it works when drugs are lowered.  Feeling optimistic about it helping :)
1/topic_title: How I control uveitis with diet
2/post_text/0: Great Tatiana, I really hope this helps you. I would also recommend you try a probiotic as steroids are known to upset the natural gut flora balance leading to leaky gut syndrome and food sensitivities (this would tie in with the bloat you mention). One with B. Infantis and L. Plantarum is especially good if you've experienced problems with bloating (I use New Chapter Flore Active, NB probiotics stored in the fridge tend to be better quality). I cant recommend Sarah Myhills website enough, the Body Ecology diet book also helped me. They both explain how you can heal the route cause of autoimmune problems (not just control through diet which can be tough if you're eliminating a lot of foods). Good luck!
2/topic_title: How I control uveitis with diet
3/post_text/0: Thank you, glad to have been pointed  to this site, working my way through it, determined to conquer this, lots of good information there.  Interestingly I had started drinking Kefir everyday but shall have  look at the New Chapter Flore too.  So far have actually lost weight, even though on high steroid dose, and no stomach aches.  Also adding lots of turmeric to food as read it works for inflammation, plus Saffron that Maxine had suggested too.   Shall report back when I have been on diet for a while - :)
3/topic_title: How I control uveitis with diet
4/post_text/0: Look forward to hearing how you get on. It's probably obvious but i would recommend supplements if you're cutting out lots of foods (calcium and B vitamins may become low when you eliminate dairy and bread/cereals). The raw food websites/books are great for recipes that are 'safe' for us. Im not a vegetarian but they give some great imaginative ways to eat lots of nuts, seeds, fruit and veg (which can get a bit boring otherwise! ).I treated myself to a vitamix blender recently and it's been a god send for making veg/fruit smoothies for breakfast, nut based energy bars (for snacks) nut or rice milks, nut butters, safe ice-cream (from just frozen fruit, nuts and honey-really delicious). Basically I no longer feel deprived and it's a very healthy diet :-). I hope this helps you, please do keep in touch.

3/post_text/4: Synechiae can be compared to scar tissue, which forms after a severe flare up of anterior uveitis.  It causes the iris to stick to the cornea (anterior synechiae) or to the lens (posterior synechiae).  It can cause the pupil to become ‘fixed’ and raise intraocular pressure resulting in certain types of glaucoma.  If the synechiae have recently formed, dilating drops can be used to try and break the adhesion.

2/post_text/1: i have pan uveitis too and like you, nothing else wrong.
2/post_text/2: Pan uveitis, untreated, can blind. It's something that can go on for years and when the inflammation is at the back of the eye and painless, and your eye looks normal, not red, you won't know it's there until your vision reduces and damage has been done. The oedema that can happen at the back of the eye is often what causes the reduced vision and if untreated, blindness. I got oedema in one eye within three months of being diagnosed and was legally blind in the eye. A specialist took over then, gave me steroid, put me on immune suppressants and then infliximab. He got back some sight in that blind eye and infliximab has kept both eyes inflammation free for years now.

0/post_text/1: This week, we will travel to Boston to meet with Dr. Stephen Foster and I am praying that we will be offered new hope in eradicating, or at least, finding a viable treatment in the management of this disease.  My son has already had cataract and glaucoma surgeries in both eyes while in high school.  In the summer of 2015, as he was headed off to University, he seemed to have had a "remission" and was cleared by his doctors as "Uveitis-free".  You can imagine that we believed this was a timely miracle.  His prior treatment included Methotrexate - which he had to stop because he has the A1298C Heterozygous mutation of the MTHFR gene and could not break down the medicine, steroid infusions, Remicade infusions, Humira injections, Rituximab infusions, R etisert and Ozurdex implants, etc... but our "miracle drug" had proven to be Actemra. He had also been taking Combigan eye drops to manage his eye pressure.
0/post_text/2: Admittedly, my son became inconsistent in taking his medication regularly while he was away at college.  Unfortunately, he withheld this information from us until he was forced to return home to be closer to his doctors because of aggressive eye flare-ups with vision loss.  It was frightening to receive a call from my son saying that he could only see "half of his face" while looking in the mirror. Within one month and 7 days, he had lost significant vision in his one good eye! We immediately flew him home back to Texas and scheduled an emergency appointment with his doctor. We were very lucky when his vision returned in his good eye after an emergency injection of steroids into his eye. Currently, his rhuematologist has him on a combination of two drugs to help reduce active inflammation.  The drugs are:  Acthar and Kevzara.  Has anyone used these drugs in the treatment of Uveitis?  Personally, I would like for him to be back on Actemra.  I would love to hear if anyone has found successful treatment with doctors here in the United States, and if so, with whom.  Our story is a long one and I know that what I am posting here is brief; However, I am happy to share more information if it helps!  Any advice that anyone has to offer would be greatly appreciated.

0/post_text/0: Hi, some advice please! Harrison just had a big flare up and it was controlled by Maxidex although his eye pressure went up to 33. He moved back to Vexol which just is not controlling the inflamation. He has now been put on Pred forte.  Maxidex seems to put the eye pressure up and making the cateracts worsen. Any info about Pred Forte is most welcome.  I have no idea about it.  His pressure is now normal but inflammation about 1 on the scale.  Not bad but only 2 weeks since last appt so hoping the Pred Forte means he doesnt have to go back on Maxidex.  Any info greatly recieved xxxx
1/post_text/1: Glad the flare was brought under control and sorry you've had a pressure scare.
1/post_text/2: Pred and Maxidex are about equal in strength and both can raise pressure. Steroid drops, used long enough, will cause cataract. In uveitis, the cataracts tend to be posterior ones and can take quite some time to develop to the point they affect sight. Some patients have them developing for several years before they require surgery, but for others, sight may be affected sooner. I would be inclined to ask Harrison's consultant for information about cataract surgery if the plan is to keep him on drops.
1/post_text/3: When you go back, if you are still using a lot of drops and pressure is raised again, you could ask about the intermediate strength eye drops, like Predsol - halfway between Vexol and Maxidex/Pred. Using these would, of course, depend on the degree of inflammation. There is also Lotemax which is not supposed to raise pressure, but may not control the inflammation as well as Maxidex and Pred do.
1/post_text/4: It's quite a balancing act managing steroid drops, pressure rises and glaucoma drops. Has Harrison managed to get off the steroid drops for any length of time so far?

7/post_text/0: I am not surprised that nurses are taking an increasing role in patient treatment and procedures. Over time, non-professional medical employees have been filling the roles that only nurses were allowed to fill, such as wound care and medication administration. The financial crunch to provide medical care at the lowest cost possible has forced the medical community to think outside the box and be willing to cross train both professional nurses and their non-professional employees. The care that patients recieve is still top-notch, just provided differently, so don't become concerned! Non-professional and nurses are still getting the very best in training! I am considered a non-professional medical employee and we go through extensive training and have strict regulations governing our new found roles in the practice.

2/post_text/1: Uveitis is a game of two halves as such! Inflammation consists of cells which are measured on a scale from 0-4+, and then there's flare also measured form 0-4+
2/post_text/2: A flare up is defined as cells present but you can have cells and no flare, or flare but no active cells! Confused?!

4/post_text/4: Sam. x
2/post_text/5: When blood vessels in the iris leak protein into the anterior chamber flare is said to be present.  Like cells, it is measured on a scale from 0-4.  If permanent change to the blood vessels occurs, the flare is considered chronic, and can be present regardless of whether or not a uveitis ‘flare up’ is occurring.  Flare in the vitreous can also be observed and rated.
2/post_text/6: Cells and the grading of cells
5/post_text/4: We use the epi pen which is OK, but having used a syringe for mtx for so long I'm only just getting used to it myself. It's quite unwieldy, not designed for small hands!
5/post_text/5: Take care
2/post_text/7: Leukocytes (white blood cells) can be seen during a slit lamp examination.  The cells are a byproduct of inflammation caused by the uveitis.  If the uveitis is anterior, cells can be seen and counted in the fluid in the front chamber of the eye (aqueous humor).  Once dilated, the presence of cells can also be observed in the middle chamber of the eye (the vitreous).
2/post_text/8: How many cells there are forms the basis of how severe the inflammation is at a particular given time.  The inflammation, and in turn the uveitis, is graded from 1-4, the least severe being 1 (the aqueous calls numbering 6-15) and the most severe inflammation being 4+ (when cells numbers are greater than 60).
2/post_text/9: So for O the cells have decreased but the flare has worsened as the blood vessels are still leaking protein...
2/post_text/11: The first shot of Humira was fine because ignorance is bliss! It's the second which was the worst and took 2 hours to do, the third took 1 and half hours, so a slight improvement.  We just use an ice pack on the stomach for 5 mins or so beforehand (in O's case this means it has gone on and off 10 times or so in the lead up to actually having the shot). None of the creams have ever worked on O and we just use deep freeze from the can for Mtx.  We were advised not to use this for the Humira shot as this can actually make it more painful.
2/post_text/12: As soon as shot is done we put the ice pack back on the site and hold firmly for as long as O feels she needs up - so far a good five minutes, but then that's it, over and done with for another 2 weeks.

4/post_text/1: I'm ashamed to say as an adult who has been in Braiden's position, I do get it. Frustration, anger, despair. A friend came to keep the peace when the social worker for the blind came to visit. It takes time to accept the low vision, it takes time to want to use a cane. At the point of being offered mine, I didn't want to announce to the world at large that I was blind. As an adult, I was able to do something about my situation, retreat from the world to an extent, take stock, learn how to cope. It wasn't easy. I imagine the processes are the same for a child, perhaps expressed more forcibly since their independence, being a child, is even more limited. It sounds as though Braiden is being educated by people trained to help the visually impaired. What do they say about his reactions?
4/post_text/2: I read your reply to Ricky on the other forum. After cataract surgery, my eyes were inflammation free for about two months. That might have been the effect of the aggressive treatment before surgery with a drug that cannot be used long term. I needed a further change in treatment after surgery to prevent inflammation. What is being done, other than steroid drops, to treat Braiden's new inflammation? I think you said Braiden is on infliximab. Have you discussed perhaps altering the interval between infusions or if there is a possibility of safely raising the dose? Do you think it's time to take Braiden to an expert who is used to dealing with very difficult cases on a daily basis to find a good way forward? An expert used to frustrated, uncooperative, small patients?
4/post_text/3: I'm sorry this is happening and it must be breaking your heart to see your son so frustrated.
5/post_text/0: Kimberly,
6/post_text/0: Oh Kimberley, so sorry to hear about the increased inflammation as well as the frustration! I'm currently back at Uni as a mature student and recently had alternate arrangements made for writing exams - in complete head/heart conflict. Logic overruled though and I made the arrangements - as I would have recommended to others in the same situation to do - in case my joints or eyes flare and I find hand-writing for long periods of time too difficult... at the same time my inner child wanted to have a HUGE strop about it. For me there's a continual conflict about the identity and implications/complications of these chronic illnesses... and as an adult I can (more or less) express these and try to deal with it that way. I can't even imagine how difficult it must be for Braiden - I wish I had some words of wisdom but all I can say is I'm thinking of you both!
6/post_text/1: Like Maxine, I hope that laptop arrives soon and can be a glimmer of light in the midst of this.
6/post_text/2: Take care,
7/post_text/0: Maxine, the rheumy increased his remicade from 150mg every 8 weeks to 200mg every 6 weeks and the mtx to 25mg from 20.
8/post_text/0: Hi Kimberly,
9/post_text/0: The rheumy said, the remicade is in 100mg vials and when they give 150mg they throw away the other 50! What a waste! He says he has been planning to just give Braiden the other 50 eventually anyways because he clearly needs it and 50mg is way too expensive to waste.
10/post_text/0: Hi Kimberly,
11/post_text/0: Thanks Ian. It is very difficult from a child's point of view because they lack the ability to reason or project the consequence of their refusals. Although I can't imagine having to change the whole direction of one's life after they have been an adult and experienced the sighted world. I believe for both, child and adult, it is an evil disease!
3/post_text/1: That said Kimberly, you've managed to come this far, please hang in there, take any support you can and stay strong. However stressful and endless it seems right now, be hopeful that it will get easier. As a mother of a child with uveitis, I completely understand your frustrations on both fronts.
3/post_text/2: My daughter can often have mother of strops in the middle of a consultation refusing to speak or give anyone eye contact on a bad day. It's so heartbreaking what these kids have to go through, they have to vent their frustrations in the only way they know how to.
3/post_text/3: How do the doctors expect you to sedate him for goodness sake, not sure I like the sound of that, perhaps i'm missing something?
5/post_text/1: 2.5mg per kilogram body weight every eight weeks is often the dose of remicade used in RA. For uveitis, 3 - 5mg every six weeks is usually more successful. On 5mg every eight weeks, my eyes had cells at the 6 to 7 week point. Reducing the interval to 6 weeks stopped the flaring between infusions.
8/post_text/1: My mtx was also increased for about a year from 20 to 25 alongside moving to six weekly infusions. It sounds quite a large increase in the dose of infliximab so I hope Braiden experiences the same success I had and you get a break from this constant anxiety.
8/post_text/2: Fingers crossed,
8/post_text/3: Maxine
10/post_text/1: i can honestly say i can understand where your son is coming from, one of the biggest hurdles I've faced was accepting the fact that I needed help, weather something as simple as always having to wear sunglasses, or getting my first symbol cane from social care.  I've often thought if it would be easier to adjust if i was a child, and I don;t think it would be.  I think as an adult it has been far easier to grasp the gravity and seriousness of the condition.

0/post_text/0: I have just had my second episode of Uveitis.  The first flare-up in 2014 was Intermediate uveitis and this time was iritis.  I was given the same steroid drops as I had been prescribed before, Maxidex.   I had to stop taking them half-way through the course, I rang the pharmacist and said that my light sensitivity was worsening   since using the drops.   She said to stop taking them and when I had my next appointment at the uveitis clinic to tell them.  I was diagnosed at the clinic as having Sjogren's syndrome, which they think my dry eyes could be associated with and I have Ehlers-Danlos syndrome ( a connective tissue disorder which is associated with the retinal changes).  It is the light sensitivity that I am having terrible problems with.  I get glare from every reflective surface,  both outdoors and indoors.  When the sun is low in the sky, as it is this time of year,  I have to walk looking at the ground as I cannot look straight ahead or  upwards as the dazzling glare is unbearable.  I wear a peaked cap, polarized, anti-reflective  (back and front lens) UVA and UVB  wrap-around protection sunglasses  but I am still having problems with glare.  None of the ophthalmologists I have seen so far have been able to say what I can further do and the ophthalmologist at the uveitis clinic said that I could have cataracts surgery but  he didn't think that would solve the problem.   I have now read about prosthetic lens, you can only get treated with these prosthetic devices in the States and they help with both dry and light sensitive eyes and wonder if anyone has heard about his treatment.

1/post_text/1: Followed your link - that lens sounds brilliant! Perhaps you should email Boston Sight and ask whether you should have cataract surgery before seriously committing to the idea of such a lens. It would be a good move to talk about it at the uveitis clinic as well. They might know about Prose and be better able to advise you since they know your disease and eye(s).
1/post_text/2: Cataracts do cause a lot of glare and in low sun, mine totally blinded me. All I saw was whitish/yellowish light when my cataracts were really dense. I've never had photosensitivity so have no idea if the glare caused by cataract makes photosensitivity even more painful.
1/post_text/3: You're into really specialist territory here. All I know is that people who have had their iris damaged by herpetic uveitis sometimes do well with a special contact lens which stops too much light entering the eye. Whether or not something like that would be helpful when you also have dry eye is another matter.
1/post_text/4: Have you ever been offered Minims steroid drops when you're flaring? I just ask because they are preservative free drops and the preservative in Maxidex may make dry eye worse when you're putting in multiple drops daily.

2/post_text/0: Hi Emily,
2/post_text/1: many people take methotrexate with absolutely no problems whatsoever.  Some people do feel nauseas and quite often a switch over from tablets to injections will stop the sickness. If you were to feel sick ask your GP or consultant for anti sickness (anti emetic) pill such as Zofran which has very good results.  One word of warning though stay away from alcohol as much as poss! A student's nightmare I know but it really doesn't interact with mtx very well and could make you feel quite sick.
2/post_text/2: Concerning how long you'll need to stay on mtx will depend on how well your eyes react.  As soon as they've been quiet with no inflammation (cells) for 3 months solidly, the stop clock can generally start, and approx 2 years from that time if there have been no further flare ups or complications, your consultant could discuss the possibility of you slowly tapering off the mtx.

2/post_text/3: hope this helps
3/post_text/1: Great to hear that you're not having any problems with methotrexate! A change in dose does not automatically mean that you will feel sick - especially if the dose is changed relatively gradually so that you can adjust to each increase. Mtx bothered me a bit in the beginning - not nausea too much (over the counter pills helped the little bit I had) but more on the fatigue side - if I were to start it again I'd start on a lower dose and taper up - but after a few months when I got more used to it dosage changes didn't bother me at all, even if we changed 5mg at a time! You've started off well so hopefully it'll stay that way!
3/post_text/2: Nicki's already mentioned staying away from the alcohol, but do try to drink lots of water and other fluids - that and the folic acid all helps ward off side effects!
3/post_text/3: Take care,
5/post_text/1: It's great that you're escaping side effects.
5/post_text/2: There are lots of appointments in the early months of methotrexate, but once you've reached a dose which controls your uveitis, if your blood results become stable, the rheumatology appointments can be extended to once every three months and blood tests become less frequent too.
5/post_text/3: Not drinking alcohol is difficult. I tried all the non alcoholic wines and lagers the supermarket offered and all tasted foul. I did get used to not drinking, but it took a long time before I stopped resenting not being able to have a glass or two of wine. Be careful with friends, some of whom will tell you, 'one glass won't hurt.' It probably won't, provided it's not methotrexate day, but one glass isn't enough until you're used to just one glass.
5/post_text/4: Good luck with your continuing adaptation - it does become a way of life eventually.

3/post_text/1: It sounds as though methotrexate was doing the job for your daughter's uveitis. Is the Enbrel prescribed for an associated condition which isn't controlled so well? If she has JIA as well as uveitis, Humira is effective for that and the sting was taken out over a year or two ago, so there shouldn't be old, stingy stock still going out now. I do know of one mother whose daughter did fine on Enbrel for her uveitis and JIA, but you're right, there are reports that uveitis is sometimes triggered. Sorry, don't know how quickly that would happen or whether or not the methotrexate would prevent it from happening. If your daughter has been ok for two months now, maybe she would be OK staying on it. Sorry - I don't have enough knowledge to tell you that for sure though. In your position, going with Mum's instinct, worried by what you've read about Enbrel, I think I'd probably switch to Humira which now has masses of successful clinical trials behind it for JIA uveitis. If your daughter has something other than JIA, I'd be asking the rheumatologist for advice about which is the better treatment for her underlying condition but since they are happy to swich her anyway, possibly there isn't much difference between them?

2/post_text/0: Sounds like you are on the right track, my son has been put on to Methotrexate, which is a chemo therapy drug - but you are given a much, much lower dose than a cancer one. The idea with my son, is the drug dampens the immune system to stop the uveitis flares, then you stay on it for a period of time until your eyes are stable and slowly weaned off it and hopefully, the uveitis stays away. You should be able get a referral to Moorfields through your GP as well - it will probably take two to three months anyway. Keep badgering them about referring you, uveitis is a serious eye condition so they shouldn't fob you off.

2/post_text/4: Are you also using a dilating drop? This helps to prevent sticking of the pupil. You could ask if using such a drop will prevent further sticking. Once stuck, the pupil is unstuck during cataract surgery. It's all rather frustrating since cataracts in uveitis take time to develop and you have to put up with the stuck pupil until then. Have you been told if a cataract is developing because if you do have one, that too will affect your vision in sunlight. Polaroid glasses help with this.

0/post_text/0: There is a great deal of new evidence linking vitamin D deficiencies with autoimmune diseases, like uveitis. The majority of adults in the UK and US are Vitamin D deficient, through not spending enough time outdoors, excessive use of sunscreen etc. I have suffered from repeated attacks of uveitis for 2 years now and have noticed a marked improvement by increasing my vitamin D levels. Please note that you should take Vitamin D3 (not D2 as this is much less effective). I take 4000 IUs per day (1000% RDA). The existing RDAs are probably too low (they were based upon the vitamin content of cod liver oil). As a PhD Scientist I work with the Pharma industry and from my point of view there is not enough research being done into this. Please don't hang around waiting till this eventually seeps through to your GPs office. I really hope this can make a difference to you.

10/post_text/0: Hi Oki - Yes I was furious that they put the wrong lens in - one thing I would say is make them do the measurements for surgery before you lose too much sight and not at the last minute!  Although they use a machine as well as manual tests,  if you have little sight left it is not so accurate I believe,  although for me that was not the only problem but someone decided to change the lens just before the op!  I then had laser a year later to correct it.  It is fine now and I see well but I am mad as they do cut your eye for laser and this should never have happened, so I now have very dry eyes from the laser.  I am on Humira and my eye has been quiet for 18 months except for a brief 2 weeks when I had cataract surgery which is normal even if you do not have uveitis.  By the time I had surgery I could not see, everything was just white.  The reason that they did not do it sooner (which would have happened) was because they could not get rid of the CMO until I went on Humira - so it ended up being a year of hardly seeing in one eye and by the end really seeing nothing.  I did not get halos everything just went blurred bit by bit until I could no longer read the eye chart or see faces.  If you no longer have inflammation and do not use steroids it may be that it just stays at the same level for you, but you should be able to tell from the eye chart how much it decreases.  I guess it probably depends on age too as to how how quickly it worsens. If I were you I would monitor it carefully and hopefully you are no longer having to use steroids because the cyclosporine is working.

8/post_text/1: I got uveitis 4 years ago in one eye.  For almost two years I was given steroid drops and had steroid injections to control the inflammation which included CMO.  I had raised IOP becuause of the steroid drops and also steroid injections (orbital floor dexamethodone).  I then had to have glaucoma drops to keep pressure down which had soared from the steroids.  I ended up after a year with early posterior subcapsular lens opacity from chronic steroid usage.  This progressed fast although you don't wake up one morning with sight gone it increases bit by bit.  However, it is different for everyone the speed at which it progresses but because it is a posterior cataract caused by steroid use or possibly some of it inflammation it tends to be right in the line of vision unlike cataracts from old age hence it effects the vision in a worse way.  In terms of the IOP as soon as I came of steroid drops when the inflammation was controlled with immunossuppresants it dropped back to normal.  I had a cataract operation in February last year.  Again the problem with this is they cannot do the operation if you have any sort of inflammation, ie you have to have a quiet eye for at least four months.  As a result I suffered with a cataract for a year whereby I saw little, as they could not get my inflammation under control.  To make matters worse, I was particularly unlucky as they managed to put the wrong lens in my eye when they did the cataract op.  So whilst it went well I ended up being so shortsighted in just one eye (my other eye is longsighted) that I had to have my eye lasered!  It is now ok but the trauma it went through was so unnecessary.  In the light of all of this, I wish I had been put on immunossuppresants earlier and avoided getting the cataract to start with.   Some Opthamologist will argue the cataract is from inflammation but I do not accept that and think that it is mainly from the steroids either as drops but also orally (although to a lesser degree).  I think your choice to go on immunosuppressants is a good one and hopefully you get your inflammation under control so you do not need steroid drops.  I am assuming you have raised IOP from steroid drops and not from the type of uveitis you have, ie viral?  which immunosuppressants are you on?  If they are not controlling it they may put you on two different types.  Is your uveitis in both eyes?

9/post_text/3: Cheers,
11/post_text/1: Just wondering whether you know anything about low white blood cells? In my last test just 1 week ago, the white blood was on the verge of the lower normal limit. For the last few days I start to feel tired, sleepy, have occasional muscle pain, nasal drain... Normally they may be symptoms of a cold or sorethroat, but the strange thing is I have no fever or significant pain, just this general tiredness.
11/post_text/2: So I'm just thinking... is there any chance that when your white blood is too low, your body just wouldn't bother fighting infection and thus you have no fever?? When will it be alarming enough to go to A&E? Last week I had some intense activities and I'm not even sure whether they are the reasons for this or the immunosurpressants :s
12/post_text/1: The immunosuppressants will lower your white blood cell count to the lowest count to stop your bodies inflammatory response to infection hence preventing the eye inflammation.  They monitor that they do not squash your immune system too much hence keeping it at a level low enough to stop your body inflamming your eye in response to what it thinks is an antigen but not so much that you could not fight an infection if necessary.  Mine too was always at the lowest limit of normal.  At the start the drugs can make you feel tired, you can get muscle pain but often this goes as you get used to the drugs.  The only thing I did find strange was that in all my time on immunosuppressants I never got a cold even when my daughter got a bad one, so I did also wonder sometimes if there was a correlation between this and a lowered immune system.
13/post_text/1: Hope you're feeling better by now! There's been a nasty virus going round - I was in bed for a week with it. I found adjusting to methotrexate quite hard at first - very tired, completely drained - and then I got used to it. But yes the idea is that your white cells are low - and that's what they monitor, whoever is checking your bloods will let you know if there's something unexpected. If you're tired - just rest! Listen to the signals your body is giving you!
13/post_text/2: Re posterior subcapsular cataract: I've had one since before I started immunosuppressants, although only found out when I saw the consultant... Mine essentially hasn't changed (in 8 years) as we've drastically reduced the amount of steroid I've needed over the years - THAT is why I chose this steroid-sparing treatment approach.
13/post_text/3: Tatiana - so sorry to hear about your surgery!!! I'd be furious too. Wanted to comment on the dry eyes: my consultant recommended Hylo Tears (by Scope) when I was complaining about blurred vision once. The clinic I had laser surgery at since gave me Hylo Forte (Same company, "thicker") - I now buy this on Amazon. Expensive, but no comparison at all to something like Blink or other lubricating drops. I generally use Hylo Forte first thing in the morning/last thing at night and it makes a huge difference. Give it a try!!
11/post_text/3: Cheers,
15/post_text/1: Ouch! That sounds painful - hope the hylo forte can help a little. I not heard of Omega Eye before but good omega supplements make a lot of sense here - I hope that, somehow, anyhow!, you get some relief soon!
15/post_text/2: Yes, my surgery was purely elective: I was at approx -5.5 with astigmatism in both eyes, and couldn't find contacts that fit properly anymore. Last January's rain really annoyed me with glasses and a friend asked why I didn't consider surgery - I honestly had thought it was out of the question with my uveitis history. Anyway, at my next appointment with Prof Ayliffe I asked his opinion, expecting it to be ruled out and that would be that... But no, he said as long as I saw Prof Reinstein at London Vision Clinic it should be fine - and wrote a referral letter straight away! It's likely my eyes will worsen again with age, but we thought it was safer whilst I was on Humira - and even with some changes, I'd still be much better off that before. So that's what happened, and I honestly cannot recommend LVC enough. Despite perioperative oral steroid for my keyhole(!) laser surgery, I had an unexpected autoimmune scleritis flare 4 days post surgery, but the care I received was superb and with input from both Prof Ayliffe & Reinstein I have no permanent effect from that. It was so unusual they're considering publishing it! Final surgery follow-up (almost 1 year) is next week :)

1/post_text/1: My son Riley takes methotrexate, he is 7 years old and started MTX on 25th October 2014. One day after his 7 birthday.  He has it as an oral solution and is on 15mg/week. He was sick once the fist morning after his first dose the evening before. He usually has a hot chocolate first thing. We stopped that, since then he has been absolutely fine no side effetcs. We did have to change the brand of MTX he was having and he was sick once again the next morning but it was after he had hot chocolate first thing, my husband forgot.  He was fine for breakfast at 9 ish and then went to a kids party at 11am. I was a bit worried for him so stayed (something I stopped doing ages ago) but he was absolutely fine. Ate all sorts and was bopping about with the best of them. My worries with regard to MTX with regard to nausea and tiredness just haven't happened.
1/post_text/2: We give him MTX on Sat evening at 4pm - I figured if he was going to feel poorly it would be better to feel rubbish on Sunday, rather than Saturday. The monthly blood tests are a bit tough but we are getting there slowly.
1/post_text/3: I wonder, if you mind writing to me about your son's cataract experience? I had looked back ages ago now at old posts and wondered about your son. He is a similar age to Riley.  Riley has a small cataract and I was really keen to contact a parent who had gone through cateract surgery. For advice and tips really.
1/post_text/4: Anyway, I did worry lots, I still worry lots but so far, MTX hasn't proved to be horrendous, I just keep a close eye on his blood test results and make sure that I take a copy of results every time we go to the hospital. But fingers crossed, It is going OK. I just hope MTX will do the job and keep the uveitis at bay. He recently had a small flare but had only been taking it for 3 months ... 3/post_text/1: Harrison had cataracts in both eyes.  He is a steroid responder but the left eye's cataract was fast growing and aged 6 he could not see much out of the left eye.  His eyes had to be quiet for the op first and then he wore an eye guard for some time, especially at night.  His prescription for his glasses took some time to get changed.  For some reason the hospital wanted to wait.  After surgery Harrison was on Maxidex every two hours and then it reduced.  He does have some issues around the new lens inserted in his eye but its not causing him any issues at the moment so we are leaving it be.  Apparently that issue can be corrected with laser surgery.  The cataract in his right eye is much slower growing so we are not there yet for that one.  Thank goodness because my nerves are shattered!! The actual surgery is day surgery and thankfully very quick.  Harrison was operated on at Moorfields where he is under Prof Lightman, his surgeon was Dr Ezra. Please feel free to ask me anything.  Can I ask how long it took before Riley stopped steroid drops?

7/post_text/1: I was under Mr Pavesio but he went to City Moorfields and am now under Angela Rees who trained with him for a long time and now runs the uveitis clinic at Moorfields, St Georges, I am very pleased.  I also was under Prof Ayliffe at Croydon for a while but for various reasons went back to Moorfields as I was happier there. there.  Privately I have seen Prof Ayliffe, Prof Lightman and Mr Pavesio.  My uveitis was finally brought under control with immunosuppresants but I have CMO which did reduce finally on Humira which I take too.  I am only affected in one eye.  I think in the end it is a lottery sometimes which drugs work for who, I tried all the immunosuppresants which either did not work or made me ill, finally I am on Cellcept. All the consultants will have different views.  Key in my mind is that you are seen often enough and control is found as fast as possible and hopefully you understand what your options  are and these are explained fully.   To be honest my advice is get referred to either Moorfields City or Moorfields St Georges uveitis clinic.  City is run by either Prof Lightman or Mr Pavesio or St Georges is Angela Rees, all very good.  Hope this helps.

0/post_text/0: I have currently been suffering with chronic uveitis with secondary glaucoma since the age of 17. from the start, my doctor assumed that because every blood test she had tried had came back clear that my uveitis was idiopathic and had just simply came out of nowhere. from the beginning I knew this was not true as I have never felt the same and only seem to be getting worse as time goes by. I attend my hospital every two weeks and in some cases have to go more often than that only to be told I should lower or higher my doses on the six different eye drops I am using (oral steroids effected me badly so I had to stop taking them) it is a vicious cycle. my doctor cant control the flare ups of my uveitis because highering the dose of pretforte only makes the pressure in my eye increase, the highest it has been is 47. this has gone on for over 17 months, with my school and social life suffering because no doctor can locate the cause of my uveitis. it is only now that my doctor has said enough is enough looking at how often I have had to come and how many eye drops I have had to use every single day realising that this cannot just be idiopathic and from nothing but that something must be causing this relentless condition and that it needs to be looked at more thoroughly so she is bringing it up at a consultants meeting asap. the symptoms I have had since diagnosis are, extreme tiredness (sleeping for at least 12 hours every single night and if not feel exhausted), muscle weakness in legs and arms, sore joints in arms legs and sore back, sore scalp, blocked ears (no one sees any signs of ear problems), random swollen glands, no energy, lack of concentration, repeated cold sores, headaches. The only thing that I know is that I seem to have a weak immune system, tonsillitis has always been a problem for me since I was young and I repeatedly had to take antibiotics to treat this. If anyone knows anything at all, or has experienced anything similar any responses would be greatly appreciated.

1/post_text/1: Reading your post, totally agree with the 'Enough is enough' summary. Cannot imagine how soul destroying it must be to juggle six different drops a day and still get nowhere.
1/post_text/2: Do you have one eye or both affected? Does your local clinic have a uveitis specialist? If you read our treatments section, you will see that there are alternatives to the endless cycle of drops. You would ideally need a uveitis expert's
1/post_text/3: opinion to guide you about the suitability of moving on from drops to something else for your uveitis.
1/post_text/4: Regarding your symptoms, if any of these started after your diagnosis, it is possible that one or two may be the side effects of pressure lowering drops. If you noticed something happening shortly after beginning a new drop, it would be a good idea to mention this to your doctor. I'm one of the people who got the less common side effects from some of these drops such as depression and loss of energy. One even made me so stiff in the mornings, I found it hard to get out of bed. When that drop was changed, the stiffness went.

4/post_text/0: Hi Jessica
4/post_text/1: I should have mentioned that if you've had lots of antibiotics then this definitly points towards you having "leaky gut" which leads to food intolerances. Basically the antibiotics are non-selective and will wipe out lots of beneficial bacteria in your gut. This makes your gut porous and food particles (esp gluten, dairy, soya, egg corn) will leak through to your blood stream kickstarting your immune system.
4/post_text/2: I'd bet my house that if you cut out trigger foods you will get your inflammation under control. You should also start to look at rebuilding your gut and replacing beneficial bacteria by taking a good probiotic.

1/post_text/5: With your other symptoms, we can only hope that your consultant's meeting will come up with something. Some people find the idiopathic diagnosis hard to accept and one of my uveitis friends had her consultant chasing cause for over ten years. Her consultant is one active in uveitis research and I think it was one of the happiest of her uveitis days when he told her she had a recently discovered, very rare auto immune disease. By that time, he had her on a drug that controlled her uveitis and was also effective at controlling her underlying disease.
1/post_text/6: I hope you get some answers soon and with them, a clear direction about the way forward for you.
2/post_text/3: My story is that since the age of 10 I have experienced the chronic fatigue (“oh she’s always tired"), the pain in my sacrolitic joints, lower back (“oh it’ll be growing pains” or “sitting awkwardly” “period pains” etc), the sore scalp (“oh get dandruff shampoo”).  At 35 I was in so much pain I was referred for an x-ray (at a geriatric hosp!!!) and misdiagnosed with an illness “that’ll burn  itself out”.   It didn't.
2/post_text/4: Fast forward to age 52 when I ended up at Moorfields with a really bad uveitis attack (misdiagnosed by my GP as conjunctivitis – during the 2 weeks I was in absolute agony).  Moorfields saved my sight just in time with an injection into my eye. The condition is now chronic in both eyes and I have to stay on the steroid drops for life now.
3/post_text/1: I'm so sorry you've had to go through this, especially at such a young age. I've had very similar symptoms and I hope my experience will help you.
3/post_text/2: You do ask what caused this - Infections or vaccines seem to very good triggers for autoimmune disease, including uveitis. You do mention you've had repeated tonsillitis, for me it was a flu vaccine.
3/post_text/3: Regardless of the initial trigger, perhaps surprisingly, food intolerances are strongly linked with autoimmune disease. Here is a publication from 1963 linking uveitis and food intolerance. Most people don't realise they have food intolerance so I'd strongly advise you look into this even if you don't identify as having food intolerance/ allergy. It's definitely worth trying to cut out gluten and dairy from your diet in the first instance as there is a good chance this will help get the inflammation under control. There is an amazing allergy clinic who can test and also treat/ cure intolerance/ allergy
5/post_text/1: Sorry you've had such a rough time - I'm glad this is now being discussed with a consultant and hope that brings new treatment plans and hope, there are other options other than oral steroid. Have you discussed your other symptoms with your GP - perhaps they could also refer you to a rheumatologist to see if that avenue brings any clarity?
7/post_text/1: The reason it has crossed my mind to check back is because after all of this time, I have been to a chest specialist for the heart palpitations I was suffering as I told my doctor my dad suffers with asthma this is where I was sent. From there they found nothing, only that my breathing was slightly below average and have given me a peak flow measure for four weeks to see if any changes in environment effect my breathing. The doctor also referred me to the right place once this was cleared up, cardiology where I will be getting a 48 hour heart monitor fitted to check my heart. I believe this has only come about as a side effect of one of the drugs I have been on and am not too worried about it. The doctor here was also concerned that I had never had a blood test to check my thyroid so sent me to get this done and I am awaiting results.
3/post_text/5:
. I hope it encourages you to know that I've used this approach to completely get my uveitis under control - no symptoms, no drugs :-). 
 Your other symptoms ( joint and back pain) do point towards you have Ankylosing Spondylitis. Your Doctor should test to see if you have the HLAB27 gene which is strongly linked to Ankylosing Spondylitis. The good news is that you should be able to control your joint and back pain by eliminating starch from your diet. The reason for this is your immune system is attacking klebsiella pneumoniae bacteria. If you have HLAB27 gene your joints and back resemble klebsiella pneumoniae and are basically victims of friendly fire from your immune system. By cutting out starch you starve this bacteria of their food source so there are less enemies for your immune system to attack and your joints and back get a break.
 Please do try this and hang in there. Using this approach I live medication and symptom free. After 5 years I have 20/20 vision. I have shared my experience with my optometrist who passed it on to fellow uveitis patients who are also getting similar benefit. I sincerely hope you will too and  this allows you to get on with the rest of your young life.
5/post_text/2: @Wendy - I also wanted to respond to your comment about needing steroid drops now for life - please explore other treatment options to break the cycle, anti TNF can be very effective. I too have AS, which presented first with uveitis and similarly became chronic. We tried various immunosuppressants over the years but humira has been my absolute miracle drug - both for the eyes and joints. If you are HLA B27 +ve, then please taper steroids VERY slowly - this was one thing I learnt over 10 years of flares. Where previously I'd flare within about 2 weeks of stopping steroids the "usual" way (ie. dropping a drop a time, over a number of days - finally going from 1 drop to none) - slowing that down even more helped break the chronic cycle completely for me. So 1 drop/day, normally for a week, then 1 drop every other day for a week, etc... It's almost 2 years now since I last used steroid drops, so the Humira really has helped to bring this under control too. Please explore options with your consultants to break the steroid drop cycle rather than staying on them indeterminately.
5/post_text/3: Wishing all of you all the best,
7/post_text/2: In terms of Rheumatology, my eye doctor sent me here once I told her about the soreness and stiffness and I don't know if it is the same for anyone else but I only feel like this during flare ups, which seem to correspond with flare ups in my eye which at the moment is all quiet. this makes the whole process very frustrating because now that I have been there ive felt fine during this period and the first time I went I was discharged even though I tested positive for blood test ANA. My eye doctor pulled this up and referred me back again, this appointment was only yesterday and once again the doctor says he is looking for swelling or inflammation of tissue in my joints and cant find any, he said many people test positive for ANA and are diagnosed with nothing. the doctor didn't ask me any questions regarding my general well being or what symptoms I have so I didn't want to push as I don't want to seem like I'm looking for something which may not even be there. When I did mention to him that it was my immune system which seems to be the problem with me he said yes a lot of people suffer with tonsillitis and sore ears at your age, because your white blood cell count is normal I am not concerned with this. Does anyone have any information on this?

9/post_text/2: Just because I've had similar experiences with very high pressure 57 the highest in my right eye. After almost a year of watchful waiting/ trying different drops and medication I found myself in the position where surgery was the only option. I was on maximum medical therapy (1000mg diamox, 3drops iopidine and 2 drops cosopt daily) and my pressure was still too high. I had a deep sclerectomy on Monday (also known as non penetrative trabeculectomy) surgery was a success and my iOp was 5 post op (28 before)
9/post_text/3: My uveitis is quiet, I have had a rough 5 years of it though and it has taken its toll on my eyes. (Macula oedema/ epiretinal membrane/cataracts /glaucoma /posterior synnachae!) I am on a 1 drop a day maintenance if maxidex which is amazing progress from where I was a year ago. I've narrowly avoided systemic treatment at the moment, but it is something I would do without a second thought if my attacks became aggressive again.

4/post_text/4: http://www.drmyhill.co.uk/wiki/Category:Allergies,_autoimmunity_and_infections
2/post_text/5: But, going back to the reason for me writing…. It was the amazing consultant at Moorfields who asked if I suffered from back ache  (tick), if I had flaky sore skin (tick), if I had fatigue (tick).    As I answered a big YES to all of those questions she referred me to a rheumatologist at St Thomas’ Hospital who booked me in for an MRI scan - and there it was after putting up with fatigue, painful flare ups of bones, horrid bouts of psoriasis – my diagnosis of AS may as well have been written in large capital letters on my forehead.    I can’t say I was thrilled – actually I was and still am very scared – but at least I now have a name and a reason for what I am suffering.  I now have regular checks at both hospitals, attend physio and hydro and I have been recommended to have Anti-TNF medication - which will slow down the AS and calm down my eyes.   I’m now 55 so it has been a long journey of discovery for me (though I have to say I never used to visit a GP until absolutely unbearable).   Its since been said that I have had uveitis flare ups before but was just lucky that they eased off without medication or ill effect (must have been the many bouts  of “conjunctivitis” I had in my youth.  Also, AS hides itself very well until quite advanced so x-ray’s  aren’t much good for finding it.   I also had a blood test to see if I had a particular gene – which I did.

Make the candidate entry smaller and the percentage pass rate decreases further if one child fails.
