1/post_text/0: Hi Rebecca, sorry to hear you're going through this. I had two attacks, similar period apart as yourself. I've managed to get my uveitis under control mow through diet (this is recommended for anyone suffering autoimmune disease). I was sceptical at first but it has really worked Initially you should try eliminating gluten, dairy and egg and see if this helps. You can find more details of treating autoimmune disease through diet and supplements here
1/post_text/1: http://www.drmyhill.co.uk/wiki/Category:Allergies,_autoimmunity_and_infections
1/post_text/2: . I really hope this helps, good luck!
2/post_text/0: Hi Rebecca,
2/post_text/1: Sorry you're having a second attack. Do you know where the inflammation is in your eye? When it's treated with drops, it's usually the front of the eye that's affected. It's too early to say whether you'll have another attack. Some people just have one or two attacks, others have repeated attacks with lengthy periods inbetween. For a minority, the inflammation becomes recurrent or chronic, affects both eyes and may affect more than the front of the eyes.
2/post_text/2: When it does become recurrent, blood tests and x-rays are usually done to find out if there is a cause behind the inflammation.
3/post_text/0: Hi thanks for your replies.  I am a type 1 insulin dependent diabetic so maybe that would be the underlying condition? My husband was the one who recognised the symptoms.  A&E said it was a viral infection but it got worse over night to the point of no vision and now the 6 weeks of steroid drops.
4/post_text/0: Hi Rebecca,
4/post_text/1: You should have a follow up appointment. Are you also attending the eye clinic for your diabetes? It may be that you'll receive an appointment letter in the post, but you could ring the clinic to make sure a follow up appointment is being made.
4/post_text/2: You can certainly ask for the blood tests and x-rays to find out if there is a second problem. Most of us get asked loads of questions about our general health in order to narrow down possible causes for the inflammation. Uveitis isn't always part of an auto immune disease and may be caused by microbial or viral infections. When the cause is identified as one of these, the infection may need treatment as well as the inflammation.
4/post_text/3: I hope your eye is feeling more comfortable today. Is some sight coming back?
5/post_text/0: Hi yeah I have just 5 weeks left of treatment. I'm away on holiday but on my return I will be getting everything sorted. Really missing not being to drive. I have most of the sight back its just not in focus.
2/post_text/3: In the future, the important thing to do when you feel any sign that inflammation is returning is to go to the eye clinic straight away. Waiting a day or two just to see if you're mistaken allows the inflammation to take hold. People learn to recognise the signs and sometimes the ophth won't see any inflammation at that point, but the next day, there will be serious inflammation. Ophths used to treating uveitis will start the drop treatment at that point if the patient has had previous bouts of inflammation and knows another attack is about to begin.
2/post_text/4: I hope your inflammation resolves easily and quickly.
3/post_text/1: In answer to your question it looks like it was the front of my eye which was affected this time but not sure about last. To add problems I also have blood vessels in both eyes which have caused bleeding  and made small black spots in my vision.

0/post_text/0: Moorfields supports global campaign about rare diseases
0/post_text/1: Moorfields is supporting Rare Disease Day on 29 February with a number of activities including a web chat about rare eye diseases with Professor Michel Michaelides.
0/post_text/2: Rare Disease Day takes place on the last day of February each year and aims to raise awareness among the general public and decision makers about rare illnesses and their impact on patients’ lives. A rare disease is defined by the European Union as one that affects less than 5 in 10,000 of the general population. Research shows  one in 17 people, or 7% of the population, will be affected by a rare disease.
0/post_text/3: From 22 February on  our Twitter and  Facebook channels we will highlight diseases such as retinitis pigmentosa, birdshot uveitis, achromatopsia and Stargardt disease which affect some of our patients.
0/post_text/4: On 29 February between 12.30-1.30pm our web chat will give a chance for staff, patients and the general public to ask Professor Michaelides, consultant ophthalmologist, about rare eye conditions through this link  http:​//www.​moorfields.​nhs.​uk/event/rare-disease-day-web-​chat.
0/post_text/5: Rare Disease Day has also attracted the support of the National Institute for Health Research Biomedical Research Centre at Moorfields and UCL Institute of Ophthalmology, who are calling for patients’ voices to be heard. Patients and the general public can leave messages of support for people with rare diseases via ballot boxes in Moorfields’ clinics or online here http:​//www.​brcophthalmology.​org/rare-disease-day-2016​.
0/post_text/6: Retinal disorders overtook diabetes as the third leading cause of severe sight impairment in England and Wales in 2013. One patient who knows what it’s like to live with a rare retinal disease is Joshua De Silva who was diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa (RP) at Moorfields Eye Hospital when he was 11.
0/post_text/7: RP is the name given to a group of inherited conditions that progressively cause reduced vision and blindness by attacking light sensitive cells in the retina. Currently there is no cure. Joshua said: “The form of RP that I have results in a very limited peripheral field and reduced night vision. I really struggle to see in low light, that includes a dimly lit room, at dusk and dawn and when the sun is beginning to set. I have my central vision but I have no outer vision.”
0/post_text/8: Now 26, Joshua continues to be seen at Moorfields: “It’s incredibly bittersweet whilst I’m here because it forces me to think about my RP and it’s not the most pleasant thing to think about. It also fills me with so much gratitude because I’m still able to live a relatively normal life.”

3/post_text/1: Herpes is not good news. Herpes is a virus and remains in the system for life or until someone finds a cure. It will flare dependent on the immune state.
3/post_text/2: Acyclovir helps slow the rate of reproduction of the virus during these flares. For Acyclovir to work optimally therapy needs to be initiated within 48 hours of the start of the flare. Once the flare has established itself its affect is pretty minimal. You need to have a course of acyclovir on hand so that when a flare starts you can start it immediately.
3/post_text/3: As others have said herpes is very contagious. On the positive side this may be the key cause in Owens case and Acyclovir used correctly certainly can help control the situation.

0/post_text/0: With new treatments being licensed for non-infectious intermediate, posterior and pan uveitis, pharmaceutical companies want to be certain about patients' needs. Cello Health are working with one pharmaceutical company in order that they do get these needs right before they launch their product.
0/topic_title: Cello Health Insight and adult non-infectious intermediate, posterior and pan uveitis patients.
0/post_text/1: If you're an adult with the types of non infectious uveitis listed above, this is your chance to make patient information about a licensed for uveitis drug heaps better and get paid for doping so! And the people at Cello Health are really nice to talk to!
0/post_text/2: Here's their letter to us with all the details:
0/post_text/6: We are writing to you from an independent market research company, Cello Health Insight, as we have been asked by a pharmaceutical company to conduct a market research project amongst people who are living with Uveitis. You have been passed this letter because you may be eligible to take part in this market research.
0/post_text/7: What is the purpose of this project?
0/post_text/8: We are conducting a market research project on non-infectious uveitis, on behalf of a pharmaceutical company. They are looking to gain an in-depth understanding of what it’s like for patients living with this condition and to understand the support needs that patients like yourself have while they are on treatment and how best they might be able to address these needs.
0/post_text/9: Who would we like to speak with?
0/post_text/10: We are looking to speak to people who have been diagnosed with uveitis whose disease is non-infectious and is intermediate, posterior and/or panuveitis i.e. non-anterior.
0/post_text/11: What does taking part involve?
0/post_text/12: If you are interested in being part of this research the research would take the form of a one on one interview lasting 60 minutes that would take place in your home or at our offices in Central London at a date and time convenient for you.
0/post_text/13: Should you feel uncomfortable or wish to stop the interview at any time then you are free to do so
0/post_text/14: Will my personal details be kept safe?
0/post_text/15: For your peace of mind, please be assured that everything you say during the course of the study will be treated in the strictest confidence and your personal details will not be given to the pharmaceutical company that has sponsored this project or to any other third party.
0/post_text/16: We abide by the Data Protection Act and a range of industry codes of conduct (including British Healthcare Business Intelligence Association (BHBIA), Market Research Society (MRS), European Pharmaceutical Market Research Association (EphMRA) guidelines), which means what you say is entirely confidential and that you are guaranteed anonymity (i.e. your name/address will at no point be passed on to any third parties) except for disclosure to which you specifically consent.
0/post_text/18: For taking part in the research you will be offered a thank you of £35 in appreciation of your contribution and your time. Alternatively we can make a donation of this amount to a charity of your choice.
0/post_text/20: If you are interested in taking part or would like further details about the market research project in order to make a decision, please contact Nancy McNeil on
0/post_text/22: (Or, alternatively, by phone on 0198 678 4325) letting her know when is it best to contact you, along with your contact details.
0/post_text/23: Please be assured that your participation in this project is entirely voluntary and should you wish to, or need to pull out of the process, for any reason, you may do so at any time.
0/post_text/24: Cello Health Insight is a market research company which specialises in the healthcare industry. Our projects help the healthcare industry to better understand the needs of people living with various health conditions. Should you wish to find more information about us, our web site is
0/post_text/27: We look forward to hearing from you, and thank you for your help.

0/post_text/1: I'd just like to say firstly that I think your website is great and has made me not quite so alone having being diagnosed with uveitis. I love any comments of my story to give me confidence that I am getting the right treatment as I am becoming a little disheartened lately whilst trying to stay positive.  Here goes...I initially started with a sore right eye which after 2 days became much worse, I attend my local opticians suspecting I may have a ulcer due to my contact lenses. I was told she couldn't see an ulcer or anything but would get one her colleagues to do a 2nd check. The colleague immediately sent me to the emergency eye hospital closeby telling me I had a sever case of uveitis.  That night I had a dexamethasone  injection into the eye and was given eye drops and given an appointment for outpatients the next week.  I was back in the emergency clinic 2 days later as it had become much worse, unbearable. More injections, scans- was told they couldn't see into my eye as it was so severe- very 'soupy', started oral steroids 60mg, several eye drops and commenced toxoplasmosis treatment, had syphilis tests, lfts, fbc, chest X-ray- all clear.  I lost most vision in the eye for several weeks and over the course of the next few months it did improve.  Now 7 months later it's still ongoing, they tried twice to reduce my oral steroids and each time it come back with a vengeance so now I am back upto 20mg prednisolone and was told they may consider a vitrectomy or immunosuppressants if I have another relapse.  I forget which type I have been told it is either intermediate or panuveitis , I can't remember.

0/post_text/0: Chloe is on Infliximab, Methotrexate and Maxidex eye drops once a day. At her appointment yesterday we were told her left eye was clear but her right eye as some cells. My question is does the treatment aim for completely clear eyes or will she always have some issues?
1/post_text/1: The ideal is no cells. If there were very few cells and you didn't need to increase Chloe's dose of mtx and/or infliximab, then I wouldn't worry too much.
1/post_text/2: It's impossible to say if Chloe will always have some issues and only her doctor can answer this. I'm on the same meds as Chloe and experienced a flare after a year of no inflammation. It was upsetting, but in the grand scheme of things, the flare was over within a month by adding two drops for two weeks and one drop for two weeks, sight wasn't affected and a slight flare was nothing in comparison with the constant inflammation, constant cystoid macular oedema and uncertain sight one day to the next, pre infliximab. (I should mention this rationality was definitely NOT present at the time of the flare itself).
1/post_text/3: I hope Chloe's eye is settling now and this flare is just a blip.
1/post_text/4: Take care,

1/post_text/0: Sorry, Katie, I've no idea what you can expect. If there are lengthy intervals between the episodes and they clear up easily with drops, I can't see that there is a problem apart from time off to attend an eye clinic.
1/post_text/1: In the UK, there are all sorts of employment laws concerning discrimination and health so I would think it would be difficult to retract an offer of appointment in most fields of employment just because you have medically managed uveitis which hasn't affected your sight.
1/post_text/2: Good luck,
1/post_text/3: Maxine.
1/topic_title: Appointment with Occupational Health doctor before employment
2/post_text/0: Hi Katie
2/post_text/1: Ive had experience in employing candidayes with ongoing  health problems who understandably havep had the same concerns as you. Employers decide on whether to employ someone kr not on 'capability' and by law first and foremost must be prepared to make all reasonable adjustments to enable you to do your job - as Maxine says it is against the law to discriminate. The role of occupational health is to support you in any way they can in order that you can do your job. The big factor is that you mentioned that you have no symptoms that prevent you doing the job so obviously best to emphasise that and Im sure it will be fine
2/post_text/2: Goodluck !

0/post_text/0: Hi my son is 14 years old and has Bilateral persistent anterior uveitis, he was diagnosed when he was 5 years old and has been on steroids drops ever since, just before Christmas 2017 he started on 20mg of methotrexate injections, and I have noticed an increase in negative behaviours and today he has been excluded from school for two days, I am unsure if this is just a coincident or can methotrexate impact on behaviours.
0/topic_title: increase in negative behaviours since starting methotrexate
1/post_text/0: Your best bet probably is to discuss this with the rheumatologist or uveitis consultant. Methotrexate can cause problems for children, mostly nausea and tiredness. Putting up with those alone, every week, could cause a change in behaviour. Perhaps it is the methotrexate itself. Given the timing of the change in your son's behaviour if he's not suffering physical side effects, could it be that he's fed up of having uveitis and the change from topical treatment to injections has had more of an impact on him than anyone realises? Adults struggle with this disease, so how 14 year olds cope with it is beyond me.
1/post_text/1: Think you need professional input so your son doesn't suffer needlessly if a change in treatment will do the trick or psychological support could help him. Letting the school know you're seeking medical advice might help with anything they are planning. There's quite a difference between a child causing problems while growing up and a child struggling with a disease or side effects of meds.

3/post_text/0: Hey, sorry, didn't realise there were replies. Floaters, yes, thousands. However I had an epiretinal membrane peel so they 'hoovered' out my vitreous which cleared a lot of them from my left eye. Still got large ones in my less active right eye, especially since the vitreous collapsed a few years ago.
3/post_text/1: As for the query about managing, it hasn't been quiet for 27 years, it's flared on and off a lot. I had a five year break this time. But you could put that down to being pregnant and breastfeeding for 2 years. I always think hormones play a part in my case.

0/post_text/0: Hi, I was just wondering if anyone who has this could answer a question. I was diagnosed with IU in April and have been on continous drops since then, but have tapered done to one drop of Maxidex a day. It's in one eye only. At a recent appointment I was told everything was fine, but my vision is still blurry and have floaters. Has anyone else experienced this? Did this stop when you stopped the drops? Does it never settle down? Ps, any tips for coping with this at work? I work at a computer (up to eight hours a day. Should I tell my human resources manager?
1/post_text/1: When the intermediate uveitis in one of my eyes stopped and I was still using drops for anterior uveitis, there was no blurriness. My vision was the same as it was pre uveitis, but the floaters and blobs were still there. Blurriness came when the cataract started to develop. A dry eye may also cause blurriness. Is your vision sharper looking through a pinhole?
1/post_text/2: I did tell HR - with the hours off for appointments, there wasn't much choice. Think it depends on how you expect them to be of help. Anke has said that a matt screen helps her - would HR provide this for you?

2/post_text/0: Hi Helen,
2/post_text/1: I've only ever had anterior uveitis, but find my vision blurs quite quickly - either with inflammation, or steroid drops. I've learnt to give it time after stopping all drops and the blurriness tends to disappear (apart from the cataract induced blurriness - but that is much more pronounced for me if I'm on drops) It would have been a costly mistake had I listened to the doctor once who said my vision should be fine - I very nearly had new glasses made which I could have thrown out a few weeks later!
2/post_text/2: As for computer work... as Maxine has said I tend to favour matt screens, and also avoiding direct overhead lights which cause reflections. You can also get screens which you place in front of monitors which may be able to help, I usually work on laptops so it's a little more tricky. In previous flares I've tried to have lights turned off before (requires some colleague negotiations...) Also, increasing the font sizes in all programs, decreasing the contrast in applications (e.g. changing the background colour in Excel to a very light grey rather than white) all helps... I find the size of the font on my screen is often a good indicator for how well I can see! I also told HR although we're a fairly small company and my boss had seen my red eye just before I was first diagnosed - the sales manager drove me to the hospital...!

1/post_text/1: Can whole heatedly believe that you have had a continual chronic uveitis for 5 years my son has uveitis continually for what will be 2 years in August. Uveitis is a complete nightmare, it can very persistent and soul destroying but there are people in the UK, with chronic uveitis, who have found the right doctors and after a struggle have managed to get their uveitis in remission. My family are still trying..... Keep thinking we are moving forward and then something whether it be a dodgy blood test result or more cells crops up. Contact OV directly, Maxine might be able to recommend a uveitis specialist centre that is near to you, so you can start the referral process. Best to go to your GP with a name and centre in mind. You can't be expecting to get on ... Well you can but sooner or later steroid induced complications will strike. Most doctors are just blissfully ignorant with regard to chronic uveitis.

0/post_text/1: I'm a fellow sufferer for the last 5 years, my treatment plan is next to nothing at the minute really. I've yet to find a doc that is fully interested in me getting better treatment. I Constantly have a flare up and that's not a lie. The longest I've gone in the last 5 years without steroids is 4 months!!! Anyone else have the same problems?? I'm hla b27 and told to get on with it surely not....
2/post_text/3: there is a list of them. The fact that you are still using steroid after 5 years worries me a bit as the side effect may kick in soon. In my case I got cataract and steroid was possibly partly attributed to my high IOP as well, both of which were more severe than the inflammation.
2/post_text/4: However please don't be too disheartened. The fact that I have been with this for so many years and still manage to keep my eyes intact without surgeries means you may be the same. I also got quite bad doctors to begin with, and only found a decent one since last year. But I always regret not finding a specialist earlier and stop steroid before all the side effects.
3/post_text/1: B27 associated uveitis can respond to treatment slightly differently, so it is useful to know that. I would also strongly encourage you to seek a specialist referral - it's time to break that cycle! I started with 3 separate flares in one eye, a year off (yay!) and then the other eye became chronically inflamed - I think I could only have about 2 weeks off steroid at the time before it would kick off again.
3/post_text/2: I found my specialist, we started immunosuppression and importantly he had me slow down the final taper completely - so rather than one drop a day for a week then stop, it became one drop/day, then one drop every other day, and then only stop. I've since learnt this is a B27 thing - we often know when we're flaring very early, and can therefore do a short sharp burst of steroid to stop it in it's tracks - then weaning off very slowly. The overall steroid load was smaller for me this way, which is definitely a good thing.
3/post_text/3: In time, we broke that horrid chronic cycle with immunosuppression - my steroid induced cataract hasn't changed, so that's good. I found it helpful to print out info on the Stepladder treatment Approach from the
3/post_text/5: site when asking my GP for a specific referral - and had no problems with that.

0/post_text/1: Im jessica and I have suffered with uveitis in my left eye along with secondary glaucoma since I was 16. I started on treatment of steroid tablets, I reacted very badly to these and had to be taken off them. When first diagnosed I felt helpless as no one understood how it felt to have this condition as there is so little information and awareness out there about it and every symptom I felt I tended to try and ignore for fear of looking for an underlying cause which wasn't there. Five years later, my body is still not the same, I have gone from 6 different eyedrops daily down to 3 different drops - Azopt twice daily, Pred forte twice daily, Nevenac four times daily. Once my doctor discovered Nevenac after asking a specialised doctor in a conference one day as she was so frustrated with my fluctuating eye pressure and unstable condition my treatment has completely changed. I have gone from visiting the hospital every two weeks to visiting every three months which has taken the burden off my life a lot, my condition is now stable it has not gone away it is just at a level that she is happy that it is not causing catastrophic damage. I have also since then developed a cataract in my left eye as a result of constant use of steroids and high pressure.
0/post_text/2: I am still convinced even though my doctor has given up hope that I have something underlying within my body that is causing this problem as I have recently started being treated for psoriasis in my scalp which is very painful and is not very reactive to treatment. I have also started to develop problems with my bowels that I have never had before and I constantly feel sick whenever I eat. I was wondering if anyone has had these problems and found an underlying cause for their uveitis?
1/post_text/5: Not sure what type of uveitis you have. Uveitis does not always have an underlying condition. There will always be charlatans out there to tell u what u want to hear. What is your cell count?
2/post_text/3: Since your uveitis is chronic and requires daily treatment, I would be inclined to ask for referral to a uveitis specialist who sees chronic cases all the time and will be able to give answers to your questions about possible cause.  There are excellent specialists in Manchester. Your GP or eye doctor could make this referral for you. It's probably better to wait until you have answers to autoimmune issues before consulting a nutritionist and if one is needed, I would ask your GP to recommend one so you avoid Ghost's charlatans.
2/post_text/4: Don't be embarrassed about seeking a consultation with a uveitis specialist. You've had uveitis for five years now, you have pressure problems and a developing cataract alongside psoriasis which isn't responding well to treatment and bowel issues. You need the input of an expert, someone who deals with these things all the time.

1/post_text/1: Welcome to OV.  Does your daughter have JIA associated uveitis?
1/post_text/2: My daughter hasn't been on MM but I know many children who have.  It's tolerated very well by many children, but like all these meds there are a proportion who feel very sick on it. If a child tolerates Mtx well from a nausea perspective they tend to tolerate MM (also known as Cellcept) well.
1/post_text/3: There are quite a few adult sufferers and some parents on here whose children have been on MM and hopefully they'll post their experiences, but how one child reacts rarely has any bearing on how the next child will react ...Just remember that if your daughter can't tolerate a particular drug there are alternatives. My own daughter has been through mtx, ciclosporin, tacrolimus and hummira!

4/post_text/1: Sorry to hear about Katie.  I am an adult uveitis sufferer on MMF and thought I would let you know my experiences while acknowledging that we are all individuals and each of us may have different side effects and tolerances of medication.
4/post_text/2: I was unable to tolerate MTX or Azathioprine and have been on MMF since May last year.  Personnally I have been able to tolerate MMF much better.  Having said that I felt very tired for the first 7 months.  The tiredness has now mostly gone but sometimes my legs ache a bit.  My main problem has been with my stomach which I understand is a common side effect with MMF.  I am now working with my GP to try and find some additional medication which will settle my stomach.  From speaking to my rheumatology nurse, many patients have no side effects from MMF whatsoever and it is generally tolerated much better than MTX and AZA.  Fingers crossed that is the case for Katie.
4/post_text/3: The MMF is definitely helping my uveitis and the inflamation is being reduced although I'm not in remission yet.  I have been able to dramatically reduce the number of steriod eye drops in my left eye and have completely stopped the drops in my right.  Onwards and upwards.

0/post_text/0: Hello, this is my first post on here and I have found reading the threads on this forum very helpful.  I hope someone can help me. We, my huband and I, thought the Dr told me that I would have a Uvi Test – neither of us understood that he said I had Uveitis, as I had never heard of it before.  When I told the Dr. that I was using eye drops (for dry eyes) about 12x times a day but they weren’tgiving me any relief he prescribed, steroid eyedrops, Maxidex for one month.  He said that he would write to Moorfields, Tooting to make an appointment for me.  If my symptoms cleared up before my appointment then I should cancel it,  as the tests done at the hospital would not show what the problem was if the condition had cleared up.  The condition hasn’t really cleared up as my eye is very dry, my vision is abit blurred, more floaters and feels very sore.  I have not received a hospital appointment.  I don’t know what I should do now, should I go back to Moorfields in the City again?, if it hasn’t cleared up completely after one month.  After reading different threads on the forum I understand that the tests for Uveitis include a Chest x-ray regardless of whether you are having a Uveitis flare-up.  Also you can just go to the Uveitis Clinic held on a Thursday at Moorfields, Tooting.  I already am an out-patient at Moorfields Tooting, for another eye condition, and understood that you could not go there unless you had an appointment.  So can I just go there then on a Thursday?

0/post_text/1: On another thread I noted a lady said that she had IBD.  I have IBS and after seeing two gastroenterologists I was referred to a dietician and put on the Low-Fodmap diet which is a diet that eliminates different food stuffs as IBS sufferers cannot tolerate certain food sources.  That has restricted what I can eat and then a few months ago after having a blood test I was told I had high cholesterol (my mother had a stroke so it is generic) and I now have to follow two very restrictive diets.  This has caused me so much stress that I am sure that my gut problems and me having Ehlers- Danlos Syndrome is having a direct impact on my overall health particularly my eyes.
3/post_text/1: I'm sorry it was too much trouble for your GP to actually help you with the promised appointment. Unfortunately many do not know much about uveitis. You have done the right things - waited for an appointment letter and then sought the assistance of your GP.

3/post_text/3: I would ring eye emergency at Tooting or St George's and say you have been on Maxidex for a month following a diagnosis of uveitis and have received no follow up appointment to check your inflammation and the impact of steroid drops on your eye pressure although an appointment in a (uveitis clinic ?) was promised four weeks after diagnosis. Mention that you are a first time user (?)of Maxidex, state that your symptoms have not improved and your eye hurts. If you don't get invited to attend the clinic you ring, perhaps just turn up at the other one?
5/post_text/1: I shouldn't be cynical (because the NHS is fantastic when it works) but the whole process of getting and receiving appointments is a nightmare. My heart sinks if a doctor says they write a letter because you know it will take two weeks for the letter to be typed up. Another week for it to arrive. Another two weeks for the letter to get to the right department etc, etc. I don't know what is wrong with email! Then you have to wait for available space.
7/post_text/1: When I went to A&E the Dr told me that he would make an appointment for me to have tests after I had completed the course of eye-drops.  I just understood that the tests weren't done in A&E  I tapered the Maxidex drops down from 4 drops in the first week to 1 drop in the fourth week. The letter sent to my gp from A&E stipulated,treatment: Uveitis review in 4-6/52, which I received after I started my first post.  Perhaps if I had known at the onset that the review would have been in 4/6 weeks and not 4 weeks, I might not have started getting so worried.   Because I have had a vitreous detachment in the eye that now has Uveitis I am, I think, understandably over-anxious.
8/post_text/1: I just want to say how much comfort your posts have given me.  I think, for those who have just been diagnosed with Uveitis, that there should be some readily available material and written in layman's terms. I did not understand that if the uveitis had cleared up, with steriods how nothing would show up when you had tests done, blood tests, and either\both a chest or back x-ray.

0/post_text/0: Hello, I've decided to get my head out of the sand. My son is seven and was diagnosed with jia and uveitis when he was one. He's been on steroid drops all of this time and also dilating drops. He's also been on methotrexate and was put on humira last July. A couple of weeks ago we went for a check up and found out the vision in his right eye had all but gone due to a cataract. This was a huge shock as he hadn't complained and his sight was ok when we were there 4 weeks previously. He had the cataract removed last week and we are waiting for him to hopefully get contacts so he can see.
1/post_text/1: Firstly, hope that your son is doing OK. It must of been a horrible few weeks, a huge shook then surgery.
1/post_text/2: I always have HUGE trouble with this. I also have trouble with consultant letters that come through the door! They always cause me a lot of grief! There are two types of flare, there is the one that counts the cells and there is another type of flare which grades the amount of 'liquid released by the cells'. Now that really is how I understand it and I would quite happily hold my hand up and say that I am happy if somebody corrects me. So I guess the flare graded one in both eyes relates to the amount of haze 'I.e liquid left by the cells' and the grading for the cells (e.g 0.5 and 1) relates to the actual number of cells in your son's eyes. So that would be a 1 + flare and trace flare in the other according to the grading system the hospital uses.
1/post_text/3: However, it does confuse me also because I would read it as just 1 cell in one eye but you can't have half a cell (0.5) in the other. So I think I would ring the consultant's secretary and ask if the consultant could clarify his comments.
1/post_text/4: To be honest,  now when we are told my son has a such, a such flare. I have to ask - How may cells is that?  We have had incidences when my husband has taken him to an appointment and said he has one cell, which is actually not the case. He is having a 1+ flare and actually has considerably more than one cell in his eye. There is something called the SUN criteria which explains at least the grading system.

1/post_text/5: Hope that helps, rather than adds to your concussion. Maxine might be able to shed more light.
3/post_text/1: Cells are how inflammation is graded. 0.5 means 1-5 cells, 1 means 6-15 cells. Like Becca, I think of flare as haze. Flare is a way of grading any haziness they see when they look into the front of the eye. A '1' for flare, I suppose, could be described as a  slight haze. Flare is a by product of the inflammatory cells. Hopefully Connor's next Humira injection will sort out the little bit of inflammation he has.
3/post_text/2: I'm glad Connor has perked up now. It's so sad that young children go through this surgery.
3/post_text/3: Hope next week's appointment goes well and Connor's eye has settled after the surgery.

I know that some cataracts can grow quickly but just for reassurance I would get his other eye checked as soon as possible. Just encase his vision loss in the other eye is not caused by a cataract. I am shocked how quickly his cataracts have grown.  I really feel for you and Connor, it is just horrible handing your child over for an operation. Then just to watch as they struggle afterwards.

3/post_text/0: Hope the injection went well Nicole.
4/post_text/0: No I am at harrogate hospital. I have been on 2 hourly steriod drops for about 8-9 weeks and no inprovement. Well the anterior segment improved but the intermediate and the macular edema persisted although from what I gather, i was only getting the injection because of the macular edema and not because I had inflamation (although hopefully the steriod will clear that too). Leads me to think that If i had just had the inflamation, they would hve continued with the eye drops which, after doing research seems to be the wrong treatment. As for the injection, the procedure was fine, they make a big deal about it though. You properly get admitted then discharged and i had to get changed into gowns. I wasnt even allowed to walk back from theatre. It was painless and quick though. The worst part of the procedure was the clip they put on to keep eyelids open but it doesnt hurt, just an odd feeling. The afternoon afterwards was horrible though. My eyeball was swollen and it bulged out oddly amd was pretty painful. Its only mildly sore today. I think i have a small patch of subconjunctiva hemorrage as well. Im just hoping it works and I dont have to have another one as I dont want the after effects again! I think it has about 2-3 months to see if it works.

1/post_text/1: I am sorry this has happened to Oz but the situation was similar for Harrison who is now 4.  We too were told that he has conjunctivitis and for 12 days was on cream that was obviously doing him no good.  A more on the ball GP referred us to Moorfields where he was diagnised with uveitis and they think he probably had it for a long long time.  I really sympathise with you as they can give no answer as to why Harrison has it and although in one respect I am so grateful he does not have any other underlying condition as so many children with this condition do, I am still yearning to find out why.
1/post_text/2: I am not going to try and give you good medical advice as I am only learning about the condition myself and there are others on this site who are much more well informed than me, but I am learning and I bet you are too!! Harrison too has tested negative on all the bloods but he is now being referred to an immunologist as he has no anti bodies to chickenpox even though he has had it.  His tonsils are always enlarged and if I took him to a GP today they would prescribe antibiotics even though he is fine as they would automatically think he has tonsilitis.  However, we do know his immune system is hyperactive and so an immunologist is the next step.  Please let me know how you get on.  Harrison is down to one Maxidex drop per day and this is the best its been since January when he was diagnosed too. I have to say that you son must be ever so brave with the injections as we have luckily not had to do this with Harrison.  But it does happen with no other symptoms and if you are anything like me you are constantly looking out for things just in case.  Its hard to think "why" when you son is so healthy in other ways.
1/post_text/3: Do let us know how you and Oz get on.

2/post_text/4: Is sarcoidosis in the eye a definite diagnosis, or have you been told you have granulotomous uveitis which may be a symptom of sarcoidosis? Sometimes granulotomous uveitis is a result of other past infections in the body like Rob explained some time ago and disease is not found in the rest of the body.
2/post_text/5: Sarcoidosis sometimes doesn't show up on a chest x-ray, but might be seen on more precise imaging tests, like CT. Presumably you would need to be referred to rheumatology by your GP for further tests to find out.
2/post_text/6: If you know you have sarcoidosis in the eye, we have links to sarcoidosis support groups on the links page. It might be worth getting in touch with these groups to see if their members can be of any help. The information and support group have an eye forum on their site.

0/post_text/0: If you look through pinhole in black paper,you
1/post_text/0: This will save millions of eyes I'm third world.
0/post_text/1: See the iritis cells in anterior chamber.
0/post_text/2: You look through pinhole at light source. I lay on bed and look at round led ceiling light. It takes concentration.
0/post_text/3: great way to detect iritis/uveitis early.
0/post_text/4: They used to use this technique to detect cataracts but it has been lost to history/patient apathy.
0/post_text/5: For stability, use occluder with black duct tape over hole. Make a couple holes in tape because you need the right sized hole for best results.
0/post_text/6: The iritis cells are in foreground and move independently of each other when there are not too many. When there are lots they may not appear much different than floater. They seem to move from top to bottom when disturbed. Floaters
0/post_text/7: In vitreous appear as groups of cells moving in unison. You may have to learn by doing this
0/post_text/8: When you have a flare. You may have to flick eye to get floater moving. You should see clear areas between floaters if you dontdohave iritis. Iritis cells will be seen
0/post_text/9: Floating on top of floaters. When the doctor says your iritis is at trace/resolved, there will still be thousands of iritis cells visible through pinhole. When doc says you have zero cells, you will still see a few cells in entire eye. The cells appear as round circles.
0/post_text/10: You may see the nucleus of the cell. You will see any iritis scars on lens capsule, Wrinkles in cornea and lens. Pieces of iris torn off from sticking appear as chains of cells which
0/post_text/11: Corral the iritis cells. They hang around for couple weeks. Its the cells that cause the blurred vision. Of course, you need 1+ cells to blur vision so blurred vision not good early detection method. When you have iritis, there will be no clear areas there
0/post_text/13: Will be cells touching everywhere.no floater visible
0/post_text/14: Most people seem to wait for pain which is too long. Sticking can occur before pain. Its the inflamed iris that causes pain not necessarily

6/post_text/0: Hi to you, Anke, thanks for your response and nice to meet you.
6/post_text/1: There are some lovely people on this site - so supportive and non-judgemental.  Over the last few days I've found that to be a real Godsend as I am widowed and live alone. (A fact that has probably exacerbated the anxiety over the last few weeks!!)
6/post_text/2: One of the worst things for me has been sleep deprivation because of pain and also not having anyone around to give me a hug when I'm feeling sorry for myself at 3 in the morning!  Moreover, because the only outward signs are a red eye, strained face, along with purple shadows below my eyes due to sleep deprivation, I'm certain that some of my colleagues at work aren't sure if I'm 'swinging the lead' or not when I've ventured in to the city with a second sick note!!
6/post_text/3: On a positive note, since going down to 40mgs Prednisolone yesterday, I had 5hrs sleep last night, only woke up twice (and put the Pred drops in!) and woke proper at 6 this morning....absolutely fantastic! And.... my knees aren't painful,swollen and red any more.  Although my eye now feels 'gritty', there is no pain to speak of (that tends to come on at the end of a long day) the redness has gone down and, fingers crossed, apart from blurring, I'm sure I can 'see' a little better today. I've even got my appetite back which is a big bonus because I am a bit of a 'skinny minnie'!  I'm rattling a bit though - Omeprazole, prednisolone, voltarol, Nefopam, Protelos,Calcium and Vit B, Fortisip as well as the pred drops and restarted the stinging Mydrilate this morning!!  Thank God for pre-payment prescription cards - the hospital pharmacist advised me to get one and she has saved me a fortune!!
6/post_text/4: Just hope the improvement continues come Sunday when I'm due to drop the Prednisolone another 10mgs to 30mgs daily!

1/post_text/5: Good luck tomorrow - really hope you are told the inflammation is subsiding. Good luck too with the steroid side effects.
2/post_text/3: Going to appointments demented with worry and side effects, I used to take a list of questions. It made things simpler. If you read this in time, I'd ask what has happened to your pupil. Is there more adhesion or less? Does it look stranger because atropine has magnified the effect of the adhesion? I'd also ask what effect the steroid is having on the inflammation - ask for the cell count and the flare and what these figures were for the appointment when oral steroid was prescribed. If they haven't reduced, ask for an explanation and a plan of what will be done next.
2/post_text/4: Getting to a rheumatologist is a must, so I really hope you see the same doc you saw last time. If she's in clinic, ask to see her and say you don't mind waiting to do so.
3/post_text/1: considering you're on high dose steroid I thought you were incredibly coherent!  Uveitis knocks you off your feet at the best of times but throw in steroids, sight loss, joint pain and worry and it's a recipe to make the most stable person into a nervous wreck.
3/post_text/2: I'm delighted you have a supportive GP, this will make all the difference.  As Maxine said ask if there's been any improvement concerning the level of flare and active cells.  Both are measured on a scale of 0 - 4+
3/post_text/3: Best of luck for todays appointment, let us know how you get on.
5/post_text/1: So pleased to hear that there has been improvement in the inflammation and that it sounds like you're now getting thorough care! I find that my visual acuity is impacted quite quickly by any drops - either dilating or steroid - but with patience it has generally returned to as good as before - one "advantage" (?!) of HLA-B27 uveitis is that I can now tell when I'm flaring so tend to catch it very early.
7/post_text/1: My Prof's office is also used for a paediatric clinic. There was once a teddy bear sitting on a shelf amongst the books. It shouted, 'Hug me,' when held. Have occasionally thought we adults could do with that bear as much as the kids!
8/post_text/1: Good news that the inflammation is being brought under control. At least you know there is benefit from the high dose steroid.
8/post_text/2: I wish the rheumatologist appointment were sooner than October, so that you could be started on something else, if needed, while the steroid is being reduced.
8/post_text/3: It is normal to feel down when high dose steroid is being reduced and also to feel physically uncomfortable. I remember using over the counter nsaids for the stomach discomfort and also took probiotics. Whether it was time or probiotics, the discomfort passed in a couple of weeks. The low mood persisted for ages and after the intense weepy stage, I just tried to avoid situations where I knew I'd be rapidly provoked into snapping. Most people find tapering off steroid very difficult - you're not the exception with that one!
5/post_text/2: Best of luck with the oral steroid taper - hope you get more sleep very soon - and thank you for sharing the lovely family pic with us!
6/post_text/5: Thank you to everyone who has supported me and good luck to the lady with blurry vision  and bilateral uveitis who mentioned me in her post, so sorry I can't remember your name.
7/post_text/2: Hope the next reduction in Pred goes OK and seeing a little better continues.
7/post_text/3: Take care,
8/post_text/4: I sometimes wonder how many people with uveitis actually escape getting a cataract eventually. From the docs' point of view, it's far better to save sight and cause a cataract in the process, than to let sight slip away. However, when it's your eye, you want your sight preserved without developing a cataract! The short sighted do get a bit of a bonus though - a lens implanted that gives good distance vision.
8/post_text/5: Without steroid messing up emotion, I suspect relief would be the dominant one right now. The inflammation is being brought under control and that's the most important thing.
8/post_text/6: Good luck with the taper and hope the cells continue to be snuffed out.
9/post_text/1: Thanks for your response. Like I said, I'm totally fed up now. It seems to be one thing after another and I've reached the end of my tether. My life for almost 2 months has revolved around predforte (mostly hourly, but less on occasion!),oral prednisolone, mydrilate/atropine and trips to the local hospital and my gp. I have followed the treatment regime to the letter and still there are problems!
9/post_text/2: As for the ulcerative keratitis - I don't think Mr Redmill knows why I've got ulcer/s on my cornea! I did tell him I was on antibiotics for a bacterial infection in my foot and a chest infection, plus I'd had a tablet for a fungal infection/ulcers in my mouth and Daktarin gel as well. As I said, he did ask me whether I'd ever had a cold sore - the answer is no! My ex-husband suffered with them and kissing was out of bounds if he had an active sore!  I think Mr Redmill is just treating the ulcer/s with aciclovir as a 'let's see if it's that' treatment! So, I'm doing as I'm told but all the time I'm getting more anxious because I've subsequently read that corneal ulcers can cause scarring which affects your vision and if not treated properly can cause blindness!
9/post_text/3: I may ask for an appointment to see my gp tomorrow - if I'm up to it! The Rheumatologist appointment is 3 October which isn't so far away now.  As for the referral to see Prof Rennie in sheffield, been told it could be months and I have no idea how I can track progress, if any, in that department.
9/post_text/4: I'm back at the hospital at 9am on Friday - if you have any questions you think i should ask please let me know as I'm completely lost now :(
2/post_text/5: Really hope there are signs of the inflammation reducing this afternoon. When you feel up to it, please post again and tell us how you got on.

0/post_text/0: Fight for Sight would like a uveitis patient (or two) to attend this meeting. If you are free on Tuesday, April 16th and would like to meet with uveitis professionals, other uveitis patients and the major charity working to prevent avoidable sight loss as well as helping those with visual impairment, it's an opportunity not to be missed! It's a chance to find out more about our disease and to let those treating us and helping us know about our concerns. The uveitis team at the Birmingham Eye Centre are among the professionals attending.

0/post_text/0: Hi, I'm sarah and and son is Owen, Owen is now 8 years old. Three years ago we posted a few times on here talking about Owen bilateral anterior uveitis, and after a year of steroid drops and dilating drops his cells decreased right down, 2 years of close monitoring saw it not reappearing, amazing news.  Then 3 days before Christmas Owen complained if not being able to see much, it was so much more than that, he couldn't even see my nose eyes or mouth, just a blurry outline of my face.  Rather than do our usual mad rush and trek to Alderhey children's hospital our local optician agreed to take a look immediately, after some photos which they couldn't do because he couldn't see and the slit lamp we were told to get straight to Alderhey as it was very serious.  We made our way there, to the eye clinic, they were waiting for us with his notes, and for hours different doctors came and looked at his eyes.

1/post_text/1: I don't know how you are holding it together at all. This time last year my son was in Great Ormond Street hospital and I would fairly regularly have a sob in hospital loos and hospital chapel and I wasn't 6 weeks pregnant with all the complications and anxieties that can cause.
1/post_text/2: I read what you have written and I feel all my fears churning and bubbling around inside, we were not sat down and told that our son could go blind but we were sat down and told that he was at high risk of having a Stroke, that was bad enough.

I can find more information if you like or at least the name of the condition and associated support groups. But surely, the hospital must have some support. 0/post_text/0: Hi guys,
1/post_text/1: The cost of private treatment varies. Consultants charge different fees - think of £120 - 200 for a consultation. Should you need tests, for example, OCT and field of vision, in the private sector costs vary according to where the scans are done - a private hospital might charge £400 plus for an OCT and field of vision, whereas an NHS centre may charge a private patient approx. £250 for the same tests. On top of this, you have the cost of drugs. Eye drops, steroid and glaucoma, vary from a few pounds to £25 plus. A local pharmacist would give you the exact costs for the ones you currently use. Small independent pharmacies will sometimes charge less than the large chains.
1/post_text/2: If your uveitis requires you to move along from steroid onto immunosuppressants or anti virals (Herpes) again the cost of drugs varies from the relatively cheap methotrexate (pounds) to the very expensive anti tnfs (thousands per year). There are also the associated costs of regular blood tests. It's impossible to give you figures to plan a budget for private care - too many variables!
1/post_text/3: Quite a few people combine NHS with private care seeing a uveitis consultant on a private basis as need arises for a second or expert opinion on a way forward. Private care is manageable when the uveitis is straightforward to treat, but horribly expensive if it's more complex and requires surgical treatment as well as the medical.
1/post_text/4: Perhaps you are best off booking an initial private consultation to discuss your symptoms and whether you are best off having NHS or private care? The majority of the uveitis consultants working in the private sector are also NHS consultants. There is a thread below yours (George - Prof A.) which discusses some of the issues and if you are London based, several members are in a position to give you more precise advice about who to see or which NHS uveitis clinic to attend.

4/post_text/2: Sabine's idea of asking for a referral to a uveitis clinic is a very good idea. Having Crohns as well as uveitis suggests both conditions could possibly be treated together and being seen in a uveitis clinic helps this to happen if it's appropriate. If after asking for referral, you still have to use A&E because you can't get into a uveitis clinic, someone years ago got round the problem of a lengthy wait by arriving at the emergency eye clinic before it opened. Another thing you could do if you recognise when an attack is beginning, is ask if you could be prescribed a spare bottle of drops so you can self treat before being seen and thus avoid the wait in blinding pain. Of course this does not mean it's okay to self treat and avoid the eye clinic altogether!! You should still go in within 24 hours to make sure what's happening in your eyes and have pressures checked!

3/post_text/2: With regards to his veins I used to have the same problem, until a wonderful male nurse who took my blood through my first pregnancy solved the problem.  He said it's not the veins it's just that the nurses automatically choose the bigger juicier one thinking it will be easier to take the blood from, when in fact they need to take blood from the smaller vein to the side which is buried a bit more deeply.

Am I right to worry?Sorry about my spelling, I have got bad eyes lol, please help
1/post_text/1: Sorry to hear that the uveitis is back! and bilateral too. It's good to hear that the clinic is doing blood tests already at this stage - what they will most likely be looking for is various markers indicating possible autoimmune causes (such as those related to rheumatoid arthritis or ankylosing spondylitis) It is possible that they may not find anything, this is then known as idiopathic uveitis - either way it's good that they are doing these investigations as it can influence the treatment choice if necessary. I know it's easier said than done, but try not to worry about it for now - it's good that they're doing the investigation, but the most important thing right now is to get your eyes quiet again which is what the Maxidex is for.
1/post_text/2: I find my vision blurs even just on Maxidex - after one of my early uveitis episodes I questioned the blurriness with one of the doctors who said it should all be fine again (I'm short sighted anyway...) - so I went and had another prescription done for glasses. I ended up waiting to order them due to the cost of the lenses and found a few weeks later that my vision had returned to "normal" (or at least normal for me... my previous prescription was fine!) So - as frustrating as blurry vision is, I now try to ignore it as best as possible until some time after being clear of ALL drops! Hopefully you'll also find an improvement in vision when your eyes are quiet!

6/post_text/0: Hi Ally,
6/post_text/1: You could try using celluvisc drops which are artificial tears without preservative to see if those help with the dryness. Wait about twenty minutes after putting in a steroid drop before using the dry eye one. Blurriness is sometimes caused by dry eyes. Tesco stock celluvisc on the pharmacy counter.
6/post_text/2: It's difficult to say if the persistent blurriness is normal. For some, the blurriness is caused by the drops and for others blurred sight can mean ongoing inflammation. The cause is something only a doctor can tell you with certainty.
6/post_text/3: Your next appointment is still some time away so if you are very worried, or you think your sight has worsened since the last appointment, you could try to have it brought forward or go to the emergency clinic.
6/post_text/4: The first attack of uveitis is incredibly frightening and upsetting and I'd go as far as to say it brings many of us close to tears through the anxiety it causes. One of our members summed it up by saying he was ready to move into the eye clinic with his bed and I could have done with someone looking at my eyes three times a day, but would still have been worried. Perhaps that is the 'normal' patient reaction?

1/post_text/1: I'm so sorry to hear that Freya was diagnosed with JIA and related uveitis at such a young age! She does sound like an absolute star though, even through all the horrible investigations and meds.
1/post_text/2: I'm an adult with uveitis, currently on Humira and MTX, so can't comment on having to take decisions for my child although I'm sure Nicki and the other parents will join in with their experiences. Often uveitis requires higher doses of MTX than JIA though - has increasing this dose ever been considered? Injectable MTX does get absorbed better than oral MTX so that may well be a good route to go.
1/post_text/3: For most of us, it takes a number of medication tweaks to get the right dose, or medication/medication combo to put the uveitis into remission. In my case, my MTX dose ranges from 15 - 25mg, and we tried two other medication combinations before settling on Humira/MTX which I love. I also have ankylosing spondylitis, and thought I'd "save" Humira for when I needed it for that in the future - but a bilateral sight-threatening flare last February essentially removed that decision and I haven't regretted it at all.

4/post_text/0: Hi Sam,
4/post_text/1: This is a tricky one!  If you tell her too much about the shots then she'll be terrified but you have to give her some sort of warning.  If she's ever pricked her finger on a badge safety pin or something like that tell her it will be a similar feeling but over really quickly.  Explain that you can make the area (I inject the bottom) nice and cold first and that there's a good chance she might not even know it's been done until it's over.  Give her an ice pack or ice cube to hold eg on her arm so she understands how numb you can get the skin - I use freeze spray for instant results!  And just reassure her that the thought is worse than the deed.  She'll probably be fine the first time, it's the second time when they know what's coming that trouble can start!

2/post_text/8: SourceInterdisziplinäres Uveitiszentrum, Augenklinik, Universität Heidelberg, Im Neuenheimer Feld 400, 69120, Heidelberg, Deutschland.
2/post_text/11: Pediatric uveitis differs from uveitis seen in adulthood not only because of the uveitis presentation and severity of disease but also by a worse prognosis and age-specific problems that may occur under therapy. Biologics are selective acting proteins that are manufactured by biotechnology. The greatest amount of knowledge to date exists for the TNF alpha blocking agents. Experimental and clinical studies showed that TNF alpha plays a significant role in the process of intraocular inflammation, so it was a logical step to use TNF blocking agents in uveitis therapy. Randomized controlled studies are rare, but pooled data (as presented here) of case series published show good evidence for the efficacy especially of infliximab and adalimumab. It is to be hoped that blindness and severe sight disabilities can be further reduced by this treatment in the future. From pediatric rheumatology we have learned about even newer biologics. With this review we want to show the weaknesses and strengths of therapy with biologics and want to help in choosing this treatment at the indicated time point in the disease.
2/post_text/13: I'm pretty sure the team treating Freya will be familiar with all the studies already done on humira and will be able to allay some of your fears about starting it.
2/post_text/14: Again, really sorry you're dealing with this,

1/post_text/1: Your uveitis seems to have become chronic and as you've got a cataract forming and problems with steroid and pressure, as well as the development of intermediate uveitis, you'd probably benefit from seeing a uveitis specialist if there isn't one in your local eye clinic. A uveitis specialist will know best whether it's worthwhile doing the tests they usually do when both eyes are affected or the uveitis is chronic. Referrals to a uveitis specialist are made by the eye clinic or by your GP. Your GP can also order the blood tests and x-rays for underlying disease causing uveitis. About half of us turn out to be idiopathic - no cause identified.
1/post_text/2: I would push for referral because you no longer have simple anterior uveitis, yours has become complicated. The main specialist centres are in London, Bristol, Birmingham, Manchester, Sheffield and Newcastle. There are specialists working in other clinics and if you go to the websites of hospitals near you, the information about their eye clinics will show whether they have a uveitis clinic.
1/post_text/3: My own experience with uveitis was similar to yours to begin with. I didn't cope at all - do any of us with the type of uveitis that doesn't clear off with a course of drops cope? Getting to a specialist and a rheumatologist made things easier. I also learned as time went on that I'd be in pieces for a day or two when something new (read bad!) happened, but that a couple of days later, while I'd still be unhappy about it, I'd be back to functioning normally again. Recognising that pattern helped.
1/post_text/4: With work, educating the human resources people about the disease may help. No one's heard of it unless they, or someone close to them, gets it.

I was told there maybe a possibility I may have another flare up or I may be lucky and wouldn’t have another one. So December 2017 two weeks before Christmas and I was getting ready to go to a Christmas party and I noticed my eye was very red again and by the Monday morning I was in pain and light sensitive. I called the eye care centre and they managed to get me in that afternoon where it was confirmed that I had another flare up. I was prescribed Pred Forte every hour until review 7 days later, cyclopentolate twice a day and also Azarga twice a day.At my next appointment I was told to reduce the steroid to every two hours for 5 days and then go to 4 times a day, in the meantime at the next appointment the nurse practitioner that I saw decided to stop the steroid completely and within two days the flare up had started again and that is pretty much what has been happening for the last 6 months, I have only had one appointment where I only had a couple of inflammatory cells present and the decision was made to put me on acular a non steroid drop, I managed about 2 weeks before it flared again and ended up back at the hospital the night before I was going on holiday, I was told to increase the acular to 6 times a day and I couldn’t have a steroid as I was flying and there were concerns about the pressure. On my return from my holiday I saw the consultant who decided acular wasn’t working so then tried lotemax which didn’t work either,so back to the hospital again and now I am told I have anterior and intermediate uveitis so currently on Pred forte every 2 hours but going to 4 times a day from tomorrow and dreading it already! I feel like I am going round in circles and at the last visit I was told I have a cataract forming due to the steroids. 1/post_text/1: having been where you are now a few years ago I really feel for you.  I managed to get signed off work for a few weeks with a GP note and then a medical certificate. 1/post_text/2: I couldn't have driven, I would have been a danger on the roads, but I was on a bus route.  Do you have any friends who work/live nearby who could help you in the short term getting to and from work?  One thing you do find out is exactly who your friends are!
1/post_text/3: I think whether you're in a position to stay at home depends entirely on your financial situation.  I had no choice being single with a mortgage to pay.  Hopefully this flare up will be your first and last, but if not you'll find that over time you have no choice but to soldier on for as long as your vision allows you to.  It will help to speak to your boss/manager/HR and discuss with them your situation.  Unless they know now what's going on they can't help, or make allowances, and many will.
1/post_text/4: You could also give them the link to this website so that they can read for themselves what uveitis is, I'd also give them a link to some of the personal stories on here, not that I'm saying any of them will be applicable to you but it should drive home how awful this disease can be if chronic.

4/post_text/2: I'm afraid most of us find we know whether we're able to work or not from the emotional side of things. I continued working, albeit part time, for eight months after diagnosis with bi lateral uveitis and unable to see much at all out of one eye. After the initial shock, (time off) work served as a welcome distraction from the uveitis. It was also necessary - there was no one else to pay the mortgage and bills! Work didn't like the time off for appointments, but tolerated them.
4/post_text/3: As for driving, I was able to drive if sight in the better eye met the legal standard - approx. 6/9. That eye had dilating drops twice a day, but the drop was the lower strength cyclopentolate 0.5%. The only difficulty I had was if a road dipped into an underpass or tunnel, or being caught on the road when the sun was low. I only drove when neither of these things was a possibility and didn't drive anywhere unknown. Driving with one eye is something you get used to. Many of us  just shut the distracting, dilated one in adverse light.

14/post_text/0: The guide of max 26C means the intention is storage at room temperature which is around 20C under normal circumstances.

3/post_text/1: Welcome - although I'm sorry you had to come looking for us and that you're experiencing a nasty flare :( Both the uveitis and especially the cyclopentolate can really blur your vision (and also mess up emotions..), it's not much fun at all.
3/post_text/2: I've never had to make a decision re driving during flare-ups as I don't own a car (living in London has public transport advantages) - but I know at times I would not have been able to drive. 3/post_text/3: Regarding work - I was only booked off once with my very first flare (although had to take a fair amount of time for appointments...!), the rest of the time I more or less soldiered on... (probably a lot less productively than normal though!) Are you able to work from home at all, if that's not a normal arrangement for you could special arrangements perhaps be made? I did that when I could, as I'd then patch the "bad" eye which made it a lot easier to see with the "good". It also let me take rests more frequently, when I felt I needed them, and I was more likely to stick to the correct drop schedule if I wasn't in a meeting! Increasing font sizes on the computer in whichever way possible also helped, as did controlling the light sources around me (I'd tend to switch lights off or sit in a darker part of the office - screen reflections really bothered me!) I also did have a chat to my managers though, so they knew what was going on and could support me through it.

11/post_text/2: All pharmaceutical products should be stored at the recommended temperature range stated on the packaging. Storing products outside of recommended range can result in unintended consequences. Difficult to explain to laymen but drugs have certain forms called racemers and these have pharmacological actions that differ. Storing at a different temperature (especially lower temperatures) can change the racemer.

1/post_text/3: The high dose steroid is designed to give you cover from inflammation while the cellcept gets a chance to work. The steroid will also help with the cystoid macular oedema - fluid on the retina causing the distortion in your vision. The idea is that the cellcept, once it has built up and is working, will control the inflammation that causes the cystoid macular oedema. It may take a month or two for this to happen and if it's not having a good enough effect, Moorfields may add another immunosuppressant, often cyclosporine, so that the steroid can be reduced and even eliminated.
1/post_text/4: There are other ways of getting rid of the cystoid macular oedema, but as the most direct methods involve injections into the eye ( oddly, these hardly hurt!)I don't know if the surgery you had for your retinal tear makes these rather risky. You could ask about having the steroid injected into your eye instead of swallowing the pills and suffering the side effects, or receiving it through an iv infusion (fewer side effects). You could also ask about an injection of lucentis. I'm not sure if this is available for uveitis on the NHS, but if you have private medical insurance, it should be funded. The injections usually resolve the cystoid macular oedema, but they are pointless unless the inflammation is being controlled. If the inflammation isn't controlled, the cystoid macular oedema comes back when the effect of the injections wears off.

9/post_text/0: That's right, Colin, Lucentis is an anti vegf. It clears the fluid up, often within  two to three hours. The problem is that it doesn't treat the cause of the fliud leaking, the inflammation itself, so when the lucentis wears off about 4 weeks later, you get another bout of cystoid macular oedema. That's why I suggested you should ask if it's better to have it while you're building up the dose of Myfenax, or wait until you know the Myfenax has brought the inflammation under control.

1/post_text/5: If you go to our treatments section, you will find links to information about cellcept, how to take it and side effects. It's pretty effective at stopping inflammation.
1/post_text/6: Have Moorfields told you that your uveitis is a consequence of the surgery for your retinal detachment? I only ask because the course of traumatic uveitis might be different to uveitis which is associated with an auto immune condition. In auto immune uveitis, you can expect to take cellcept for at least two years once your eyes are cell free, then the dose is reduced slowly and if you're lucky, your uveitis is in remission, off drugs. In traumatic uveitis, this might be different, so it's probably best to ask Moorfields how long they expect you to be on treatment.
1/post_text/7: You have our sympathy about the high dose steroid and hopefully you'll see the benefit in your sight to make it worthwhile.

2/post_text/7: Take care
6/post_text/8: As far as infection goes, most people stay healthy. You should, however, avoid those coughing and sneezing and take quite a lot of care with handwashing when you're in public places, like tubes and buses. Hand gel is helpful and if you avoid touching your face, you greatly reduce the chance of picking up others' bugs and viruses. I'm careful where I eat and what I choose from menus.
6/post_text/9: With side effects, you adapt to them over time more often than them subsiding! If they are too bothersome, they'll try a different drug instead. If blood tests show an adverse effect, again a different drug will be used. You'll have regular blood tests to keep a watch on the side effects.
6/post_text/10: How long you remain on Myfenax is something to ask the consultant. With autoimmune uveitis it is often for two years at least. With your uveitis, if it's traumatic uveitis, it might be different.
6/post_text/11: The ANA test picks up autoimmunity. I expect it's already been done. Again, ask at the consultation for the results of all your tests and an explanation of what they were for and what the results mean.
6/post_text/12: From what you've written about the change in treatment, it sounds as though a second opinion, at this point, would not be helpful. Myfenax is effective and another consultant is likely simply to tell you to try it and see if it works.
6/post_text/13: I hope it does work and you're soon at the stage of inflammation put out, macular oedema gone and life returned to normal, albeit with Myfenax. And don't worry about further questions - it's takes a long time to get something resembling a grip on all this stuff.
15/post_text/10: I don't think you have made an assumption.  Many consultants are happy to say the eyes are clear when actually they are 1+, it's always best to check what their definition of a clear or quiet eye is! I learnt this the hard way with my daughter who's now blind in one eye due to a cavalier attitude and over reliance on steroids.  Her other eye has been saved so far due to an aggressive approach of combining immunosuppressants by an expert who does not tolerate any cells full stop.

0/post_text/0: How long can steriod eye drops be used? Before becoming a concern ??
1/post_text/1: It depends.
1/post_text/2: For some patients, using steroid eye drops to control anterior inflammation is the safest treatment, even though eventually they will cause cataracts to develop. These patients typically have no diagnosed systemic autoimmune disease which requires treatment and their flare ups of acute uveitis come with lengthy intervals between them. If steroid drops raise ocular pressure, that can be managed with pressure lowering drops. In these cases, the eventual development of cataract and short lived, manageable pressure problems are considered lesser evils than the potential side effects of immunosuppressant drugs.
1/post_text/3: When inflammation is chronic, steroid eye drops do become a concern, especially if they affect pressure. In these cases, patients are offered immunosuppressant drugs like methotrexate. Once the immunosuppressant is controlling inflammation, the steroid drops can be tapered and stopped. In an ideal world, the transition between drops and immunosuppressants would occur before cataract development has begun or there are problems with pressure. In the real world, it can be three to six months and sometimes even longer, before a treating doctor has a good idea how the patient's uveitis is likely to pan out and whether or not the patient would benefit from immunosuppression. When immunosuppression treatment is begun, the steroid drops may be needed to put out inflammation while the 'trial and error' of doses and choice of drug takes place.
1/post_text/4: The situation is further complicated by the treatment preferences of the patients and the treating doctors. Some doctors treat anterior uveitis with drops in the hope that the uveitis will run its course (can take years) and the patient emerge with most sight still intact, albeit with artificial lenses in their eyes and perhaps glaucoma surgery carried out. Other doctors prefer to treat the immune system with systemic drugs to avoid the sight threatening consequences of chronic inflammation and side effects of steroid and they will change the dose of an immunosuppressant or alter the choice of drug when inflammation persists.
1/post_text/5: The short answer is that in approx. 50% of patients, cataract formation will begin after about 850 drops. The cataract itself may take several years before it begins to affect sight. As far as eye pressure goes, some people are steroid responders i.e. pressure goes up and some are not.
1/post_text/6: If you are new to uveitis, reading the Uveitis and Treatments sections at the top of the page will help you understand what you are dealing with and the treatment options.

0/post_text/0: Hi all, I have posterior uveitis which flares every 2-3 years and the last two episodes have resulted in a significant macula odema. I live in the Portsmouth area and have no faith in my treatment at the eye department there. My last flare up was discovered last December and I was sent home knowing I had significant inflammation and oedema and was given steroid drops to be taken every 2 hours and no follow up offered for SIX weeks! It makes me feel sick to think of all the poor people going home in good faith just going blind as a result. Anyway, having previously been a private and then NHS patient of Prof Ayliffe I made an appointment as soon as I got back from the hospital. I saw him a week later and my inflammation was well controlled but needed to tackle the oedema. (Steroid dropped to 4 times a day and pressure was up so the fact Portsmouth would have left me for 6 weeks means my sight would have been threatened by the treatment and lack of treatment for the oedema)
