0/post_text/1: Prof Ayliffe started me on ciclosporin along with various drops and I saw him weekly. He no longer has an NHS clinic but offers a very reasonable rate for self-funders and I truly believes works magic on eyes. I was very desperate around Christmas trying to navigate the mix of private and worrying that it was such a serious condition with serious medication that I felt v vulnerable being out in the wilderness essentially managing my own care. I rang the helpline between Christmas and New Year and spoke to a wonderful lady (thank you whoever you were) who did the right amount of support whilst instilling a sense of fear and urgency that no, I could not stick my head in the sand about this.
0/post_text/2: I kept my appointment with Portsmouth 3 weeks later just to see what they would say and to take advantage of a free OCT scan and the uveitis 'specialist' there said he wouldn't offer any treatment for my oedema as I am a steroid responder and it would just make my cataract worse and 'everyone I have operated on has had a worse outcome. Eyes filling with fluid, losing sight, massive flares up' imagine how sick and worried and despairing I left that room. So unprofessional I think. He also said as the oedema was so large it may structurally reduce in size but would have damaged my sight anyway as the cells had stretched. I decided there and then never to be at the mercy of that department again and to only use the walk in clinic.
1/post_text/5: Thanks for posting, Claire.
0/post_text/3: Back to Prof Ayliffe the following week who gave me a steroid injection for the oedema, continued immuno-suppressant meds and various pressure-reducing treatments. It cleared up the oedema within weeks, pressure was managed and all lost vision returned. As predicted it did advance my cataract but it makes sense to me to preserve as much vision as possible and then try and deal with the cataract when appropriate. Otherwise there is 100% possibility of sight loss, first from lack of treatment and eventually from cataract too.
0/post_text/4: In April Prof Ayliffe felt the time was right for my cataract op as three months inflammation free, still some steroid in my eye to help control post-op inflammation and already on the cocktail of drugs that would be used in complicated cataract surgery (the approach of true uveitis specialists)
0/post_text/5: My outcome? Successful treatment of inflammation and cataract surgery, vision in my left eye better than it has EVER been, appt last week showed I was inflammation-free and I am gradually tapering my drug levels down.
0/post_text/6: NHS involvement-in January I made an appointment with my GP and explained the dilemma and asked what they could support me with on the NHS. He agreed to prescribe all the eye drops, do my blood tests for ciclospoirn (as long as the results were faxed to Prof Ayliffe who took responsibility) and agreed to refer me to an out-of-area true specialist. He wrote to Prof Ayliffe for advice on the best person and I was recommended Nigel Hall in Southampton/Winchester and have been so impressed with his approach and openness to my combination of care. He uses immuno-supopresants so I have finally been able to get most of them prescribed via my GP surgery now.
0/post_text/7: Private ciclosporin: for several months I funded this myself as the GP was nervous to prescribe until I was within the NHS system again. The best place to get it is from Sainsbury. I rang around a lot of places and they were easily half the price. They prescribed Neoral which when I was taking 150mg twice a day cost about £45 a week. My local one was amazingly flexible and hung on to my private prescription dispensing as and when I needed it to save me the cost of getting it all in one go and as I lived in the hope of getting it on the NHS ASAP.
0/post_text/8: In summary you have to become an expert in your own care and patch together the best bits you can find and navigate a way through them all working together. It is SO hard when you are feeling at your lowest and desperate and scared, to motivate yourself, and I just wanted to stick my head in the sand to ignore the fact I had a sight threatening condition which is clearly going to plague me throughout my whole life. If at all possible see Prof Ayliffe, he works miracles and I just do not understand why my local department is not interested in how he achieves it. His cataracts stats are (I hope I have got these right!) 95% improved vision, 3% no change and 2% deterioration. Compare to Portsmouth consultant who told me 100% are worse off. I accept the limitations of a service but I do not accept him not referring me on to another specialist who offers alternative treatment. I would have lost vision in my left eye if I had put my trust in that department.
0/post_text/9: Obviously it has cost me a lot this year especially with the surgery but I feel that just pushing within the NHS can get you better treatment and each episode that happens I now piece together my care again ready to set it in motion when the next emergency happens.
0/post_text/10: I'm really sorry this is so long, I'm not very good at concise. Thank you all who post on here especially those that respond so frequently and give so much support. Thank you to that lady who gave up her time over the Christmas holidays to answer that helpline to me. Good luck to us all in our continued journey with this tricky and awful condition. Best wishes, Claire

0/topic_title: Methotrexate and my three year old
1/post_text/1: Sorry your daughter has uveitis.
1/post_text/2: I think many parents find it difficult to accept a drug like methotrexate is needed to help their child retain sight so you're very far from alone there. Some parents who delay moving on to methotrexate when advised this is the best way forward, later say they wished they had started it sooner as their child deals with inflammation that is chronic, cataracts and in some cases, the problem of raised ocular pressure which becomes difficult to control.
1/post_text/3: Hearing and reading about the potential side effects of methotrexate is frightening. It helps a bit to keep in mind that methotrexate is used in low doses to treat uveitis and the side effects are therefore considerably less than those experienced by patients on the high doses needed to treat other conditions. With regular blood tests carried out to monitor for side effects, the drug is generally used very safely in uveitis. Should a blood test reveal anything abnormal, the child misses the next weekly dose and does not restart methotrexate until blood results are back to normal. Stopping the drug for a week usually means that the repeat blood test shows things are back to normal. Your daughter will be very well looked after to ensure mtx does her no lasting harm.
1/post_text/4: The most common side effects experienced by children are feeling tired the next day and nausea. Some children will experience a little thinning of the hair. Some children experience nothing at all. There are ways of dealing with side effects and I imagine you have the number of a specialist nurse who you can ring should anything really worry you. Should a child not be able to tolerate mtx at all, there are other treatments.

0/post_text/0: I have read your stories on here, and I see that some are new to the experience and aren't sure what to expect. I wrote a blog about my ordeal over the years, losing my vision, medications, procedures, depression, and accepting my life. I want to urge anyone looking for information to read it, I put in some things that you won't find elsewhere. One thing that I want to stress to parents is the side effects of medications. I was on high-dose Prenisone, Cyclosporine, and Methotrexate and experienced heart problems (while on them), now have degenerative vertebral discs, and an arthritis-like pain in all of my joints that will only get worse. These are things that can happen to you or your children, so I want everyone to be aware. It is worth taking the medication to control the inflammation, but be very aware of residual effects that these drugs can have on the body. Also, I've had many procedures done on my eyes and can offer advice on them to anyone who might find it helpful. I'm sorry that we are all having to go through this, but I believe that we can all help one another. Though I'm only 27, I'm a veteran when it comes to this stuff, so if you feel that I might be of help to you, my door is always open to my fellow sufferers and I will help in any way that I can.
